abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  Three or four weeks ago, there were four hundred and fifty soldiers, Maine men, remnants of regiments, and many among them wounded, going home on furlough by the Fall River line. The Government gave them their passage, but no rations. The few passengers, who learned that these men were supperless, promptly did what they could toward supplying them, and the very walters stripped the tables...

lead_paragraph: We find in the New Orleans papers of the 24th inst. a long letter from Gen. BANKS, addressed to Senator LANE of Kansas, on the subject of reconstruction in Louisiana. Gen. BANKS alludes briefly to the protest of Messrs WADE and DAVIS against President LINCOLN'S refsual to sign the bill for the reconstructton of government in seceding States, and says it was perfectly apparent that its authors but imperfectly understood the condition of things, and had been misled by their informant. He then shows that the provisions of the bill had been complied with, in every essential particular, in the attempts to reconstruct a loyal government in Louisiana. He says:

abstract: Election This; What it is Worth; Northern Encouragements of the Rebels
snippet: Election This; What it is Worth; Northern Encouragements of the Rebels
lead_paragraph: There are those who think it a great misfortune that a Presidential election should take place in the midst of the war. They talk dismally about the country being racked by terrible political excitement, when civil war already imposes upon it as much as it can endure. On the contrary, we hold that the occurrence of the Presidential election at this stage of the war is most fortunate -- that it is a signal vindication of the wisdom of our fathers in providing that this election should recur every four years, instead of the longer interval which was advocated, and which the Southern traitors afterward actually incorporated into their spurious Montgomery Constitution.
headline: {'main': 'What this Presidential Election is Worth.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What this Presidential Election is Worth.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: By the arrival of the Saxonia off Cape Race yesterday we have three days later intelligence from Europe. The news is not important. MULLER, the murderer of Mr. BRIGGS, who was apprehended in this City, had arrived in London,...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the Saxonia off Cape Race yesterday we have three days later intelligence from Europe. The news is not important. MULLER, the murderer of Mr. BRIGGS, who was apprehended in this City, had arrived in London, and was undergoing an examination. The London Times says that the rapture of Atlanta is regarded as the crowning success of the Southwestern army. The rebel Loan fell three per cent on a report of the surrender of Mobile. A new Spanish ministry had been formed, who had announced a conciliatory policy. The demand of Denmark that the troops of the allied armies in Jutland are not to be pensioned by Denmark has been absolutely rejected by the German Powers.

abstract: We had the pleasure yesterday of meeting a gentleman who has been a resident of Little Rock, Ark., for the past seven months, and who left that city Saturday last, on his way to his old home in Lincoln, Illinois. This gentleman represents the season as having been extremely unhealthy in the region of Little Rock, and far more so than has for some years been known by the people living there.
lead_paragraph: We had the pleasure yesterday of meeting a gentleman who has been a resident of Little Rock, Ark., for the past seven months, and who left that city Saturday last, on his way to his old home in Lincoln, Illinois. This gentleman represents the season as having been extremely unhealthy in the region of Little Rock, and far more so than has for some years been known by the people living there. Refugees are constantly coming in from the more southern sections, in a sad condition of poverty and disease. The army authorities kindly furnish them with rations, but being to a large extent deprived of shelter, and being poorly clad, their sufferings are such as to appeal loudly to the sympathies of the humane.

abstract: Message Vetoing Rejoicing on Union Victories
snippet: Message Vetoing Rejoicing on Union Victories
lead_paragraph: Whatever else he may, or may not be, Mayor GUNTHER is a "Democrat" in the party acceptation of the word. His orthodoxy has never been disputed or doubted. He is and always has been in good and regular standing ing. The party elected him, not so much on account of his splendid talents or of his brilliant personal qualities of any sort, as because he was known to be a genuine, unmistakable, unadulterated disciple of the modern Democracy. They have made him Mayor, and naturally enough he now feels bound to represent their principles, and carry out their views.

abstract: Lytton, Sir E B; Poems and Ballads of Schiller; Disraeli's Amenities of Literature; Keith, Mrs C P; Memoir by W G Tenney; Boker's, G H, Poems of the War; Lowell's, J R, Fireside Travels; Schiller's Poems and Ballads; by Sir E B Lytton
snippet: Lytton, Sir E B; Poems and Ballads of Schiller; Disraeli's Amenities of Literature; Keith, Mrs C P; Memoir by W G Tenney; Boker's, G H, Poems of the War; Lowell's, J R, Fireside Travels; Schiller's Poems and Ballads; by Sir E B Lytton
lead_paragraph: In any book with Professor LOWELL'S name attached to it the reader is sure of meeting with acute observation, fine and delicate fancy, a lively sense of the humorous, and a graceful diction that gives point and vivacity to every sentence. These qualities will all be found in the volume before us, but those who really appreciate LOWELL'S talents, and regret the rarity of his appearances in public, will be disappointed to observe how thin is the staple of the work. It is composed of four or five magazine articles, originally published, ten years ago, in Putnam's Monthly and the Graham of that period, and having served their turn in this capacity, were scarcely worth rescusitating in all the luminous emblazonment of Messrs. TICKNOR's clear open type and hot pressed paper. Two of them relate to home subjects "Cambridge Thirty Years Ago" and a "Moosehead Journal." These are decidedly the most attractive portion of the book, and are written con amore, with a far-searching wealth of allusion and occasional happy grotesqueness of idiom that recalls not faintly some of CHARLES LAMB's descriptive essays. "Leaves from a Journal in Italy" occupy the remainder of the volume, and have additions from old letters and journals written on the spot. Though they suffer from the immense mass of printed matter extant on the same perennial topic, they are redeemed from commonplace by the individuality of the writen who says his wish was "to describe not so much what he went to see, as what he saw that was most unlike what one sees at home." Fireside Travels must be accepted as an earnest of greater things from Prof. LOWELL, and we hope their favorable reception will incite him to further confidences with the public.
headline: {'main': 'NEW BOOKS.; FIRESIDE TRAVELS. By JAMES RUSSELL LOWELL, 12mo. Boston: TICKNOR & FIELDS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'NEW BOOKS.; FIRESIDE TRAVELS. By JAMES RUSSELL LOWELL, 12mo. Boston: TICKNOR & FIELDS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Seventh Vermont Regiment, under command of Col. HOLBROOK, will arrive in New-York today, en route for the Gulf, having reenlisted. They will sail on Monday for New-Orleans and will, while here, receive the hospitalities of the Sons of Vermont. This regiment will be remembered for the conspicuous valor and gallantry of its Colonel and men in the first battle of Baton Rouge, where the lamented Gen. WILLIAMS fell.

abstract: Gen. N.P. Banks, United States Army, accompanied by two members of his Staff, Col. J. Grant Wilson and Capt. J. Schuyler Crosby, arrived in the City, yesterday, from New-Orleans, per steamer Suwonada. The General and his Staff, who are in the enjoyment of excellent health, proceeded immediately upon their arrival to the Astor House, where the General's family were in waiting. They will remain at the Astor House until Tuesday next, and probably longer. Gen. Hurlburt remains in charge of the department at New-Orleans.

abstract: -- The Citizens Association County Convention meets next week. They will probably make no independent nomination, but will make up a ticket composed of the best men nominated by the different parties. The Association think they will be able to elect such a ticket, although they are as yet young in the field. The doings of the Convention will be looked for with considerable interest by politicians as well as others.
lead_paragraph: -- The Citizens Association County Convention meets next week. They will probably make no independent nomination, but will make up a ticket composed of the best men nominated by the different parties. The Association think they will be able to elect such a ticket, although they are as yet young in the field. The doings of the Convention will be looked for with considerable interest by politicians as well as others.

abstract: The St. Louis Union of the 28th says dispatches received at Headquarters from North  Missouri report that our troops had a fight with TODD'S and THRAILKILL'S guerrillas on Sunday, the 25th, in which thirteen of the rebels were killed, including two captains, one of them named BISSELL, of Platte County.
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Union of the 28th says dispatches received at Headquarters from North Missouri report that our troops had a fight with TODD'S and THRAILKILL'S guerrillas on Sunday, the 25th, in which thirteen of the rebels were killed, including two captains, one of them named BISSELL, of Platte County. After the fight theguerrillas moved to Huntsville, and demanded the surrender of the town; but the militia under Col. DENNY defied them, and prepared for resistance; and the rebels, learning that Major KING, with reinforcements for the post, was close at hand, drew off, and moved to Middle Grove.

abstract: -- The first convention after the primary meetings met in the Town of Flatlands yesterday afternoon, at 2 o'clock. The convention was organized by the election of Hon. GEORGE HALL, as President, and Mr. C.W. THOMAS, Jr., as Secretary. After admitting the delegates, which occupied a long time, an informal vote for Register was taken. Five informal ballots were then had, and on the last the vote stood as follows: Whole number of votes, 125; Benj. R. Wilson, 69; Joseph Reeves, 56. Mr. Wilson was declared the nominee by a unamimous vote. The nominations for County Clerk, Superintendent of the Poor, Coroner and Justice of the Sessions was then entered into. The result for County Clerk was as follows: Georga J. Hardy, 64; Henry Hill, 30; J.J. Anderson, 7; P.J. Ostrander, 24. Mr. Hardy having received a majority of the votes east, was declared unanimously nominated. Mr. Isaac Skidmore was nominated as Superintendent of the Poor. The Coroner and Justice of Sessions had not been settled at a late hour.

abstract: Cooperative Movement Toward Richmond
snippet: Cooperative Movement Toward Richmond
lead_paragraph: Of the sudden, rapid, bold and remarkable series of movements around Richmond, inaugurated by Gen. GRANT on Thursday morning, we know just enough to leave us in considerable bewilderment. To the dashing and unexpected movement on the north bank of the James, were yesterday added two other movements of equal or greater magnitude on other lines -- making altogether three great, distinctive and simultaneous operations in progress upon the enemy's position -- not to speak at all of the movement of Gen. SHERIDAN in the Shenandoah Valley. Yesterday morning Gen. WARREN, who has been for six weeks planted on the Weldon Road, about a couple of miles south of Petersburgh, and who formed the left wing of our army, attacked and carried the enemy's line on their extreme right, and, says GRANT, "immediately prepared to follow up his success." The third of the cooperative movements is under Gen. MEADE; and regarding this -- perhaps the most important of all -- the Lieutenant-General simply gives the following sentence: "Gen. MEADE moved from his left this morning, and carried the enemy's line near Poplar Grove Church." This sentence was probably not intended for the popular eye, and neither in its grammar nor its topography is it very easily defined. But we suppose the pronoun his refers to Warren's "left," and that from the latter's position on the Weldon road MEADE struck in a northerly direction for the railroad running from Petersburgh to Burksville Junction, and thence diverging to Danville and to Lynchburgh. GRANT says that MEADE "carried the enemy's line near Poplar Grove Church," and we find "Poplar Grove" where we should suppose the Church ought to be, indicated in our map on the above mentioned railroad, and located only about fifteen miles from WARREN's position, or left, on the Weldon road. GRANT's dispatch is dated at half-past three yesterday afternoon, and MEADE might have made this fifteen-miles march between the time he started in the morning and that hour. This would undoubtedly be a bold and perilous march and movement, and we shall wait further advices before endeavoring to clear up the entanglement. The operation, however, has long been anticipated by strategists, and it is one that, according to what is understood to be GRANT's programme, is essential.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The sale of tickets for the opening night on Monday next goes on in spite of the bad weather with unprecedented velocity. Yesterday there were but four seats left in the sections reserved for the Fourteenth-street customers. Mr. MARETZEK'S down-town reserves are pressed in...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The sale of tickets for the opening night on Monday next goes on -- in spite of the bad weather -- with unprecedented velocity. Yesterday there were but four seats left in the sections reserved for the Fourteenth-street customers. Mr. MARETZEK'S down-town reserves are pressed in the same way, and he will have to call them in, in order to keep open his communications with the public. About the first night's house, there is no longer a doubt. It will be thoroughly fashionable and full. Certainty is not one of the attributes of operatic management, but it seems almost certain that the forthcoming season will be the brightest and most remunerative on record. The principal boxes and the choicest seats have nearly all been disposed of for the season, and we think we are right in saying that no Manager of late has opened with prospects so flattering, or a subscription list so long.

abstract: Copperhead Press in London, >amp;c.
snippet: Copperhead Press in London, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The picture of the condition and prospects of the United States on which a portion of the English is now fondly dwelling, as revealed to us by the latest European mails, furnishes some very profitable matter for reflection to all Americans. We believe all our readers are aware, by this time, that the ruling classes is England have been from the outset as anxious for the disruption of the Union as any men could be, who were not actually engaged in a conflict with us. They desired it for several reasons, none of which they have had any hesitation in avowing. They feared that this Republic was becoming so vast and powerful that its existence would upset what is called "the balance of power," the creation and preservation of which, have taxed the resources of all European nations during the last three centuries. They feared, too, that the continued success of the experiment of democratic government in this country, would give immense impetus and support to the democratic movement in Europe, which, in the opinion of most observers on the other side of the water, threatens, in a generation or two, the complete destruction of all the existing aristocracies, and the resolution of all European Governments into democratic despotisms like that of France. To this tendency the Southern rebellion has been considered likely to give a most decided check, as it has been made in support of thoroughly oligarchic ideas, and in direct opposite to the government of majorities, and to the prevailing idea of human equality. We were clearly mistaken at the outset of the war in attributing so much of the English hostility to us to the effect which the war was likely to have on the cotton supply. That, after all only affected the manufacturers and mechanics. "Good society" in London, was influenced by considerations of wider range.

lead_paragraph: The latest news from Gen. GRANT is up to five o'clock yesterday afternoon. Yesterday morning Gen. WARREN advanced from his position on the Weldon Road and attacked the enemy's extreme right, carrying their line of works handsomely, with a number of prisoners. He immediately prepared to follow up his advantage. Gen. MEADE, according to the dispatch, also moved out another force from his left, and carried the rebel works near Poplar Grove Church, in the direction of the Danville road. Our forces on the North side of the James successfully hold all the ground they gained on Thursday. During yesterday afternoon the rebels assaulted our position near CHAPIN's Farm, but were handsomely repulsed by Gen. BUTLER's forces.

abstract: Dr. Studley's Reminiscences of
snippet: Dr. Studley's Reminiscences of
lead_paragraph: Fort Lafayette is, I should judge, about four or five hundred yards from Long Island shore, at a point where stands Fort Hamilton, and about a half a mile from Staten Island shore, at a point where stands Fort Richmond, thus making in this connecion a most formidable protection against our floating enemies. Most of the year the few minutes' sail required to take you from Fort Hamilton thither is a pleasant one; but in the Winter this narrow run is frequently blocked with dense masses of ice, so much so that it is a herculean task to force a way through it. It was exposure here, together with my arduous and unpleasant duties at Fort Hamilton, where I was required, in addition to the hospital duties, to attend night and day over one hundred camp families, together with officers, including even naval officers and their families anywhere within a circuit of a mile and over, that finally led to broken health, which, together with other causes, obliged me to resign my position. The fort is somewhat in the shape of a card diamond, presenting the angles nearly in the direction of the cardinal points of the compass. It stands upon a foundation about four hundred feet square, containing an open area within its walls. The casemates on the ground floor, together with some rooms with vaulted ceilings constitute the prisoners habitations. These vaulted rooms -- about twenty feet in length by about twelve in width -- were the more honored receptacles of prisoners of State and such as require close or solitary confinement. The number of prisoners generally ranged from 60 to 100. It will be remembered that these prisoners were by no means all prisoners of war. They may, for convenience sake, be divided into two classes, viz: 1st, prisoners of war, comprehending such as were captured while acting with and confessedly aiding the enemy, and 2d, political prisoners, embracing such as were considered as giving aid and comfort to the enemy, and such as were discovered in contraband trade. In regard to the suspension of the writ of Habeas Corpus by Government as a war necessity and the consequent placing of so many objects of suspicion within the walls of Fort Lafayette, I have little or nothing to say. That many have been placed there unjustly is not denied by Government, as is confessed in the act of setting them free upon a due investigation. By far two little consideration is given by the masses as regards the perplexing and harrassing dilemma in which Government has been placed all through this war from the first attack on Sumter to the present, full as much by foes within as without, and it is a matter of doubt whether any Administration, of whatever political phase it might be, would not have pursued the same course. Admitting its propriety in the midst of such tempestuous emergencies, it would certainly be not a little surprising if some of the innocent should not be made to suffer with the guilty. But, on the other hand, supposing such a political course to be necessary, what should be done, it strikes me, is this: When, upon due inquisition, the parties arrested and incarcerated are found faultless, let Government proclaim their innocence, duly remunerate them for their losses, and then ferret out and properly punish their false accusers. Such a course, I am sure, would diminish arrests upon mere suspicion, and go far to remove the furrows that cloud the brows of many who hesitate not to utter hard things of our Government, and speak bitterly of American bastiles.
headline: {'main': 'Reminiscences of Fort Lafayette,', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Reminiscences of Fort Lafayette,', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: New-York; Duncan >amp; Reed's, Waterstreet; $300,000
snippet: New-York; Duncan >amp; Reed's, Waterstreet; $300,000
lead_paragraph: DAMAGE, $300,000. -- Shortly before 12 o'clock, last night, a fire broke out in the bakery of Mr. CHAS, T. GOODWIN, No. 230 Front-street, near Peck-slip. Owing to the combustible nature of the material in the building, the flames spread very rapidly, and before the firemen were on hand, the fire extended through to Water-street. Messrs. DUNCAN & REED, occupied premises Nos. 245, 247 and 249 Water-street, as a tin and sheet iron shop and warehouse, which were entirely destroyed. Their loss will amount at least to $200,000. The entire block from Front to Water streets is an entire wreck. The damage to the buildings will amount to $100,000 at least. How the fire occurred is not known at present. Fire Marshall BAKER will investigate the case immediately. The Police of the Second, Fourth, and other Precincts were promptly on hand and tendered very valuable services.

abstract: Rebel Treatment of Our; Barbarities to Prisoners
snippet: Rebel Treatment of Our; Barbarities to Prisoners
lead_paragraph: Of all the conduct that has forever stained and sullied the vesture of Southern chivalry -- that has even stripped it of its false garb of honor, and compelled it to stand plainly and undisguisedly in all its infamous blackness before the people of the North -- none has been more perfectly characteristic of Southern baseness and inhumanity, than the general treatment of those of our unfortunate soldiers who have fallen into rebel hands as prisoners of war. Not all the repudiations of public debts -- not all the pilferings of the United States property at the beginning of the war -not all the less excusable dishonesty of the systematic fraud by which Northern merchants were designedly cheated of millions of prearranged debts, bear the stamp so perfectly of the true Southern standard of honor and civilization, as does rebel conduct in this matter.

abstract: The final struggle for the possession of Virginia is now near. This war draws to a close. If Richmond is held by the youth till the 1st of November it will be ours for evermore, for the North will never throw another large army into the abyss where so many lie; the war will conclude, beyond a doubt, with the independence of the Southern States.
lead_paragraph: The final struggle for the possession of Virginia is now near. This war draws to a close. If Richmond is held by the youth till the 1st of November it will be ours for evermore, for the North will never throw another large army into the abyss where so many lie; the war will conclude, beyond a doubt, with the independence of the Southern States. Events have made this city, in itself insignificant, the keystone of the arch. Probably the last immense effort which the enemy is now about to make, would not be attempted had not Atlanta fallen into the hands of SHERMAN. But SHERMAN's triumph compels GRANT to match it or sink into insignificance.

lead_paragraph: The well-known firm of Messrs. CLARK, DODGE &c Co., bankers, at No. 51 Wall-street, has for some time past had occasion to suspect that their cashier, Mr. LORING W. WATSON, was in the habit of appropriating to his own use large amounts of money from time to time. An examination of the books of the firm, made yesterday morning, revealed the fact that WATSON had made divers false entries for the purpose of balancing them, and thereby covering up his defalcations.

abstract: The War Department, yesterday, received an official dispatch from Gen. SHERIDAN, dated at Harrisonburgh, Va., Sept. 29, 7:30 P. M., in which he gives full details of the pursuit of EARLY up to that time. He says that the most reliable accounts show that EARLY'S army was completely broken up and demoralized, and gives it as his impression that most of the troops EARLY had
lead_paragraph: The War Department, yesterday, received an official dispatch from Gen. SHERIDAN, dated at Harrisonburgh, Va., Sept. 29, 7:30 P.M., in which he gives full details of the pursuit of EARLY up to that time. He says that the most reliable accounts show that EARLY's army was completely broken up and demoralized, and gives it as his impression that most of the troops EARLY had left, passed through the mountains and fell back upon Charlottesville. SHERIDAN kept up the pursuit to Port Republic, destroying seventy-five wagons and four caissons. He sent Gen. TORBERT to Staunton, with WILSON's division of cavalry and one brigade of MERRITT's. TORBERT entered Staunton on the 26th, and destroyed a large quantity of rebel Government property, harness, saddles, small arms, hard bread, flour, repair shops, &c. He then proceeded to Waynesboro, destroying the iron bridge over the south branch of the Shenandoah, seven miles of the track, the depot buildings, a Government tannery, and a large amount of leather, Hour, &c., at that place.

abstract: The Second District Republican Congressional Convention met at Lattimer Hall, in Court-street, yesterday afternoon, and after twelve ineffectual ballotings adjourned until Tuesday next, at 12 o'clock M. The first ballot stood: Samuel T. Maddox, 24; Archibald M. Bliss, 28; Henry A. Kent, 14. The twelfth ballot showed the following result: Maddox, 25; Bliss, 31; Kent, 10; S.B. Dutcher, 3. There being no choice, the convention adjourned.

abstract: Burnhan, Brig.--Gen.
snippet: Burnhan, Brig.--Gen.
lead_paragraph: This noble and gallant officer fell at Chapin's farm, on the 29th inst. It is simple truth to say that a braver and more conscientious soldier never lived. Not bred a professional military man, yet entering into military service with all the enthusiasm of a national soldier, combined with that high sense of duty which he felt as a patriotic citizen, and which placed him foremost in every place of danger. Under the lead of such a man it was no wonder that his old regiment, the Sixth Maine, loved him, and followed his brilliant example through many fiery streams of death. That regiment never broke -- side by side with the gallant old Fifth Wisconsin, we have seen them go into battle, or supporting each other, seen them charge and take such fortresses as the heights of Fredericsburgh. They were worthy of such a leader, and their leader was thrice worthy of all the honors he ever received. He was a man who never failed to do his duty, and the promotion to a Brigadier-General's commission, last Winter, was but small recompense for such distinguished gallantry as he exhibited in the great charges at Fredericsburgh and Rappahannock Ford. He fell in an other charge; but it is worthy to note that the position charged was taken. Such men we cannot afford to lose.

abstract: Prussia and Her Poles
snippet: Prussia and Her Poles
lead_paragraph: The Germans of Schleswig-Holstein, at the outbreak of the war of liberation, were not the only oppressed nationality under the sun. Beneath the sway of the very Powers which drew the sword against Denmark, lived peopies whose lot was still more unenviable than that of the inhabitants of the Duchies. The lot of the Prussian Poles, for instance, is by no means a happy one; and, if we may judge from a trial now in progress at Berlin, other races beside the Teutonic need champions to redress their wrongs, and other sovereigns beside King CHRISTIAN need correction. There are at present arraigned before one of the high judicial tribunals of the Prussian metropolis, at the suit of M. VON BISMARK, for the crime of treason, several Polish gentlemen, natives of the Grand Duchy of Posen, and subjects of the Brandenburgher. The indictment against these men is of so voluminous a character that twenty-four consecutive audiences had to be held ere its reading could be completed, the natural inference from which would, of course, be that the crime of the accused must have been of a very atrocious complexion. But what were the acts which imparted to it this somber die? Did the traversers conspire to raise an insurrection against their King, or plot the massacre of the Prussian garrison quartered in their Duchy? Did they, by uttered word or overt act, give any indication that they harbored disloyal and treasonable designs, inimical to the safety of the State, and the monarch's supremacy? Not at all. In none of these respects were they guilty. The head and front of their offending consisted merely in the expression of sympathy for their brethren, and in aiding them so far as they were able. This, however, though well calculated to rouse the ire of WILLIAM and VON BISMARK, could hardly be made to amount to treason. The Prussian King may have regarded the Russian Poles as common enemies of himself and the Czar, but his Polish subjects did no violence to their oaths of allegiance, and committed no offence against their proper Sovereign; and anxious as the Minister-President is to establish against the prisoners the charge of treason, it is not very probable that he will succeed. Even in Prussia, the prosecutor must furnish some proof of the imputed crime, in order to obtain the condemnation of the accused. But VON BISMARK is totally unable to do this, unless reckless assertion is accepted in lieu of proof. "Where are the facts?" asks Dr. GUEIST, the eloquent advocate of the defendants, "and if there are no facts, then are these men being prosecuted for their thoughts and sentiments -- a mode of proceeding which would carry us back to the trials of the Jews in the dark ages."
headline: {'main': 'Prussia and Her Poles.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Prussia and Her Poles.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Sergt-Maj. HASTINGS returned home on Monday night, having been unsuccessful in arresting any of the Lake Erie pirates of whom he was in search. He traced them from this city to St. Catherines, where they stopped for a day, each one at a different hotel, and thence proceeded to London. HASTINGS followed them there, but could find no trace of them. On Saturday morning a Detroit detective, in
lead_paragraph: Sergt-Maj. HASTINGS returned home on Monday night, having been unsuccessful in arresting any of the Lake Erie pirates of whom he was in search. He traced them from this city to St. Catherines, where they stopped for a day, each one at a different hotel, and thence proceeded to London. HASTINGS followed them there, but could find no trace of them. On Saturday morning a Detroit detective, in company with a couple of other detectives, arrived here in search of the pirates, and on hearing that they had been seen in St. Catherines, they proceeded there. They are yet engaged in the chase, and are sanguine of ere long capturing them. The affair seems to have been badly managed throughout, or the fellows would have been taken before this. They travel in no secret manner, and always register their names in full at the hotels where they stop. When in this city they registered their names as follows: R.L. Smith, Brislow Clark, O. Dunn, Hoits, Robert Drake, Capt. Bell. A not very minute description of some of them has been telegraphed to the police authorities in different parts of the country; it might be of assistance in detecting them, and therefore we publish it.
headline: {'main': 'The Lake Erie Pirates.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Lake Erie Pirates.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: LORING W. WATSON, for some time past a cashier and confidential business agent of the well known banking firm of CLARK, DODGE  Co., at No. 51 Wall-street, was arrested yesterday by Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Precinct Police, on the charge of embezzling large sums of money from his employers. A hasty examination of the company's books yesterday morning, showed that he had stolen at least $12,000, and it is believed
lead_paragraph: LORING W. WATSON, for some time past a cashier and confidential business agent of the well known banking firm of CLARK, DODGE & Co., at No. 51 Wall-street, was arrested yesterday by Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Precinct Police, on the charge of embezzling large sums of money from his employers. A hasty examination of the company's books yesterday morning, showed that he had stolen at least $12,000, and it is believed by some of the members of the firm that WATSON's defalcations -- extending through many months -- will reach at least 840,000. He was caught aboard the mail steamship City of London, just as that vessel was ready to sail for Europe. Upon being searched, $450 in British gold and a large quantity of silver were found in his possession. He confessed to having embezzled a portion of the sum of $12,000, on or about the 19th day of April last. He is 24 years of age, a native of Brooklyn. Until very recently he had been regarded by his employers as a thoroughly honest business man, and was by them highly esteemed.

abstract: The Morris and Essex Railroad Company are engaged in preparations for building the new coal branch of their line, from near Rockaway, via. Boonton, to Montclair, and thence over the Newark and Bloomfield Railroad to Newark. The route has already been surveyed, the iron purchased, and the line is now being located, but it is not decided whether ground will be broken this fall, or delayed until spring. Mr. J.B. BASSINGER, the late efficient Superintendent, is devoting his whole attention to his duties as Chief Engineer of the road, and is superintending the construction of the extension from Hackettstown to Phillipsburg.

The route has already been surveyed, the iron purchased, and the line is now being located, but it is not decided whether ground will be broken this fall, or delayed until spring. Mr. J.B. BASSINGER, the late efficient Superintendent, is devoting his whole attention to his duties as Chief Engineer of the road, and is superintending the construction of the extension from Hackettstown to Phillipsburg.

abstract: The Captain and seven of the crew of the Spanish bark Csis, were arrested yesterday morning and brought before the Commissioner, charged with resisting United States officers in discharge of their duty. It appeared that the bark had been libeled and was ordered to be sold by a decree of the Court. In persuance of which order one of the Marshal's officers proceeded to remove the anchors and chains. The Captain headed the crew, and obliged him to desist from his work by threats and force. The Spanish Vice-Consul appeared for the prisoners, and satisfied the Commissioner that the men were ignorant that the Deputy was armed with the authority of the law, and that no intention to resist the decree of the court was intended. Upon this statement the accused were discharged.

abstract: on McClellan and Pendleton; Men North and Rebels, Unanimity of
snippet: on McClellan and Pendleton; Men North and Rebels, Unanimity of
lead_paragraph: It is very interesting to watch the complete concurrence of thought, of feeling, and of hope which exists between the MCCLELLAN men at the North and the rebels at the South. The rebels cheered for McCLELLAN in the trenches before Petersburgh, and there are many men who support McCLELLAN who do not hesitate to say they would rather have JEFF. DAVIS for their President than Mr. LINCOLN. Both alike feel the importance of Union defeats to MCCLELLAN's success. They have the same ends in view in case he is elected. Says Hangman FOOTE, in a letter to the Richmond Whig: "If MCCLELLAN and PENDLETON are elected, outraged and indignant public sentiment will demand the arraignment, trial and deserved punishment of the enormous traitors and murderers who are responsible before God and man for all the abominable crimes and mischiefs which this unpardonable war has produced." How completely the McClellan men agree with him in charging the responsibility of the war not upon the rebels who rose in arms to overthrow the Government, but upon those who have striven to keep the oath which they had taken to maintain it. FOOTE expects to see President LINCOLN and his Cabinet executed as traitors it MCCLELLAN is elected. So does VALLANDIGHAM, who said in his recent speech in favor of MCCLELLAN at Sydney, Ohio: "If the war stops, the war power perishes with it, and in the hands of a Democratic President, his (Mr. LINCOLN's) head and the heads of those around would come to the block."

abstract: Upon complaint of the Commissioners of Emigration, Frank Knowles, second mate of the ship Cornelius Grinnell, was arrested and brought before the Commissioner yesterday, charged with the seduction of a female emigrant, a passenger from London. It seems that the girl. Annie Daly, came to this country in the Grinnell on her last voyage to New-York. During the passage she became intimate
lead_paragraph: Upon complaint of the Commissioners of Emigration, Frank Knowles, second mate of the ship Cornelius Grinnell, was arrested and brought before the Commissioner yesterday, charged with the seduction of a female emigrant, a passenger from London. It seems that the girl. Annie Daly, came to this country in the Grinnell on her last voyage to New-York. During the passage she became intimate with prisoner, and he took advantage of her friend less condition to accomplish her ruin under promise of marriage. Not fulfilling his engagements since his arrival in New-York, and being about to sail on another ship for California, the girl became alarmed and stated her case to Mr. Casserly, Superintendent of Castle Garden depot, who immediately caused the arrest of Knowles, when the accused ascertained the penalty attached to his offence viz., a fine of $1,000 and a year's imprisonment. Upon conviction, he was speedily convinced that it was his duty to marry the girl that he had wronged.

abstract: London Times on the Chicago Convention; London Index on Will the South Reenter the Union
snippet: London Times on the Chicago Convention; London Index on Will the South Reenter the Union
lead_paragraph: One of the bloodiest battles of the Peninsular War was fought after peace had been concluded, and it seems as it the great American struggle would be crowned with a similar superfluity of carnage. While the most powerful party in the North was proclaiming its abomination of the war and its resolute demand for peace, the Northern armies in Virginia and Georgia were engaged in the most obstinate and sanguinary conflicts. In Virginia the advantage remained with the Confederates, who had been the assailants; in Georgia the Federerals, if the occupation of Atlanta is truly reported, may claim the credit of the day. But, though Atlanta may at last have been occupied, the covering army has not been routed, and a successful combination of Confederate forces threatens SHERMAN with serious embarrassment. At Mobile Admiral FARRAGUT is displaying that tenacity of purpose which has characterized the Federal tactics throughout the present campaign, and, if his progress be slow, he exhibits at least no signs of discouragement. But in the meanwhile a voice has gone forth which may still the thunder of the cannon. The Chicago Convention has not only declared the principles on which the great Democratic party is prepared to act, but has demanded, in the name of the people, that negotiations shall be immediately instituted for the suspension of arms. An armistice at once, a conference as soon as possible -- these are the cries now resounding through the States of the North; and unless they can be disregarded -- which is not easy to suppose -- we may relieve ourselves from the trouble of further speculations on the events of the war.

abstract: A few days ago a report was circulated that, owing to the scarcity of rations served to the sentenced prisoners in the Athenaeum, they had been compelled, in the face of actual starvation, to catch and cook rats. The report coming to the ears of Capt. OVER, he went to the prison to institute an investigation. He soon learned that the boys really caught, killed and cooked some rats. One of the guilty parties was called up, and upon being interrogated, said that the boys had a curiosity, to know how a young rat, being properly stewed, wauld taste. Accordingly, several rats were caught and served up. "Well, how did they go?" asked the Captain. The culprit replied that, to his taste, there was very little difference between a rat and a young squirrel, and although, he said, the rations were sufficient, if no objection were interposed, he would like to have the privilege of cooking and eating a rat when he felt like it. -- Wheeling Intelligencer.

abstract: on Reconstruction and Re-Union; Scheme for Ending the War
snippet: on Reconstruction and Re-Union; Scheme for Ending the War
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Courier has a scheme of its own for ending the war. It is an arrangement which the Confederate powers at Richmond, if true to the fundamental principles of their system, ought to accept. The Courier would have the whole question at once referred back for solution to the individual States. "There is nothing," it says, "in the spirit of the Constitution and in genuine American institutions and elements of Government and political relations, forbidding one State from communicating with another State." "A recurrence to the States," the Courier further says, "must form a part of any solution of the war question, and a faithful observance of the rights and relative duties of the States must be a condition of permanence and success for any league or compact that can be formed for any number of States."

abstract: From Louis A. CUNNINGHAM and other Union men, direct from Keytesvllle, Chariton County, we learn the full particulars of the bloody affair which has just attracted attention to that quarter. The occurrences at that point bring out in strong light the designs of the rebel leaders now in Missouri, and we therefore have taken pains to gather them as fully and accurately as possible. It would appear that they consider their policy to embrace politics as well as military operations. How they hope to succeed in the former is shown by the details given below.

abstract: and the Spanish Bondholders
snippet: and the Spanish Bondholders
lead_paragraph: The English who were so green as to exchange their cash for Spanish bonds may cheer up -- there is some prospect of their being paid. Her necessities are moralizing Spain. Those schemes of conquest which she is attempting to carry out in the Western World cannot be realized without gold -- those public works which are needed to facilitate the developement of her internal resources, cannot be undertaken without gold; and Spain has none to spare for such purposes, neither can she borrow it, for her credit is at so low an ebb that she could not raise a cent on any bourse in Europe. The pressure of circumstances then, is beginning to convince at length the Spanish press and Spanish statesmen that repudiation and roguery have their disadvantages, and that, in the long run, honesty is the best policy as well for nations as for individuals. This conviction has brought about a marked change in the tone of the editors and politicians of Madrid, quoad the case of the Spanish bondholders. Up to a very recent period said writers and publicists treated the claims of their unfortunate creditors with the greatest contempt, invariably repelling them with the stereotyped rejoinder that they could not recognize the existence of a debt which had been long ago canceled by the State. Now, however, that the Dons find themselves under the necessity of redeeming their credit ere they can get the needful, they seem disposed to discuss the question of their liabilities, and in a late number of the Diario Espanol, a Ministerial journal, there appears a three-column article on this distasteful theme. The author of this essay, while admitting the fairness of the bondholders' claims, endeavors to palliate Spanish wrong-doing in relation to them by ascribing it to the vituperation of the British creditors and British press. The dignity of Spain was so shocked, forsooth, at the rude violence of these angry English and their advocates, that to punish their insolence she withheld from them their cash. It is probable, however, that this British outcry contributed not a little to bring the Spanish Government to a sense of its delinquency, since it put all Europe on the qui vive as to the unreliable nature of Spanish pledges, and served as a proclamation of financial outlawry against Spain. But be this as it may, the time has come, even in the opinion of the Diarion redacteur, when the case of these bondholders should be brought before the Cortes, with a view to a liberal settlement of their claims; and he urges the industrial corporations and financial establishments of the country to make manifest to the Government and the nation the pernicious consequences which have resulted from Spain's backsliding in this matter.

lead_paragraph: It is worth while to recall the main facts of the splendid movements north of the James River, which commenced before daylight on the morning of Thursday last, and which, according to the latest accounts, leaves our forces in full possession of the outer line of defensive posts on the east and northeast side of Richmond, which, commencing with Fort Morris, at Chapin's farm, one mile from the river, extend in a curving line across the Newmarket, Central and Charles City Roads.

abstract: -In our dispatches from Cairo, some months ago, a strange charge who made against Mrs. Major BOOTH, WIDOW of the gallant officer who was murdered at Fort Pillow. The allegation was, that while acting as Government searcher, she knowingly refrained from seizing gold purporting to be passing beyond our lines to the enemy. With lively satisfaction, we learn from the Memphis Bulletin that an investigation of the case has resulted in the honorable discharge of the lady. It is much to be regretted that an accusation so injurious, yet false, has been preferred, and we especially regret that our columns, through a correspondent, were made the medium of the charge. We trust our cotemporaries, East and west, who have given currency to the aspersion, will aid us in making the amends to a worthy and as is now evident [???]erse[???]ed woman, -- St. Louis Democrat.

lead_paragraph: THE FIRE IN FRONT-STREET. -- The insurances on the Front-street fire could not be fully ascertained yesterday, owing to a number of the proprietors being out of town. It is estimated that Mr. GOODWIN'S loss on stock will be about $4,500, said to be covered by insurance; and that the damage to the building. Nos. 228 and 230 Front-street, will be about $20,000. Messrs. DICKERSON, REED & CO., Nos. 243 and 245 Water-street, tin and sheet iron dealers, lose $5,000 on stock, which is insured for in the Continental, Firemens', Trust and Market Insurance Companies, for $5,000 each, and in other companies for various sums. Damage to building $30,000. Messrs. COOK & NICHOLS, provision dealers, at No. 226 Front-street, sustain a damage of $5,000. Damage to building $1,500. Insured. J.I. & J.G. FROST, flour dealers, at Nos. 232 and 234 Front-street, sustain a damage of $1,000. Insured for $1,500 in the Continental Insurance Company. SULLIVAN, MURPHY & Co. occupied a portion of No. 247 Water-street, tobacco dealers, sustained a damage of $5.000. Insured.

abstract: A Libel on Our Armies
snippet: A Libel on Our Armies
lead_paragraph: The averment of the Chicago platform that the war is a failure, is a slander upon our officers and our soldiers. It impeaches their skill and their courage. The world knows that no armies were ever better supplied with all the material of war, and that there has been, in the main, no lack of men for coping, on equal terms, with the enemy. If all this has ended in our being worsted, the prime reason must lie in our military inferiority to the rebellious South. But we have not been so worsted. The assertion is a base Copperhead calumny.

abstract: HEAVY ROBBERY. -- A woman named ANN DOHERTY was arrested on Saturday by Officer LYNCH, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, on a charge of having, in connection with ANN DONOHUE, stolen the sum of $855 from ROBERT MCKELVIN, an engineer on board of a Government vessel. It is alleged that the accused induced MCKELVIE to enter Mrs. DONOHUE's house in North Seventh-street, Eastern District, and while he was asleep took the money. About $400 of the missing money was recovered.

abstract: On Saturday evening a number of War Democrats of this City, opposed to the Chicago platform and its candidates, met at the Bancroft House, Broadway and Twentieth-street. On motion, Hon. PETER COOPER was called to the Chair, and H.W. JENNINGS was appointed Secretary. The object of the meeting was stated to be for conference and consultation among Democrats opposed to the Chicago candidates, and the platform, and general harmony and enthusiasm prevailed.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday evening a number of War Democrats of this City, opposed to the Chicago platform and its candidates, met at the Bancroft House, Broadway and Twentieth-street. On motion, Hon. PETER COOPER was called to the Chair, and H.W. JENNINGS was appointed Secretary. The object of the meeting was stated to be for conference and consultation among Democrats opposed to the Chicago candidates, and the platform, and general harmony and enthusiasm prevailed. The universal feeling was; no surrender of flag or principles to rebels in arms against the country, and no armistice that would give the traitors any advantages over the soldiers of the Union. The recent victories in behalf of the Union were also warmly applauded. JOSEPH F. ELLERY, Esq., on behalf of the Committee of the City and County of New-York, and H.C. PAGE, Esq., on behalf of the War Democratic State Committee, stated that the respective bodies represented by them had appointed committees to make arrangements for a mass ratification convention in the City of New-York, of the War Democracy, and hoped the meeting would appoint a like committee of cooperation. Letters were read from Hon. F.B. CUTTING, and others, regretting their inability to be present, but sympathizing with the objects of the meeting. After some debate, in which Messrs. GEO. W. GLAZE, Hon. and Whitfield, O'Neil, McCartin, and others participated, it was unanimously resolved to appoint a cooperating committee. The Chairman stated that he would announce the Committee next Tuesday evening, to which time, after the transaction of some other business, the meeting adjourned.

abstract: The Grand Jury of Passaic County have indicted the Paterson Horse Railroad as a public nuisance, giving as a ground for this action that "the said railroad has been located and constructed without regard to the convenience of travel, and at some points to the great injury of private property. The kind of rails laid upon the road is very objectionable, and in several instances wagons have been broken in turning out of the same. In some places the road does not conform to the established grade of the street." At the time the charter for this road was obtained, great opposition was manifested to it by many people of Paterson, and this action of the Grand Jury is probably an out-cropping of the original feeling. -- Network Advertiser.

abstract: Pecuniary Stake in the Rebellion
snippet: Pecuniary Stake in the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: The enormous extent of the pecuniary interest which the English commercial world has in the result of our war, may be conjectured from the fact that the mere rumors of peace, backed up by the authority of the London Times, came very near producing a panic in the money market, and caused a greater fall in consols than has been witnessed for many years. The number of people who are speculating on a continuance of the war by holding cotton, fitting out blockade-runners, &c., is very large; and so is the number of those who are speculating on its early close, by holding Confederate bonds, and making preparations for prodigious exports to Charleston and Savannah as soon as the ports are open to Confederate free trade, also very large. Whichever of these two parties should prove right in their calculations, the other will be ruined; and we may guess, therefore, that neither would refuse to spend money freely to bring about the result it most desires.

abstract: -- The Central Committee of the St. Louis Fremont Clubs recently convened to take action concerning the withdrawal of FREMONT and COCHRANE, and passed the following preamble and resolution: "Whereas, the nominees of the Radical Democracy, JOHN C. FREMONT and JOHN COCHRANE, have withdrawn from the Presidential canvass. Be it Resolved, The Central Committee of the Fremont Clubs of the City and County of St. Louis is hereby dissolved. The Central Committee recommends the Fremont Clubs to reorganize as the Radical Democratic Clubs, on the basis of the Cleveland platform, and to elect a new Central Committee."

abstract: The Academy of Music opens to-night under the direction of MAX MARETZEK, who is decidedly the right man in the right place. VERDI's "Trovatore" is the work selected for the occasion, and it will afford the means of introducing two new artists to our public. MLLE. CAROSSI-ZUCCI is the Leonore, and Signor MASSIMILIANI the Manrico; the lady is Mr. MARETZEK's principal prima donna, and the gentleman is the leading tenor. MLLS. MORENSI makes her rentree as the Gipsey, and Signor BELLINI as the Count. With such a cast much may be expected of the performance. Mr. MARETZEK has secured an entirely new orchestra, and has made very important additions to the strength of his chorus. For the rest we must wait until this evening. The house will be extremely full and fashionable.

abstract: KINGS COUNTY UNION NOMINATIONS. -- The Kings County Union Conventions have thus far nominated the following gentlemen for the offices named: Congress -- Third District, Hon. Hardy; Superintendent of the Poor, Isaac Skidmore; Coroner, Elias Lynn; Justice of Sessions, Wm.H. Hoyt; Police Justice. Chauncy Perry; Justice of the Peace -- First District, Conklin Smith; Justice of the Peace -- Second District, H.R. Bradshaw; Assembly -- Fifth District, John C. Perry; Sixth District, George B. Magrath.

abstract: The sales of Cotton for the week foot up 37,000 bales. The market was very irregular and dull, and prices had declined 3/4 d.@ld, for American, and 1 1/8 d.@3d. for other descriptions. The sales to speculators were 5,500 hales, and to exporters 15,500. The sales on the day of the sailing of the steamer were 5,000 bales, the market closing unchanged. abstract: DROWNED. -- A man named PATRICK MCGEE, residing at No. 87 Essex-street, Jersey City, while intoxicated, fell into the Morris Canal near the foot of Warren-street, about 10 o'clock on Saturday night, and was drowned. The body was recovered yesterday, and an inquest was held by Coroner FARREL, and a verdict of accidental death was rendered. Coroner FARREL also held an inquest Saturday, on the body of a little daughter 8 years of age, of Capt. HOWE, who had been missing several days, and whose body was found in the canal near Greenville, where the parents reside. The little girl was last seen standing on the canal bridge, and it is supposed accidentally fell overboard.
lead_paragraph: DROWNED. -- A man named PATRICK MCGEE, residing at No. 87 Essex-street, Jersey City, while intoxicated, fell into the Morris Canal near the foot of Warren-street, about 10 o'clock on Saturday night, and was drowned. The body was recovered yesterday, and an inquest was held by Coroner FARREL, and a verdict of accidental death was rendered. Coroner FARREL also held an inquest Saturday, on the body of a little daughter 8 years of age, of Capt. HOWE, who had been missing several days, and whose body was found in the canal near Greenville, where the parents reside. The little girl was last seen standing on the canal bridge, and it is supposed accidentally fell overboard.

abstract: Policy; What is It?
snippet: Policy; What is It?
lead_paragraph: The country is waiting with great anxiety to hear Mr. PENDLETON's views not only with regard to the Chicago platform, but with regard to that portion of Gen. MCCLELLAN's letter which announces that, in case negotiation should be tried and fail, the war should still be prosecuted. What we want to know is, whether he too is of opinion that the war ought to be continued in any contingency or any circumstances whatever, or whether he adheres to the opinion which he held before his nomination, that "coercion" as a means of securing submission to the authority of the United States Government, is in all cases unlawful, and that therefore the enterprise in which we have been engaged for the last four years has simply been murder and robbery on a great scale.

abstract: Struggle and the Nation's Triumph
snippet: Struggle and the Nation's Triumph
lead_paragraph: We have not a doubt that our armies will be triumphant in this great war; nor have we a doubt that President LINCOLN will be reelected to the Chief Magistracy of this Republic. But it is not enough that we be assured of the ultimate success of our military struggle, nor is it enough that Mr. LINCOLN be barely reelected. It is supremely desirable that the rebellion be promptly and forever crushed, and that the popular patriotism sustain and reinforce our armies to that end. And it is supremely desirable that Mr. LINCOLN be reelected by a popular majority so great, and by an expression of opinion so decisive, as to show indisputably the power and determination of the loyal sentiment of the nation. It is not enough that the Unionists attempt to carry the requisite number of States, but they should energetically struggle to carry every State. It is not enough that there should be a languid interest in the matter; but there should be an earnest, enthusiastic, persistent effort. We should show to the rebels the strength of our purpose, and its unflinching character. We should show it to the world. We should show it to the generations who shall come after us. The moral influence of such a demonstration would be immense, both at home and abroad. The effect of a triumph of the disgraceful and cowardly Chicago platform would, we believe, be fatal to the unity, power and glory of the country.
headline: {'main': "The Nation's Struggle---The Nation's Triumph.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Nation's Struggle---The Nation's Triumph.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The price of Gold fell to 189  cent, on Saturday. The Railway Stocks were very much depressed. The Government Stocks were a fraction easier, while Treasury Certificates were firm. The Secretary of the Treasury proposes to award $40,000,000 of new 5-20 Bonds to the highest bidders, on the 14th October, receiving 25 cent, of the awards in Treasury Certificates.
lead_paragraph: The price of Gold fell to 189 1/2 cent, on Saturday. The Railway Stocks were very much depressed. The Government Stocks were a fraction easier, while Treasury Certificates were firm. The Secretary of the Treasury proposes to award $40,000,000 of new 5-20 Bonds to the highest bidders, on the 14th October, receiving 25 cent. of the awards in Treasury Certificates.

abstract: No official intelligence of the great movement now progressing in Virginia, has reached us of later date than the dispatch from Secretary STANTON, which we published yesterday; but we have received highly interesting details of the operations on the extreme left of Gen. GRANT's army, and of the movements on the north side of the James. Both here and on the left we have nothing but substantial success to chronicle. Our troops, both white and colored, fought with unequaled heroism, and by their deeds of valor have earned imperishable renown.
lead_paragraph: No official intelligence of the great movement now progressing in Virginia, has reached us of later date than the dispatch from Secretary STANTON, which we published yesterday; but we have received highly interesting details of the operations on the extreme left of Gen. Our troops, both white and colored, fought with unequaled heroism, and by their deeds of valor have earned imperishable renown.

abstract: -The real import and relative bearing of our armies in Virginia, on both sides of the James River, and on the Weldon and Southside Railroads, are not yet apparent. It is unknown which of the movements is the main one, or what is the point really aimed at. The positions attained, and the successes achieved by each of the various columns on Thursday and Friday, were of great importance; but neither of them has yet reached a logical conclusion. We shall doubtless, however, very speadily have a definite development of this great campaign.

abstract: There was a largely attended and very enthusiatic meetingheld last evening at the hall corner of Broadway and Forty seventh-street. The Union men of the Twentieth Ward were out in their strength, and the demonstration was in every respect a grand mass meeting. At an early hour the hall was filled to its utmost capacity, and among the audience were a large number of ladies. Mr. R.B. BRADFORD was called to the chair, and the proceedings were opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Fox. After a song by the Glee Club and the election of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries, Mr. BELL, read an address from the soldiers of the army of Cumberland to the people of the loyal States. Mr. G.W. CURTIS was the first speaker introduced. He said, after some preliminary remarks, that for many years there had been a large, powerful, dominant party in this country. That party, properly speaking, took its origin in the year 1812, when Mr. CALHOUN came into Congress with the cry of war with England. From that time down to the close of the last Administration that party was of necessity a war party. The principle of the party had been "Our country right or wrong." That party fought the Seminoles in the everglades of Florida; that party, true to its instinct of war, stopped across the Rio Grande, and said, war exists in Mexico. That party sustained the war which Texas waged against Mexico, leading to the annexation of Texas: that party had always been a war party. Mr. CURTIS spoke at some length upon the nick-name the friends of Gen. MCCLELLAN bestowed upon him -- "Little MAC." He wished to know it any Democrat present did not consider Little MAO, the smallest NAPOLEON that was ever seen in the world. [Applause and laughter,] The party says, "look at this little military gentleman -- see the stars -- all the buttons -- is not this war." [Laughter.] Was this little military gentleman large enough to command the Hon. HORATIO SEYMOUR, the Hon. FERNANDO WOOD, the Hon. CLEMENT VALLANDIGHAM, who are so sedulously thrusting him forward? Is he large enough to hide Mr. GEORGE H. PENDLETON, of Ohio, who stands next to him and who is exactly of the same political stamp as Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS.

abstract: -- Seventeen hundred troops left this City yesterday, including three hundred and fifty who were forced by stress of weather to return to the harbor, after sailing for their destination on Saturday. Thirteen hundred of the number were New-York State troops, two hundred convalescents, the others detachments of new recruits from other States.
lead_paragraph: -- Seventeen hundred troops left this City yesterday, including three hundred and fifty who were forced by stress of weather to return to the harbor, after sailing for their destination on Saturday. Thirteen hundred of the number were New-York State troops, two hundred convalescents, the others detachments of new recruits from other States.

abstract: An admirably engraved steel portrait of the hero of New-Orleans and Mobile, has just been issued by DERBY & MILLER, No. 5 Spruce street, from the hand of Mr. RITCHIE, the well-known engraver, whose series of portraits of American heroes forms one of the finest collections of the kind ever given to the American public. This series already embraces the portraits of Gens. GRANT, HANCOCK and SHERMAN, all of which are admirable both as likenesses and as works of art.

abstract: -The steamship Victor, which arrived at this port yesterday, reports: Sept. 28, HARLOW PHILLIPS, of Eleventh New-York Cavalry, died and was buried at sea. Oct. 1, EDWARD KIRK, of Company F, New-York Cavalry, died and was buried at sea. Oct. 2, J.N. JONES, Acting Assistant Engineer, United States Nayy, died and was also buried at sea.

abstract: Transactions in most descriptions of produce and merchandise were on a restricted scale yesterday. The very unfavorable news a from Chicago tended decidedly to depress prices of breadstuffs, which were generally lower, with a light business. Provisions were unsettled, during the day, but closed heavily. Cotton, whisky, oils, tallow and groceries were quiet and declining. Freights were dull.

abstract: We discussed some months ago the propriety of putting to some proper and appropriate use, some at least of the immense number of rebel prisoners we have had in our hands for over a year. Their long and enforced idl[???]ess is in itself a cruelty, leading to listlessness, physical exhaustion, bad habits and viciousness, whereas if they had the liberty, under proper restrictions, to engage in such useful pursuits as they might select, they would at once add to their own happiness, educate themselves in valuable occupations, and be of service to the Commonwealth. The Richmond papers republished our article, and spoke of the idea as one of the most atrocious thatever entered the Northern brain. Whether because of its atrocity or not, the rebels, it seems, have been and are now practicing the system. A recent number of the Richmond Enquirer, speaking of the Union prisoners in the Confederate States, remarks:

abstract: The steamship Peruvian, with advices to Sept. 23, arrived off Father Point Sunday afternoon, and the Saxonia, from Southampton, Sept. 21, arrived at this port yesterday. The London press, the rebel organs particularly, discussed the latest American news vigorously, and admitted that Atlanta was the crowning success of SHERMAN's campaign, but insists, as usual, that the achievement will be of no avail in closing the war. A disastrous fire had occurred in London, involving a loss of $2,500,000. The examination of MULLER, the railway murderer, was in progress, and produced an excitement unprecedented in the annals of the court. The Danish question shows symptoms of another outbreak of hostilities in consequence of the refusal of Denmark, backed by Sweden, to agree upon the terms of peace. The Turin journals discuss the removal of the capital of Italy to Florence. The Opinione says that if this removal were necessary to advance the solution of the Roman question, the Italian Government could not assume the responsibility of a refusal.

abstract: Jacobites and Emigres; America's Disgrace
snippet: Jacobites and Emigres; America's Disgrace
lead_paragraph: There can be little question that the worst thing that will be said hereafter against our institutions, the thing which more than all else will lead posterity to doubt their value, will be that, after only eighty years' working, such a tribe of people as our Copperheads should have grown up under them. It is safe to say that the like of them, considering the advantages they have enjoyed, has never appeared in any country or in any age. England had her Jacobites, men who plotted against the public peace and public liberty in unison with foreign governments, who took pay from foreign despots for bringing confusion into the councils of their own country, who betrayed the navy and sought to betray the army, to the public enemy, to whom the national honor and independence were jests, and to whom the triumph of the Court party, or, in other words, their party, was their first and dearest aim. But then the Jacobites were courtiers, or were bred under Court influences, men who had been taught from their very cradles to despise liberty, and to think of the country as the royal domain, and of the King's prerogative as the only thing in it worth preserving. They grew up in an age when the great political principles which are now familiar in our mouths as household words, were but imperfectly understood, when but few peoples in Europe had solidified into nations, and when the claims of country were only beginning to asert themselves against those of creed and caste.
headline: {'main': 'The Disgrace of America.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Disgrace of America.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC OPENING OF THE SEASON.  A brilliant audience attended the opening performance here last evening, and extended to Mr. MARETZEK'S new artists the welcome wnice is seldom withheld from new comers. The opera was "Travatore," selected by the prima donna for her debut. It answered its purpose thoroughly, and placed Mile. COROSSI ZUCCHI in an enviable light before the public.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- OPENING OF THE SEASON. -- A brilliant audience attended the opening performance here last evening, and extended to Mr. MARETZEK'S new artists the welcome wnice is seldom withheld from new comers. The opera was "Travatore," selected by the prima donna for her debut. It answered its purpose thoroughly, and placed Mile. COROSSI ZUCCHI in an enviable light before the public. We reserve our own remarks on the general performance for a more timely occasion. However desirable for the prima donna. "Il Trovatore" does not afford any particular facilities to the critic. The interest is spread over a vast surface, and does not culminate until the last scene. To write of this at midnight is impossible. It must suffice, therefore, to say, that in the first act, Signora ZUCCHI created a decided impression. She was called out and applauded in the heartiest manner. Her voice is extremely pleasant, and is managed with consummate ability. In the tower scene of the last act, the enthusiasm was unmistakable, and fully warranted. Signora ZUCCHI may be recorded, then, as an emphatic success.

abstract: The conference committees appointed by the Union Central Judiciary Convention and the Union General County Convention, to harmonise upon local candidates, met last night at the Union headquarters, corner of Twenty-third-street and Broadway. Messrs. J.W. FARR and WALDO HUTCHINS presided. On motion, a sub-committee of ten from each body were appointed to report upon a division of office and candidates. The committee retired, and after an absence of about two hours, reported a resolution to refer the nominations to a committee of six. to be chosen from each convention. Mr. CHAS. SPENCER desired to substitute a motion dividing the offices. Pending discussion on this proposition, a motion to adjourn was carried.

abstract: Conscripts tired of their Work
snippet: Conscripts tired of their Work
lead_paragraph: We have had, during the war, so many stories of repentant rebel soldiers that have proved to be utterly worthless, that it is, perhaps, well not to lay too much stress on those that are so freely repeated at the present time. It does seem, however, comparing the reports of the various correspondents in the Valley with SHERIDAN, that LEE's conscripts are getting tired of their work; that they are getting tired, moreover, in large numbers, and that EARLY has actually lost more by desertion than he has in killed, wounded and prisoners. Every mile of the army's march up the Valley, our army has found squads of fugitives eager to get protection from their late military employers, and ready to march as far as their limbs could carry them away beyond the bounds of the Confederacy. The number of guns deserted by EARLY in his Southward flight is, in a measure, proof in itself, that his men could not be depended on. One great battle, and one only, has been fought since SHERIDAN crossed Opequan Creek -- the battle which began at Darkesville at gray dawn of Monday, the 19th of September, and closed on the outskirts of Winchester at nightfall of the same day. In the series of engagements which made up that battle, SHERIDAN took, in all, but five guns.

abstract: The latest intelligence from the Army of the Potomac reports no more fighting. A dispatch dated Sunday evening, says "the rebels fell back this morning to their main line of works, which runs from the lead works to the Southside road, or near it. This position of the rebels is a very strong one, and cannot easily be carried. A division of the Second Corps advanced to the Boynton road, over which the enemy wagon their supplies to Petersburgh. Two lines of works were found unoccupied, only a skirmish line opposing the advance, and falling back as our troops went forward.

abstract: The Sanitary Commission has long made Harper's Ferry a centre of operations. Though the late important battle of the Opequan was unannounced, Colonel Muhleck, in charge of the Commission's work at that point and vicinity, including Cumberland, Martinburg and Winchester, Va., was promptly on the field of the battle with his corps of assistants and stores, which were most welcome to the men and the Medical Department. The store-house at Harper's Ferry was quickly emptied, but the second day after the battle, a fresh supply of articles most needed arrived from Baltimore, where they had been stored in anticipation of such a call, forty buildings being appropriated for this use. The distance from the Ferry to Winchester, where the wounded were gathered, is thirty-six miles, without rail communication, and the country infested with guerrillas. Supplies were immediately pushed forward in wagons under the protection of a cavalry escort. Thirteen four-horse army wagons are used in this work, with the occasional addition of wagons and ambulances, generously provided by the military authorities. These wagon-trains are run day and night, and thus far without loss. For aid and protection in this difficult part of the work the Commission is greatly indebted to Gen. Stevenson, in command at Harper's Ferry, and Col. Edwards, Thirty-seventh Massachusetts Volunteers, commanding post at Winchester.

abstract: The live stock market shows a supply for the week of 45,803 animals, including 6,260 beeves, 151 milch cows, 2,192 calves, 22,614 sheep and lambs, and 14,586 swine. The market has shown a decline generally this week, owing in part to the heavy fall in gold, which has reduced the price of hides and tallow and skins. The receipts of beef cattle have been large, though several hundred less than a week ago, and have sold at a decline from last quotations of 1/2c.@1c. lb.; medium to good quality steers selling at 13c.@17c., and prime beeves at 18c., dressed weight. While really fine bullocks have been offered in limited numbers, the lighter grades have been in full supply. There were about 450 head of heavy cattle in the yards yesterday intended for Government, but had not been weighed. The sheep market at Sixth-street yesterday was heavily supplied, and prospects in the early part of the day favored a falling off from Monday; good sheep then sold at 8 1/2c., live weight -- common lots as low as 6c. Good lambs were worth 9c.; fine, selected ones would bring more. Hogs remain nearly the same as last week; prime corn-fed quoted at 12c.@12 1/2c., live weight; still-fed, 11c.@11 1/2c.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- We have already -- with the brevity becoming to a mere item of news -- recorded the success of Mr. MARETZEK's opening night. What remains to be said, we will say now. It is unnecessary to revert to the opera of "Il Trovatore," which is rather familiarly known here, except in the way of illustration. The merits of the work are thoroughly appreciated -- so thoroughly, indeed, that nothing but a new caste can give it vitality. This was provided by Mr. MARETZEK, whose reception was enthnsiastic, and of whose new artistes we have, therefore, only to speak. Mme. CAROZZI-ZUCCHI was the heroine. The lady, like many others who have preceded her, comes direct to us from Italy. Her career here will decide her standing in Paris and London; will decide whether she ever visits either of those cities. Brag as they may, we have generally better singers in New-York than they can boast of in any one theatre of Europe. From Mr. MARETZEK's occasional campaigns, the English houses, at all events, have been supplied for many years, and, in the matter of operas, the New-York house is generally ahead of the London ones.
