abstract: Landor, Walter Savage
snippet: Landor, Walter Savage
lead_paragraph: WALTER SAVAGE LANDOR. whose death at his villa near Florence, on the 17th of last month, has just been announced by the last European arrivals, was about the sole remaining literary man whose career as an author dates front the last century. He was born in 1775. His first book, a volume of "Poems," was published in 1795, when young LANDOR, the eldest son of wealthy parents, of the old English squirearcny, had declined, with characteristic independence, the military and legal professions for which his father successively intended him, and started on a life of freedom and literature. Though diversified by many incidental changes, this programme he steadily adhered to through the long term of nearly 90 years, and of more pronounced individuality than any of his cotemporaries, on succeeding to the family estates in Warwickshire, in the early part of this century, the routine life and narrow aims of a "large acred man" could not long confine the restlessness of his spirit. Before many years were over he had become disgusted with his ungrateful tenants, dissatisfied with his neighbors, and out of sorts generally with the rural world. The resolution to sell the property that had belonged to the LANDORS for seven hundred years, was soon taken and acted on. In 1808, he stood clear of all such trammels, and rushed with ardor into the contest then waging by the patriotic Spaniards against the Napoleonic lust of conquest and universal dominion. His participation in this struggle occupied him until the pacification of Europe in 1815, when he purchased the mansion and estates near Florence, where the greatest part of his life has since been spent. As a writer be flowered late. At his residence in Italy commences the period of his greatest literary productiveness. His noblest and most original work, Imaginary Conversations of Literary Men and Statesmen, was brought out in London, in two series, in 1824-'29, and was followed by a succession of other books, partly of the same character, as Pericles and Aspasia, (with a remarkable dedication to Gen. JACKSON omitted in the American reprint.) The Tentameroy, &c., -- partly poetical, as Gehr, Count Julean, &c., and partly personal and political, springing from the intense and highly wrought feeling that LANDOR exhibited toward every object that excited his love or his hate, and between the two passions, there was no middle-ground. Though spending most of his time 'in Italy, he kept up a home at Bath. Some of his appearances in England do not redound to his credit, and must be attributed to the perversion rather than the decay of his faculties, arising from extreme age. Mr. LANDOR married in 1811 a lady of Swiss extraction. He leaves a family of three sons and one daughter, to whom he some time ago made over the bulk of his fortune, reserving but little for himself. He presented the copyright of his works to MOXON, the publisher, by whom they were brought out in ten volumes, royal 8vo., 1847,

abstract: The steamship Europa at Cape Race on the 10th brings intelligence via Queenstown to the 2d inst. The British Government had determined to reduce the militia system about thirty per cent. The Manchester Guardian publishes evidence that employment is becoming more scarce in the manufacturing districts. A gunpowder explosion took place on the 1st inst., at the Dartford powder mills. Forty lives were lost. The shock was felt at London, at a distance of 15 miles. Public opinion in Spain urges the immediate settlement of the St. Domingo question.

abstract: A ROBBERY WHICH IS NO CRIME -- REMARKABLE CASE. -- THOMAS CUMMINGS, who for the last fourteen years has been a waiter at the Astor House, was arraigned yesterday before Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs Police Court, on the charge of having stolen from one of the rooms of that Hotel, $2,480, under the following circumstances: In April last. Mr. T.W. PARK, President of the First National Bank at North Bennington Vt., and Mr. C.G. LINCOLN, Cashier of the same, put up at the Astor House, and while there, were one day engaged in their room in signing bills of the denomination of $10, for their bank. While the room was left unprotected for a short time, bills to the amount of $2,480, signed only by the President, were abstracted therefrom. The Detective Police were notified of the theft, and Officers KELSO and RADFORD were commissioned to work up the case. No clue to the thief could, however, be obtained for a long time. About the middle of September last, two of these ten dollar bills came into the possession of Messrs. FISK & HATCH, bankers, of this City, and they noticed that the Cashier's signature was wanting. From this point the officers were able to trace the matter to the wife of CUMMINGS, and thence to CUMMINGS himself. He was arrested, and his residence at No. 53 Greane-street was searched. They there found about $1,600 of the missing money. The remarkable part of the case is, that when CUMMINGS was arraigned yesterday afternoon before the Justice, that official came to the conclusion, after an examination of the law of Congress, which authorizes the formation of National banks, that he had no authority to hold him for larceny. CUMMINGS was therefore set at liberty. It seems that the law in question provides that the bills must be signed by either the President or the Vice-President of the bank, and also by the Cashier. Those which CUMMINGS is alleged to have taken were signed only by the President. It was reported last evening that the accused had been rearrested by the orders of the United States Marshal.

abstract: DEMOCRATIC COUNTY CONVENTION. The delegates to the Democratic Convention for Hudson County met at Hudson City, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of nominating candidates for County. Clerk, Sheriff, Surrogate, and three Coroners. Mr. CHARLES E. NEWHAM was chosen Chairman and FREDERICK BOHNSTEDT Secretary. The following-named gentlemen were nominated: For Sheriff Bernard McAnally. For Country Clerk George W. Cassedy. For Surrogate James O'Neil. For Coroners Dennis Farrell, Martin Hanley and George S. Avery.
lead_paragraph: DEMOCRATIC COUNTY CONVENTION. -- The delegates to the Democratic Convention for Hudson County met at Hudson City, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of nominating candidates for County. Clerk, Sheriff, Surrogate, and three Coroners. Mr. CHARLES E. NEWHAM was chosen Chairman and FREDERICK BOHNSTEDT Secretary. The following-named gentlemen were nominated: For Sheriff -- Bernard McAnally. For Country Clerk -- George W. Cassedy. For Surrogate -- James O'Neil. For Coroners -- Dennis Farrell, Martin Hanley and George S. Avery. All of the above candidates were re-nominated with the exception of Mr. CASSEDY.

abstract: Great Campaign; Progress of
snippet: Great Campaign; Progress of
lead_paragraph: The vast line of investment which Gen. GRANT is forming around the great "intrenched camp" which the rebels have established at Petersburgh and Richmond, is ceaselessly progressing toward completion. In the execution of a task so formidable and complex as that which the Lieutenant-General has undertaken, much time is necessarily consumed. The drawing of what constitutes a strict line of siege around a city, stronghold or fortress may be very quickly done, as was illustrated in the cases of Vicksburgh, Port Hudson and Fort Morgan -- the only real cases of investment that we recall in the course of the war; and the final result in such instances is not long in being reached, as was shown in each of the sieges mentioned. But, at Richmond, Petersburgh and LEE's army are located, and as GRANT's army and lines are located in reference to the former, nothing more difficult in war could be conceived than the drawing of a cordon militaire around the enemy's position. The line must be of great length, must cross rivers and intersect railroads, and must maintain itself at every point. The advantages are largely on the side of LEE. With a powerful army in a central position, he can constantly menace and at pleasure strike at any part of our long line, or at either of our flanks; and if he should succeed in breaking or piercing our line, or turning our flank, the consequences might be disastrous to our operations. But though he has made several very furious and desperate attempts to effect this he has in all of them totally failed. He tried it against WARREN on our left -- tried it twice, and achieved nothing. He tried it against BUTLER on our right -- tried it twice, and achieved nothing. We have been steadily gaining new positions and extending our lines, and on each new advance LEE has attempted to drive us back; but in all he has only succeeded in temporarily checking us once. We refer to the late check of Gen. MEADE in his attempted advance on the Southside Railroad. Even there, however, it is evident the check was but a momentary check. Our correspondent at the left, in a letter of yesterday, made mention of the reconnoissance in force of the entire Fifth Corps, and Second Division of the Ninth Corps, on Sunday last, in the direction of the Southside railroad; and there is reason to believe that news of success in that quarter will soon reach us, even though LEE should "move a heavy column from Richmond" to prevent it. But although the Southside railroad were gained, GRANT's task would by no means be completed. There would yet be the Weldon road that must be reached, and still other and more difficult work to be done.
headline: {'main': 'The Great Campaign Its Progress and Prospects.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Great Campaign Its Progress and Prospects.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The price of Gold continued firm yesterday at Tuesday's advance, and Railway speculation was buoyant in the afternoon. Money easy at 7 cent. to the Brokers. The applications for the New Loan to be awarded on Friday, at Washington, are on the increase. To day (Thursday) is the last day for making preliminary deposits in the Sub-Treasury or with the National Banks. The bidding through the Treasury Office and First National Bank of this City already amounts to $19,000,000.

abstract: Monadnock, Iron-clad, Description and Officers; Idaho, Screw Frigate, Officers and Description; Report; Chattanooga to Atlanta; March 14 to Sept. 7
snippet: Monadnock, Iron-clad, Description and Officers; Idaho, Screw Frigate, Officers and Description; Report; Chattanooga to Atlanta; March 14 to Sept. 7
lead_paragraph: The report of Gen. SHERMAN, embracing a carefully-prepared narrative of military operations in the Southwest, from the day of his appointment as Commander of the Grand Division of the Mississippi, down to the entry of Gen. SLOCUM's corps into Atlanta, has been published officially. It was on the 14th of March that Gen. SHERMAN received notice from Gen. GRANT that he (Gen. GRANT) had been commissioned Lieutenant-General and Commander-in-Chief of the armies of the United States -- an appointment which would compel him to go East, and that he (Gen. SHERMAN) had been appointed to succeed him as Commander of the Mississippi. Immediately thereafter, Gen. SHERMAN began a tour of inspection, visiting Athens, Decatur, Huntsville, Chattanooga, Knoxville, and other military points within his new command. The new Commander, in this preliminary tour of observation, had interviews with Major-Gen. MCPHERSON, commanding the Army of the Tennessee, at Huntsville, with Major-Gen. THOMAS, commanding the Army of the Cumberland, at Chattanooga, and with Major-Gen. SCHOFIELD, commanding the army of the Ohio, at Knoxville. A general programme of the campaign in their interviews with the Lieutenant-General, and the various suboridinate army commanders was arranged. On the 27th of April all the troops, thus organized under SHERMAN's command were in motion towads Chattanooga, and on that day he himself was there in person. His aim was to have the army of the Cumberland 50,000 strong, that of the Tennessee 35,000, and that of the Ohio 15,000. These figures were approximated, although, from various causes, they were never quite reached. Here we quote from the Reports:

abstract: -- The Copperheads are claiming great gains in the town elections in Connecticut. The New-Haven Palladium says: We hear of but one town, Derby, that has left the Union column, while already four are reported -- North Haven, Guilford, New-Milford and South Windsor -- that are taken out of the hands of the Copperheads. We gain three towns on them, out of thirty-one reported. At this rate we should gain sixteen of their towns in the whole State -- ten per cent. of the whole number in the State, and twenty-five per cent. of all that have been in their hands during the year past.
lead_paragraph: -- The Copperheads are claiming great gains in the town elections in Connecticut. The New-Haven Palladium says: We hear of but one town, Derby, that has left the Union column, while already four are reported -- North Haven, Guilford, New-Milford and South Windsor -- that are taken out of the hands of the Copperheads. We gain three towns on them, out of thirty-one reported. At this rate we should gain sixteen of their towns in the whole State -- ten per cent. of the whole number in the State, and twenty-five per cent. of all that have been in their hands during the year past.

abstract: The, Political Sentiment of
snippet: The, Political Sentiment of
lead_paragraph: Trust who have been bored and disgusted during the last two years by incessant asser- tions of the devotion of the army to "Little Moe," will be sensible relieved by the vote which is now coming in from the soldiers of Ohio and Pennsylvania. If any soldiers love and admire him, it ought to be those from these States, for in one of them he first saw the light, and in the other he began his military career in this war. So that, if they do not vote for him, it is hard to say who will. One great argument which has always been used by the Copperhead faction for having him in chief command of the army, and letting him do as he pleased, has been this boundless devotion of the troops to him -- a devotion so great, in fact, that at one time it was alleged that it would prevent them from fighting under any one else. It was always easy to make this statement in the newspapers and on the stump, and as it was just as difficult to disprove it as to prove it, thousands, of course, believed it, just as thousands believe, on much the same kind of evidence, that MCCLELLAN is a great General.

abstract: SALARIES OF SCHOOL TEACHERS. The Brooklyn Board of Education resolved at their last meeting to increase the salaries of female teachers of the public schools to the extent of $5 per month, in addition to present salaries, for the months of October, November and December, 1864, and for January. February, March, April, May, June and July, 1865. An attempt was made to increase the salaries of male teachers of the public schools, but failed.

abstract: -- The recent Fall Book Trade Sale went off with reasonable animation in view of the exciting topics of the coming election, &c. Events of this nature, inevitably demanding a large share of the public attention, are notoriously unfavorable to the circulation of books in the same quantities that are consumed by the general demand, when there is an absence of any absorbing subjects, and the minds of people are free to amuse themselves with the products of literature. One fact was satisfactorily established by the sale which is, that the manufacturers' call for higher prices in consequence of the increased cost of book-making, was responded to without a murmur. In fact, the additional expense attending every branch of the manufacturing process was so well known to all the parties concerned in the sale, that the justice of the rise in prices was self-evident and could not be resisted. It may, therefore, be safely asserted that until some other turn of the monetary wheel takes place, the reign of cheap literature is over for the present. Scarcely any book can be published for one dollar, and the same class of publications that were formerly issued for that sum will now command one dollar and seventy-five cents to two dollars and a half, and the same proportion nearly, will hold good with larger books. How far this new state of things prepares the way for the reception of the English system of circulating libraries, some acute business man will probably show us before long. The quantities of books sold were not large, though, as mentioned above, the prices were generally satisfactory. There was an absence of the customary Western buyers, partially made up, by the presence of a number of the Canadian Book Trade, who on the prevailing state of the currency, are enabled to lay in stock on very advantageous terms. Scarcely any new publications were offered at the sale, but full assortments of standard books went off in the usual channels for distribution among the public. Of miscellaneous articles, photograph-albums were the most abundant. Several invoices of these showed an undiminished demand. The sale was conducted throughout with the usual ability displayed by Mr. COOLEY and Mr. GEORGE LEAVITT the auctioneers, in catering for the accommodation of the Book Trade.

abstract: Office in America; Gen Dix's Letter; Letter on Pub Office in America
snippet: Office in America; Gen Dix's Letter; Letter on Pub Office in America
lead_paragraph: The excellent letter from Gen. DIX which we published on Monday, contains some admirable remarks on the effect upon our polical condition, evoked by the practice in which all public parties have indulged, for the last forty years, of considering nothing but " availability " in the choice of candidates for the Presidency. Gen. DIX ascribes, and with great reason, most of the toils which now beset us to this most unfortunate tendency. Conspicuous ability, and experience in the conduct of public affairs, were, for a long time previous to the war, almost complete barriers to political advancement. A man no sooner made his mark in Congress, or in office, than he lost all chance of reaching the highest political prize. The great thing with conventions was to find men for their nominations who had no bitter enemy, -- not because they were general favorites, but because nobody knew enough of them either to like or dislike them. This was, however, not so much the fault of the conventions after all, as of the general popular contempt for all training and experience -- a contempt bred in a great measure by the circumstances in which the country was placed.

abstract: The returns from Pennsylvania now place the fact beyond doubt that there is a Union majority on the home vote of at least 5,000 -- all Copperhead assertions to the contrary, notwithstanding. The Congressional delegation will probably stand 16 Union to 8 Democratic, a Union gain of four. In Ohio the delegation will stand 17 Union to 2 Democratic, a Union gain of 12. In Indiana the Union majority increases as the returns come in. The State is carried by 25,000 majority, and it elects 7 Union Congressmen to 4 Democratic.
lead_paragraph: The returns from Pennsylvania now place the fact beyond doubt that there is a Union majority on the home vote of at least 5,000 -- all Copperhead assertions to the contrary, notwithstanding. The Congressional delegation will probably stand 16 Union to 8 Democratic, a Union gain of four. In Ohio the delegation will stand 17 Union to 2 Democratic, a Union gain of 12. In Indiana the Union majority increases as the returns come in. The State is carried by 25,000 majority, and it elects 7 Union Congressmen to 4 Democratic.

abstract: Powell's Picture of Perry Transferring his Flag
snippet: Powell's Picture of Perry Transferring his Flag
lead_paragraph: Mr. W.H. POWELL's picture of PERRY transferring his flag, comes opportunely with the anniversary of the battle of Lake Erie. The work, indeed, is at the present moment, on exhibition at Rhode Island, the natal place of the hero, and where it is proper that his deeds should be commemorated. It is not intended, however, for that gallant little State. Ohio claims it for her new and beautiful capitol at Columbus, and has patiently awaited its completion for more than five years. Beyond waiting, we have not been able to discover that Ohio has acted with any unusual degree of liberality toward the artist. Mr. POWELL has completed the picture entirely at his own cost. We mention this fact as creditable to the gentleman, and as evidence that in painting it he has been actuated by other than the mere motives of pecuniary gain. A patriotism not unworthy of the subject, it seems to us, is exhibited in the devotion of an artist who, for so long a time, bestows the best energies of his mind upon a work which can only be inadequately recompensed in the future. Mr. POWELL's happiest reward will come, not from the Legislature of Ohio, but from the hearty approval of his countrymen, and the consciousness thence derived, that he has interpreted a brilliant incident of naval history in a large and noble manner.

snippet: On Rebels Arming Slaves to Ravage the North; Daily News; Gloomy Pictures of
lead_paragraph: The demise of Chief-Justice TANEY comes almost like some strange visitation. For one full generation he has occupied the highest judicial position in the United States, and it almost seems identified with his name. The disturbance of old associations is all the greater, because it happens at the very height of the civil conflict which is linked indissolubly with the most important act of his judicial life.

abstract: Great Haul of at Port Jervis and New-York
snippet: Great Haul of at Port Jervis and New-York
lead_paragraph: For several months ingeniously executed fifty cent counterfeit notes, fractional currency, have been in circulation along the line of the Erie Railroad and in this City. So exactly did the bogus issue resemble the genuine, it had almost grown to be a custom not to refuse them in places where time in the matter of making change is a great consideration; and it was only at banking-houses and brokers' offices that they were detected and thrown out. This proving a great annoyance to our merchants and business men generally, the authorities at Washington were appealed to, and skillful detectives employed to seek out the counterfeiters. Under the direction of Col. L.C. BAKER, Chief of National Detective Police, Officers CLARVOE and MCDEVITT, of the Metropolitan Detective Force at Washington, the case was "worked up." For a long time Col. BAKER was in this City and elsewhere, employing much of his time in the discovery of the facts which led to the detection of the counterfeiters who have been manufacturing and putting in circulation these worthless notes.

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and map be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Death of Chief-Justice Taney; Taney, Chief Justice, the Death of; Outline of Chief Justice Taney's Obituary; Taney, Chief-Justice
snippet: Death of Chief-Justice Taney; Taney, Chief Justice, the Death of; Outline of Chief Justice Taney's Obituary; Taney, Chief-Justice
lead_paragraph: ROGER BROOK TANEY, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, died in Washington, at 11 o'clock Wednesday night, in the seventy-eighth year of his age. This distinguished American jurist was born in Calvert County, Maryland, March 17, 1777. He was descended from an English Roman Catholic family, which settled in Maryland about the middle of the seventeenth century. He received his education at Dickinson College, in Pennsylvania, where he was graduated in 1795. Four years later he was admitted to the bar, and began to practice in his native county, from which he was elected a delegate to the General Assembly. In 1801 he removed to Frederick. He was elected a State Senator in 1816; and six years afterward, on retiring from that office, he removed to Baltimore, where he continued to reside until his decease. In 1827 he was appointed Attorney-General of Maryland; and in 1831 President JACKSON conferred upon him the office of Attorney-General of the United States. Upon the dismissal of Mr. DUANE, Secretary of the Treasury, in 1833, for refusing to obey the order to remove the Government deposits from the United States Bank, President JACKSON appointed Mr. TANEY to succeed him. He immediately issued the order to remove the deposits to the local banks selected by him as agents of the Government. The Senate, which was opposed to the Administration, refused in 1834, by a vote of twenty-eight to eighteen, to confirm his nomination. The following year he was nominated by the President as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court; but the Senate virtually rejected him. On the death of Chief Justice MARSHAL, Mr. TANEY was nominated as the successor of that distinguished jurist; and the Senate, which, meantime, had changed its political complexion, confirmed his nomination in 1836.

abstract: The fuller election returns given this morning will be found to justify the statements and deductions heretofore made in this journal. The popular Union majority in Pennsylvania, on the home vote, seems to be somewhere about 5,000; while the 50,000 majority in Ohio and the 20,000 majority in Indiana stand unmoved. The soldiers' vote of the two former States will swell these majorities greatly. The first-reported gains in Congressmen also prove correct.

abstract: There is little of interest from the several armies in the field. No further information, either official or otherwise, has been received. The Armies of the Potomac and James were quietly in their positions. SHERIDAN is still quietly at Strasburgh, waiting for the rebels to trot out another new General for him to whip. SHERMAN is near the Chattahoochee, quietly watching HOOD. But no fighting is reported anywhere.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The repetition of  Luorezia Borgia" last evening attracted another good house, and the performance was generally and specifically good. Signora ZUCCHI was in excellent...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The repetition of Luorezia Borgia" last evening attracted another good house, and the performance was generally and specifically good. Signora ZUCCHI was in excellent voice, and acted finely. Mlle. MORENSI as Massio Orsini looked the part charmingly, and sang with much spirit. We were much satisfied with Signor LOTTI, and Signor SUSINI, too, was in steady and tremendous voice. The orchestra and chorus, under the able direction of Mr. PREDIGAM, were both capital.

abstract: The; late in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana
snippet: The; late in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana
lead_paragraph: Tuesday last was an eventful day in the history of this continent. A battle was fought then whose results shall reach further than those of any engagement fought during this war. The simple farmer who, in the valleys of Pennsylvania and Ohio, or on the prairies of Indiana, deposited a vote that day, did his part in deciding a contest whose effects shall influence all future history. When we look down through the vista of coming time, and think what we so narrowly escaped and what we probably gained on that day, the mind is amazed at the immense results dependent on rivial human actions.

lead_paragraph: The latest returns from Pennsylvania still show that there will be a small Union majority on the home vote, while the soldiers' vote is coming in solidly for the Union ticket. The Congressional delegation stands fifteen Union to nine Copperheads by the home vote, but the soldiers' vote will undoubtedly elect RUSSELL THAYER in the Fifth District, who is only thirty-five behind on the home vote. In Ohio the delegation now stands seventeen Union to two Copperheads.

abstract: Vote, the, and Gen. McClellan
snippet: Vote, the, and Gen. McClellan
lead_paragraph: What a rebuke of Major-Gen. McCLELLAN is contained in the soldiers' votes now sweeping in! If there be one soldierly fibre in his bosom, how it must tingle with shame. His friends have always claimed that he had a peculiar power of inspiring his troops with personal devotion. All his addresses to them show that he made this a special object. Grant that he succeeded. Admit to the fullest extent all that his home admirers claim about his personal popularity with the soldiers. It makes their present rejection of him all the more dishonoring.
headline: {'main': 'The Soldiers and Gen. McClellan.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Soldiers and Gen. McClellan.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Spirit and Wealthy Men; (Railroad Fares)
snippet: Spirit and Wealthy Men; (Railroad Fares)
lead_paragraph: Nothing has done so much to consign the wealthier men in this country to the political isolation of which they complain, as their own want of public spirit. They shrink constantly from the occupation of posts which it is especially their duty to occupy, and which nobody else can occupy, and the result is, naturally enough, that they find themselves unceremoniously thrust aside when more desirable places are put up to competition. The Legislatures of our States and the Common Councils of our large cities ought, for instance, to protect the poor against the unscrupulous exactions of the great corporations. It is their duty under any circumstances, but it is peculiarly their duty, as they are generally composed of men who owe their places to profuse professions of democratic zeal, and of devotion to the rights of the working classes. But as everybody knows, the comfort of the people, and especially of the poor, are not really of the smallest concern to them. The Legislature of this State and the Common Council of this city have shown the strongest disposition, on the contrary, to allow the great corporations to do their worst against the public.
headline: {'main': 'Rich Men and Poor Men.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Rich Men and Poor Men.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A large and enthusiastic meeting was held, last evening, at the great hall of the Cooper Union, under the auspices of the Lincoln and Johnson Campaign Club of this City. The hall was crowded, and among the audience were many ladies.
lead_paragraph: A large and enthusiastic meeting was held, last evening, at the great hall of the Cooper Union, under the auspices of the Lincoln and Johnson Campaign Club of this City. The hall was crowded, and among the audience were many ladies. Much interest was had in the meeting, from the fact that the speakers of the evening were all men who in 1860 were opponents of Mr. LINCOLN, but who now, by the force of events, arrayed themselves in favor of LINCOLN and JOHNSON, and as the representatives of the Union and Liberty.

abstract: on Peace Negotiation; Stephens and Gov Brown on; Views on Peace
snippet: on Peace Negotiation; Stephens and Gov Brown on; Views on Peace
lead_paragraph: We give to-day the text of a letter from the rebel Vice-President STEPHENS, the existence of which was mentioned in a dispatch published yesterday. Mr. STEPHENS is ardently desirous of peace, but he does not see that it is in his power, or in the power of any number of persons in his position, to "inaugurate any movement that will even tend to aid in bringing about this result." He gives his views, however, at length, as to what must be its basis and key-note, and that is, the recognition of the "sovereignty, the ultimate, absolute sovereignty of the States." He regards the action of the Chicago Convention, so far as its platform of principles goes, as presenting a ray of light, and considers a convention of the States, or, in other words, "a peaceful conference and interchange of views between equal and sovereign Powers," as one step in the right direction. The real object of the letter appears toward its close, where he says: "The chief aid and encouragement we can give the peace party at the North, is to keep before them these great fundamental principles and truths."
headline: {'main': "Negotiations with the Rebels The Necessary Preliminary Vice-President Stephens' Letter.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Negotiations with the Rebels The Necessary Preliminary Vice-President Stephens' Letter.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

The object of the procession was partly political and wholly Union, and, therefore, closely connected with the other jubilant manifestations.

lead_paragraph: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE BOGERT CLUB. There was a very pleasant gathering last evening at No. 15 Carroll-place, corner of Bleecker and Thompson streets, on the occasion of the opening of the new rooms of the Bogert Club at "the Wunder." A large number of members were in attendance, and at an early hour Mr. E.R. WUNDER, President of the club, opened the meeting in an agreeable speech, in which he referred to the prosperity of the club, and gave a pleasant account of its history since their last meeting. At the conclusion of the President's remarks Mr. DRUMGOLD nominated Mr. THOMAS SETT for Sergeant-at-Arms. The nomination being seconded, that gentleman was unanimously elected. Mr. WEST, of Tarrytown, gave an interesting account of the adventures of a large number of gentlemen, members of the club, who had recently returned from the "Far West." He stated that the result of their Western tour had been very successful, and that he believed his associates, twelve in number, bore honorable record to the high reputation of the Club in the Piscatorial art. He alluded to the attention the members had received in their travels, and stated that even in the Western wilds the fame of the Club had already preceeded them. Mr. WEST concluded by reading a Report of the traveling adventures of himself and associates during their absence.

abstract: Winsor vs Ship Cornelius Grinnell; Salvage
snippet: Winsor vs Ship Cornelius Grinnell; Salvage
lead_paragraph: Henry Winsor et al. vs. The Ship Corneltus Grinnell. -- This was a libel for salvage filed by the owners of the steamship Saxon. The facts of the case were as follows: The ship had left London bound to New-York on the 23d of March, 1863, with a valuable cargo and a large number of passengers. On the 2d of April she hove to in a severe gale of wind, her master supposing he was off Fire Island. She lay to till next morning at 4 o'clock, when she was run in west-northwest, toward New-York as was supposed, and between 12 and 1 P.M. she made the land, which was thought to be the New-Jersey shore. She was then headed off east-southeast, and in half or three-quarters of an hour, struck in shoal water. She wore ship to the westward and immediately anchored in five and a half fathems of water. She lay there for about an hour, head to the wind, which was blowing fresh from the northeast, accompanied with rain, her officers being ignorant of her real position, when the Saxon, which ran regularly between Philadelphia and Boston was discovered passing on her trip to Boston. Signals of distress were immediately set and the Saxon [???] down, and Capt. Spencer, of the Grinnell, was informed, on his inquiring where he was, that he was on Five Fathom Bank, off Cape May. Capt. Spencer informed the Saxon of the condition of the ship, and asked if the Saxon would take him to a port of safety. Capt. Matthews, of the Saxon, said he would try. The Grinell's cable was slipped, and the Saxon took a hawser from her to take her in tow; but in attempting to get the ship off before the wind, the hawser parted near the Grinnell's knightheads, from inavitable accident, and though the Saxon's engines were stopped as soon as they could be, and every effort was made on the Saxon, it got foul of her screw, and 20 or 30 fathoms of it were found on her screw when she reached Boston. The Saxon then ordered the Grinnell to make sail and follow her, which was done, the two ships steering toward the mouth of Delaware Bay. After going five or six miles the Saxon stopped to let the Grinnell come up, when Capt. Mathews told her he should have to get another hawser to her before night, as it would be ebb-tide before they reached the mouth of the Bay, and he could not get him to a safe anchorage without it. Capt. Spencer then asked if he could not take him to sea. Capt. Mathews said he could; and thereupon the Saxon led the way, and the ship followed out to sea, clear of all the shoals, when the Grinnell hauled up on her course for New-York, and the Saxon went on her way to Boston. The ships had been together about five hours. The Grinnell was found to be in good condition on arriving at New-York. She was valued at $22,500, and her cargo at $100,000. The Saxon was worth over $100,000, and had on board a cargo worth $400,000. She was injured while coming in contact with the Grinnell while taking the hawser, to the amount of $260. White pursuing her voyage to Boston, she arrived at Pollock's Rip about an hour before low water, and in attempting to cross she struck, and was injured to about $2,500. If she had not been detained by the Grinnell, she would doubtless have reached he Rip at high water, and passed it in safety.

abstract: Boston; Brewster, Sweet >amp; Co. of $50000; Arrest of Manning, Wall-street Broker
snippet: Boston; Brewster, Sweet >amp; Co. of $50000; Arrest of Manning, Wall-street Broker
lead_paragraph: The firm of BREWSTER, SWEET Co., well known bankers of Boston, were on the 25th of August last, robbed of $50,000 worth of United States Treasury Notes and Certificates of Stock. The theft took place in broad daylight the thief going into the front room of the banking-house, and taking the packages from the counter. The stolen property consisted of eight $1,000. Treasury notes, dated Oct. 1; four for the same amount, dated Aug. 10; thirty-four $100 notes, dated Aug. 19; twenty-two $50 notes, dated Aug. 10, besides a number of others, the date of which is not known, also a large number of stock certificates. The firm from whom this property was stolen, immediately offered a reward of $4,000 for the recovery of the same. Printed notices, specifying the dates, numbers and amounts of the stolen notes and certificates were at once sent to all the principal cities in the north, and particularly to the City of New-York. The police of this City have, therefore, recently been on the alert in respect to this robbery.

abstract: A Few to the Rank and File of the Union Armies; a Few Plain Words
snippet: A Few to the Rank and File of the Union Armies; a Few Plain Words
lead_paragraph: NAPOLEON wittily warned Governments to "beware when bayonets should learn to think;" but with us, far from being a subject of fear, it is our glory and pride that the war for the Union has been upheld by a million of "thinking bayonets." Despots may tremble when the bayonets that sustain their thrones learn to think; but when free men rise in arms to defend free institutions, what "thinking" can be more true, more wise, more patriotic than theirs?

abstract: New-York World, on; On Long, >amp;c., Left in the Lurch; New-York, on the Peace Faction
snippet: New-York World, on; On Long, >amp;c., Left in the Lurch; New-York, on the Peace Faction
lead_paragraph: The Washington correspondent of the World says: "It is noticed here, as being of peculiar significance, that strongly-pronounced peace men like ALEXANDER LONG, and violent radicals like ASHLEY, have been left in the lurch by the popular vote. It is believed here that Gen. MCCLELLAN's letter of acceptance has hit the happy mean," &c. Now if it be true, as we think it is, that there is a peculiar significance in men like ALEXANDER LONG being "left in the lurch," this is certainly very cold comfort for LONG and VALLANDIGHAM's "valued friend," GEORGE H. PENDLETON, whose turn is to come next. If the people can't tolerate LONG, what is to become of PENDLETON? On what ground is it, we may safely ask, that the opinions of the two do not coincide? To be sure, PENDLETON expressed, at the convention, his regard for the Union, and his desire that it might be restored. But LONG and VALLANDIGHAM "love the Union," and desire its restoration just as much as he. LONG has never said he didn't-think the Union a good thing, or didn't wish it would be preserved. What LONG has said is, that he, for his part, does not think it worth fighting for, or that it is of any use to fight for it; and as it is this that has caused him "to be left in the lurch," we strongly advise him to be of good cheer, for in three or four weeks more he will find himself in respectable company. He will have at least one man in the same predicament with himself, whom we shall not indicate more particularly than to say that his name begins with P. The latter has just one chance of saving himself, though we confess we think it a poor one, and that is, to write a letter, and hit the happy mean, as MCCLELLAN has done. The public are dying to hear from him. We venture to say, that if he were to live a thousand years, he will never again have the same chance of having his opinions listened to as he will if he lets them out any time during the next four weeks, in "a line" to the committee that informed him of his nomination to the Vice-Presidency.

abstract: Mrs. H.W. STINSON, of Old Town, Me., passed through this City on Friday, having in charge the body of her son, who was killed in one of the recent battles in the Shenandoah Valley. This son, who was the only survivor of a family of four boys, enlisted soon after the war broke out, and his mother, who wos a widow, followed him to the front, to nurse the sick and wounded soldiers. She has been in the field for three years, and during that time has spent about $2,500 of her own means in alleviating the sufferings of our soldiers. She says that as soon as she has buried her son she shall return to the army, where she feels that she can find sufficient occupation to take her mind off of her recent bereavement. While in this City, Mrs. STINSON was the guest of Mrs. TUTHILL, of the New-England Soldiers Relief Association, who has also labored faithfully for the soldiers for months past.

abstract: Report on Rebel Treatment of Prisoners
snippet: Report on Rebel Treatment of Prisoners
lead_paragraph: Under the responsible names of Dr. VAL- ENTINE MOTT, Dr. EDWARD DELAFIELD, Hon. J. CLARK HARE, and others of equal professional and social standing, a narrative of the condition of our prisoners, North and South, has been published. It needed such names to make the story credible. The horrors it reveals have no parallel, even in fiction. Upon any less responsible testimony, we should be disposed to reject the whole as the invention of a diseased imagination. Even as it is, we cannot venture to do more than draw attention to the general outlines of the ghastly picture.

abstract: The ocean iron-clad Dictator having been completed at the yard of Messrs. DELAMATER, at the foot of Thirteenth-street, North River, was towed by two tugs to the navy-yard yesterday morning, to be put in commission. She has already got the heavier stores on board, and what may be added in the way of supplies can be done immediately.
lead_paragraph: The ocean iron-clad Dictator having been completed at the yard of Messrs. DELAMATER, at the foot of Thirteenth-street, North River, was towed by two tugs to the navy-yard yesterday morning, to be put in commission. She has already got the heavier stores on board, and what may be added in the way of supplies can be done immediately. The last finishing touch was put upon her by the machinists yesterday morning, and at high water, about 9 A.M., she sailed away under the charge of her engineers and those officers already appointed. The engineer corps is full, and the remaining officers will soon be appointed. The vessel is commanded by Commodore ROGERS, Lieutenant-Commander Bunce, Executive Officer; Surgeon Peck, Acting Master Smith, Chief-Engineer, E.D. Roble; First Assistant, Clement Lindsley; Second Assistants, Theodore Allen, F.B. Allen, _____ Rerick; Third Assistants, S. Sullivan, Wesley Fennemore, C.J. Habbighorst.

abstract: Kept Silent by His Keepers
snippet: Kept Silent by His Keepers
lead_paragraph: -Great efforts have been made to induce PENDLETON to write his letter of acceptance of the Chicago nomination for the Vice-Presidency, and give his views of affairs, in accordance with custom. Great efforts have also been made to induce him not to do this. The upshot of the whole is, that nobody can ascertain his sentiments -- though the fact is that everybody knows what they are. It is desirable, however, that he should embrace the opportunity to make an explicit statement of his attitude at this time in view of his possible attainment of the great position to which he aspires. A new reason for his doing this is found in the Ohio election, and in the popular verdict pronounced in his own State upon his yoke-fellows, Messrs. ALEX. LONG, COX and PUGH.

abstract: Modesty in Arm; Addresses
snippet: Modesty in Arm; Addresses
lead_paragraph: MCCLELLAN's crowning grace, they say, is an excellent touch of modesty. Quite likely it is so. But, like the ladies with their modesty-piece told of in the Spectator, he don't manage it well. Less of it in his political life, and more in his military, would be better. It is not meet that he should be all humbleness before the politicians, and all assumption before the soldiers -- that he should treat himself as nobody before the one and everybody before the other.

abstract: Judge HOLT has published in the Washington Chronicle a report, eight columns in length, in relation to the secret associations and conspiracy against the Government in the Western and Northwestern States. The actual number of persons in these secret lodges he supposes is 500,000, which is the number VALLANDIGHAM stated it to be.
lead_paragraph: Judge HOLT has published in the Washington Chronicle a report, eight columns in length, in relation to the secret associations and conspiracy against the Government in the Western and Northwestern States. The actual number of persons in these secret lodges he supposes is 500,000, which is the number VALLANDIGHAM stated it to be. It is an armed force, the arms being purchased in Eastern markets, and consisting of revolvers and carbines. One of the principles of the Order is that Federal authority cannot coerce a sovereign State, the Federal power being without sovereignty itself. Another is that when the Government is administered contrary to the strict letter of the Constitution it is the inherent right and imperative duty of the people to resist the authorities and compel them by force of arms to act constitutionally. The specific purpose of the Order at present is to encourage desertion, to resist the draft, to circulate disloyal documents, to give intelligence to the enemy, aid him by recruiting for his army, and furnishing him with arms and ammunition, and aiding in destroying Government and private property, and the establishment of a Northwestern Confederacy in alliance with the South. Judge HOLT professes to have abundant and reliable testimony establishing these facts.

abstract: This talented and gallant officer died on Wednesday last, from the effects of a wound received a short time since from a guerrilla in the Shenandoah Valley. Col. TOLLES was for many years connected with the press, and at the outbreak of the rebellion was editor of the Newark, N.J., Daily Advertiser. He was a brilliant writer, and contributed valuable papers to the Atlantic, Continental and other monthlies. His able series of articles in the Continental on organization of the army, is deserving of being collected and given to the public in book form. At the beginning of the war he joined the Staff of Gen. RUNYON, and at the time of his death held the position of Chief Quartermaster in the Sixth Army Corps with Gen. SHERIDAN. He leaves a wife, the daughter of Prof. MAPES, of Newark.

abstract: and Rebel Newspapers on "Cavalry to the Rear"
snippet: and Rebel Newspapers on "Cavalry to the Rear"
lead_paragraph: -- We suspect there is more in that long, narrow, compact, Julius-Caesar head of Gen. SHERMAN than is commonly imagined. We suspect he edits half of the newspapers in the Southern Confederacy. There are very many reasons for thinking so, but our latest reason is this. It will he remembered that while SHERMAN was laying slege to Atlanta, a couple of months ago, an apparently shrewd suggestion was made by a rebel newspaper, that the Confederate cavalry should be sent north of Atlanta and into Tennessee to operate on SHERMAN's rear. The suggestion was quickly taken up by rebel journals all over the Southern Confederacy. They demanded this action -- demanded it loudly. They roared and shrieked for it, and ever louder grew the roar and shriller the shriek. The cry of "Cavalry to the rear!" resounded through the length and breadth of the South in general chorus, till finally the tympanum of JEFF. DAVIS' ear was cracked, and his soul distracted, by the noise of the general uproar; and he ordered the cavalry of HOOD's army to hasten to the rear and to Tennessee. Now, of all things, this was precisely the one thing that was necessary for the success of Gen. SHERMAN, and the thing that actually secured for him the victory at Atlanta. In SHERMAN's order to his army upon its triumphant entry into Atlanta, he says, after recounting the various obstacles and embarrassments that had stood in the way of success: "At last, the enemy made the mistake we had waited for so long, and sent his cavalry to our rear, far beyond the reach of recall." And again, in his report of his entire campaign which we gave in the TIMES last week, he alludes to the same blunder of the enemy in sending their mounted forces northward, and says: "I could not have ask ed anything better. . . . I renewed my orders for the movement of the whole army."
headline: {'main': 'DOES GEN. SHERMAN EDIT THE REBEL NEWSPAPERS?; PAPERS?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'DOES GEN. SHERMAN EDIT THE REBEL NEWSPAPERS?; PAPERS?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Government of Peru has dispatched a circular to its diplomatic agents in Europe and the United States, in relation to the Spanish question. This circular has not yet been made public, but it is known that the Government declares it will use, as noon as possible, all the means at its disposal to recover the Chincha Islands; but will not open or initiate any negotiations with Spain to this end.
lead_paragraph: The Government of Peru has dispatched a circular to its diplomatic agents in Europe and the United States, in relation to the Spanish question. This circular has not yet been made public, but it is known that the Government declares it will use, as noon as possible, all the means at its disposal to recover the Chincha Islands; but will not open or initiate any negotiations with Spain to this end. Peru will, however, enter into negotiations on this subject if initiated by Spain. "This is the last word of Peru on the subject. She will not cede a single inch. or make the slightest concession, cost what it may. If, on her part, Spain persists in her pretensions -- if she is determined to exact satisfaction by force for imaginary wrongs, war is inevitable -- and although it may be bloody and doubtful, Peru and America will sustain and prosecute it with the same valor and decision they did the war for independence."

abstract: The second week of Mr. MARETZEK's season ended brilliantly on Saturday with a matinee, when "La Traviata" was given for the second, and we hope, last time -- for the present, at least. The performance was a good one, and Signora BRAMBILLA sang decidedly better than she did on the night of her debut. But were these circumstances cannot reconcile us to a work that has been so often played. For the moment we have had enough of the "Lost One." She has been found too often; let her now be abandoned.

abstract: Only Rebel Port Left
snippet: Only Rebel Port Left
lead_paragraph: Of all the points on the Southern coast line which were formorly used by the rebels as ports of entry for their blockade-runners, there is but one of any consequence now left them -- that is Wilmington. Some of the ports themselves -- such as Charleston, Savannah and Mobile -- we do not hold; but we command their entrances by the possession of the works controlling those entrances. The rebels understand that it is now in the order of things that Wilmington should be reduced -- or, at all events, that we should gel control of its outworks, so as to seal it up effectually; and, accordingly, half a dozen of their organs are loudly warning the Confederate Government and the rebel military authorities at Wilmington to prepare for attack by a grand naval force, which, they say, is being gotten ready near Fortress Monroe. The Richmond Sentinel, the Whig, the Christian Sun, the Charleston Mercury, the Augusta Constitutionalist, and other papers, contain news and notes of warning on the subject, and, of course, they show the utter impossibility, of our obtaining any success at Wilmington. The Augusta Constitutionalist, after announcing that the Yankees are now bent upon the destruction of Wilmington, congratulates the rebels that "this point bids fair to put a period to the audacious luck of FARRAGUT." It is stated that no more tremendous earthworks exist on this continent than those that bulwark the inlets of Cape Fear. Nature, besides, has done much for its protection. The bars are shallow, the channels narrow and immediately under rebel guns. By the most skillful navigation alone can the breakers be avoided, the slightest variation precipitating vessels upon their remorseless fangs. In addition, every precaution has been taken to counteract an investment by land.

abstract: The various City Railroad Companies have adopted a resolution that on and after the 20th inst. they will sell at their various offices tickets at the old rates of fare, with the addition of the Government Internal Revenue Tax of 2 1/2, per cent.; it being understood that all passengers who fail to supply themselves with tickets in advance will be required, as now, to pay the addition of one cent to the old rates of fare. It is asserted that the present rates of compensation are inadequate on many, if not all the roads, the cost of carrying such passengers having been, on an average, three and three-fourths of a cent while gold was at par, which makes it clear that money must now be lost on the roads when gold is oscillating between 120 and 180 premium. Hereafter passengers can purchase 8 tickets for 41 cents. to tickets for 82 cents, and 100 tickets for $5 12 1/2. The tickets sold by any one city railroad company will be good and receivable on all the roads on Manhattan Island.

abstract: Democratic Candidates and their Characters
snippet: Democratic Candidates and their Characters
lead_paragraph: The decision of the late Democratic State Convention in favor of the "regularity" of Tammany Hall, has proved wholly unproductive of the "harmonizing effects" that were expected and predicted as sure to follow. The "Young Coons," under Senator COZANS, and the "Old Coons" under FERNANDO WOOD, are still upon the war-path. The "Nationals," under JOHN MCKEON, still brandish their tomahawks; while the "German Democrats," under the accomplished editor of the Staats Zeitung, drink "confusion to Tammany Hall" in multitudinous lagers. The settlement at Albany has settled nothing, except the incompetency of our State politicians to deal with local irritations; and we have to-day every prospect of an embittered controversy in the Democratic ranks for the offices to be disposed of next November.

abstract: The steamship Yazoo, from New Orleans, Oct. 6, and the Creole, same port Oct. 9, arrived at this port yesterday. They bring news of several successful expeditions in the Department of the Gulf. Gen. ASBOTH had advanced to Marianna, Western Florida, and captured quite a number of prisoners, including one Brigadier-General and one Colonel. Gen. ASBOTH himself was slightly wounded.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Yazoo, from New Orleans, Oct. 6, and the Creole, same port Oct. 9, arrived at this port yesterday. They bring news of several successful expeditions in the Department of the Gulf. Gen. ASBOTH had advanced to Marianna, Western Florida, and captured quite a number of prisoners, including one Brigadier-General and one Colonel. Gen. ASBOTH himself was slightly wounded. An expedition sent by Gen. DANA, from Rodney, Miss., of colored troops, reached Fayette on the 2d inst., capturing 600 cattle, a large number of horses and mules, and several prisoners. Another expedition, sent out by Gen. DANA, attacked the rebels at Woodville, on the 6th inst, capturing three guns, two officers and fifty-four men, and killing forty. Our loss none. The cavalry expedition under Gen. LEE captured Clinton, La.. on the 6th, with thirty prisoners, including Lieut.-Col. PINCKNEY, rebel Provost-Marshal-General of the district, and considerable stores and ammunition. At last accounts, LEE was ten miles east of Clinton, moving on. The now Legislature of Louisiana had convened and organized. Gov. HAHN delivered his message on the 6th inst.

abstract: On the third the money market manifested decided improvement, Gold continued to flour lergely into the Bank of England, inducing the belief that the financial pressure was over.
lead_paragraph: On the third the money market manifested decided improvement. Gold continued to flour largely into the Bank of England, inducing the belief that the financial pressure was over. The demand for discount at the Bank was of the full average character. On the Stock Exchange short loans were offered at 6@7 per cent. Nearly all classes of securities advanced. Consols closed firm at the advance -- 88 1/2@58 5/3 for money, and 88 2/4@88 7/8 on account. The Confederate Loan advanced 1c., and is now quoted at 66c.

abstract: Secretary of War Buying Greenbacks
snippet: Secretary of War Buying Greenbacks
lead_paragraph: By an act of the rebel Congress, it seems DAVIS' Secretary of War is allowed to purchase United States currency. It is a penal offence, at the same time, however, to be found selling greenbacks within the Confederacy. The question, then, naturally arises -- where does the rebel Secretary of War go to market when he makes his little investments? Does he draw on Chicago, or on Canada?

abstract: Camp's Testimony on Returning Loyalty
snippet: Camp's Testimony on Returning Loyalty
lead_paragraph: There is a daily, accumulation of evidence of the distemper which has fastened itself upon Georgia in her relationship toward the Confederacy. The latest witness is the Clerk of the Georgia House of Representatives, Mr. CAMP, who has arrived at Nashville. We are the more disposed to place reliance upon his testimony, that he presents no extraordinary picture of returning loyalty among the people, or of an instant dissolution of the remnant of the Confederate force under HOOD. While the discontent of the people with DAVIS' rule is all but universal; while the Richmond despotism is execrated on all hands, there is no hope for the people of the State finding a way of release from their bondage until HOOD's army is completely and finally destroyed. That army, is still strong enough "to intimidate unarmed people, especially as the male portion of these people consists only of decrepit old men and boys." On all hands, throughout Georgia, it is admitted that "if MCCLELLAN is beaten, there is not sufficient vitality in the Confederacy to keep it alive." There is, in short, in the whole of Mr. CAMP's story a complete correspondence with the evidence on the same point, supplied in Gov. BROWN's order withdrawing his militia, in DAVIS' Macon speech, in HOOD's tribute to the deserters, thieves and plunderers in his army, and in the general tone and bearing of public opinion within the State since the fall of Atlanta.

abstract: Persistent and continuous picket firing has been kept up all yesterday and last night, accompanied by considerable cannonading, along the line of the Second Corps, in front of Petersburgh. The firing has been almost entirely in the vicinity of "Fort Hell," near Gen. HANOOCK'S headquarters. Nothing of great moment or importance has resulted from it, however. The batteries and pickets in front of the Fifth and Ninth Corps have been unusually silent.

abstract: We have again some items from Bagdad and Matamoras on the Rio Grande by way of New Orleans, the credibility of which it would be most unsafe to vouch for. The reporter who brings the news avers, that on the 21st ult., five hundred French marines were still intrenched at Bagdad; that an expedition had gone up the river in French ships to attack Matamoras, but was compelled to return on account of the lowness of the water, after reaching a point within twenty miles of the city. The expedition was not driven back, as had been previously alleged, by a Mexican force, or any other force under Gen. CORTENAJ. The latter, it is said, has his guns brought to bear upon Brownsville, in case of an unexpected assault on his position by the Confederate Texans.

abstract: A railroad accident, with fearful results, occurred on the Shore Line Railroad, Connecticut, last Saturday. The train consisted of six passenger cars, containing, two hundred and seventy-five sick and wounded soldiers, who were being transferred, from the United States "Knight" Hospital, in New-Haven to Reedville, Mass. When about four miles east of the Connecticut River, and while passing through a deep rock cut, known as "Rocky Lodge," a broken rail threw the entire train from the track, and dashed the cars into the solid ledge on either side. Nine of the soldiers were instantly killed, and fifteen or twenty others severely injured.
lead_paragraph: A railroad accident, with fearful results, occurred on the Shore Line Railroad, Connecticut, last Saturday. abstract: Progress of
snippet: Progress of
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent at Quebec, who has had special opportunity for studying the political situation in the Provinces, takes a less sanguine view of the progress of the federative scheme than the more ardent local sympathizers. The Conference has been a week in session. It has resolved by a formal vote, as everyone believed it would, that an union of the Provinces is desirable. Beyond this -- nothing. The difficulties in the way of an agreement upon details, as we have always pointed out, are now found to be of the gravest kind. The Conference has sat thus far, and will continue to sit, with closed doors. But enough has already transpired to show that on the primary question of representation alone the barriers in the way of political communion between the Provinces, and the more advanced Western Province are all but insuperable.

abstract: THE CITY RAILROADS. -- The City Railroad Companies, on the 20th, will issue tickets, selling one hundred for $513, the cents being the revenue tax. Those who do not purchase them will have to pay the six cents. Superintendent KENNEDY has issued instructions to policemen as follows: "When persons refuse to pay the price of passage demanded by the railroad companies, and the conductors require assistance to eject parties from their cars, it cannot be refused. The companies have the government of their own cars until the courts take it from them."

abstract: Petroleum is subjected to a loss of millions of dollars annually, in consequence of its evaporation and leaking through the best made barrels. LOUIS S. ROBBINS, an ingenious chemist of this city, has discovered a method by which, at trifling cost, all ordinary oil barrels may be made absolutely and permanently tight, so that most subtle fluids, such as petroleum, naptha and benzine, cannot permeate through them. His process treats not only the surfaces of the barrel, but the whole interior texture of the wood.

abstract: An expedition into West Florida, under command of Brigadier General ASBOTH, reached Mariana on the afternoon of the 27th of September, capturing that place after a stubborn resistance of several hours. The resuit is the capture of eighty-one prisoners of war, amongst them a Brigadier General and a Colonel, ninety-five stand of arms, large quantities of quartermaster's and commissary stores, over two hundred fine horses and mules, and four hundrod head of cattle.
lead_paragraph: An expedition into West Florida, under command of Brigadier General ASBOTH, reached Mariana on the afternoon of the 27th of September, capturing that place after a stubborn resistance of several hours. The resuit is the capture of eighty-one prisoners of war, amongst them a Brigadier General and a Colonel, ninety-five stand of arms, large quantities of quartermaster's and commissary stores, over two hundred fine horses and mules, and four hundrod head of cattle. Our loss in killed and wounded amounts to thirty-two; of the former Captain M.M. YOUNG, Seventh Vermont, and Lieutenant E.W. AYER, Second Maine Cavalry; of the latter General ASBETH himself, who had his le[???] cheek bone broken and his left arm fractured in two places.

abstract: -- AUSTIN JOSEPH HAND, a ship-caulker, and his wife, now residing at No. 4 Navy-street, Brooklyn, went to England in 1862, on a visit to a brother-in-law, who was then in the employment of Mr. LAIRD, shipbuilder, Liverpool. He procured work for him in the same building yard. HAND was employed there until August, 1863, when he gave information to an American Consul as to the destination of the two ram-ships building by Mr. LAIRD. He supplied information by special request, from time to time, as to the progress of the two vessels, and the names of the Southern parties visiting the yard. It was upon the information given by HAND that the rams were ultimately stopped. The report that HAND had given such information got into the Liverpool newspapers, when he and his brother-in-law were at once dismissed from Mr. LAIRD's employment. No employment could be obtained in Liverpool in consequence of being discharged by Mr. LAIRD. Not being able to get work in Liverpool, he procured passage to New-York, where he arrived on the 28th of July last. HAND has not been able to got steady employment, and is presently in great distress. He is promised work at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, but as yet remains idle. He has a wife and four children depending on him. For the services rendered by HAND (who is an American) to the mercantile community, especially that of New-York, his case demands immediate attention, as one well worthy of their liberality.

abstract: Copperheads Applaud his Letter; Charlatanry; Salute on Pennsylvania Election
snippet: Copperheads Applaud his Letter; Charlatanry; Salute on Pennsylvania Election
lead_paragraph: The Mandarin prisoner, in his cabin, who pretended that he had not heard the royal salute just fired from the 64-pounders above him, had a very cool way of showing his contempt for the outside barbarians. But our Copperheads, in themselves firing a salute, as they did last evening, over their victory in Pennsylvania, evinced a cool contempt for the people that makes the coolness of the Chinaman quite tropical in comparison. Pennsylvania has given a positive popular majority for the Union candidates on the home vote, which will be increased by the returns from the army to at least fifteen thousand, and probably eighteen thousand majority; and has elected seventeen, and perhaps eighteen, members of Congress, out of twenty-four. The Copperheads have not the grace simply to affect an unconsciousness of all this, but must claim it as a victory for themselves, fit to be celebrated with salutes and illuminations. There is something so exquisitely grotesque in this extravagance, that it is impossible to resent it.

abstract: As it Was, and Chicago Platform Charlatanry
snippet: As it Was, and Chicago Platform Charlatanry
lead_paragraph: There is no end to Copperhead charlatanry. Look at the front of Tammany Hall, or at almost any of the Copperhead banners swung over the street, and you see beneath the Janus-faced portraits of MCCLELLAN and PENDLETON, the inscription -- "The Union as it was, and the Constitution as it is." This party device is given to the winds in the very face of the Chicago Platform, the most prominent feature of which is "an ultimate convention" for the amendment of the Constitution and reconstruction of the Union. It would seem as if these Copperhead managers take the American people to be idiots, without sense enough to heed these shuffling tricks.
headline: {'main': '"The Union as it Was, and the Constitution as it is."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': '"The Union as it Was, and the Constitution as it is."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: MUSICAL AND DRAMATIC. The most agreeable opera of the sesson, and the freshest, was given on Wednesday evening. VERDI'S "Balio in Maschera "still ranks as a novelty. It is the latest important work that has issued from the composer's pen, with the exception of "La Forza del Destino."
lead_paragraph: MUSICAL AND DRAMATIC. -- The most agreeable opera of the sesson, and the freshest, was given on Wednesday evening. VERDI's "Balio in Maschera "still ranks as a novelty. It is the latest important work that has issued from the composer's pen, with the exception of "La Forza del Destino." The melodies are piquante, the musical combinations and finales ingenious and effective, whilst the instrumentation is extremely interesting. When Mr. MARETZEK first introduced the "Ballo" to the attention of the public it was with a vocal combination that demanded instant recognition. The various roles were rendered with great spirit, but the work as a whole was not so well rendered as on Wednesday night. We can say so without any hesitation and despite the fact that the contralto -- being a deputante -- was in a nervous plight, and that in several portions of the opera it became apparent that the tenor had but a slight and timid acquaintance with the music. It is due to Signor MASSIMILIAM to say that he undertook the part of Richard for the first time, and that if he seldom did injustice to the composer. His study of the part will, we are persuaded, prove amply sufficient on the next representation. The contralto to whom we have referred is Mlle. FRIDA de GEBELE, a young lady of decided promise, with a ponderous voice and an insufficient command of it. The role of Ulrica does not present any unusual satlencies, and the lady could do no more than display her voice, and ask an obvious tremulousness a kindly consideration for her inexperience. The opera, we need scarcely say, does not depend on any one artist. The ensembles are its chief attractions, and after these the interest centres principally on the soprano and the baritone -- both of whom were simply superb. The third act was given with a clearness which we have never heard equalled at the Academy, and only on rare occasions elsewhere. The fourth act was hardly less admirable, but the brilliancy of the ball room scene was marred by the paltriness of the dominoes which smothered the guests. Mr. MARETZEK is paying so much attention to the matter of costume, that it is a pity his laudable object should be frustrated by the dingey calico remains of past seasons. We lack space to enlarge further on the merits of the "Ballo." The opera will be repeated to-morrow night, and we recommend, it unhesitatingly to the attention of the public.

abstract: By the arrival yesterday of the City of Washington at this port, and of the Damascus at Father Point, we have advices from Europe to the 7th inst. The political news by these arrivals is unimportant. Miss SLIDELL and M. ERLANGER were married at Paris with much pomp. MACE, the prize fighter, charges COBURN with never intending to fight, and claims the stakes. The London papers are occupied with speculations on the Presidential contest in this country, and they concede that Mr. LINCOLN's election is certain. A peace address, very numerously signed, has been transmitted from England to Gov. SEYMOUR.

abstract: Admiral PORTER, commanding the North Atlantic Blockading Sqnadron, communicates to the Navy Department information of the capture of the English blockade-runner Bat, by the United States steamer Montgomery, on the 10th inst. The Bat is steel built. This was her trip, she having been only 19 days at sea. The vessel runs 14 knots, is very strong, and can be used to catch blockade-runners, she was consigned to FRASER, TRENHOLM  Co.

abstract: -- The disgraceful delight of the Copperheads in the occasional misfortunes of the Union arms, is exhibited in the tone of their organs daily; and the disgraceful facility which they have in inventing news of bad fortune and disaster when there is none, is also constantly seen. Two of the Copperhead city papers of yesterday pretended to give categorical statements of decent military occurrences and of the present military situation. These two rigmaroles resolve themselves into very small matter, though they are made up of such gigantic statements as these: That the "rebels" (how large an army of rebels?) "are operating in Maryland, almost under the eyes of Mr. LINCOLN himself;" that there are rebels roaming in Missouri; that "Western Kentucky is "threatened" by rebels; that a small body of our troops assailed a rebel position on the north bank of the James on Thursday last, but did not capture Richmond, nor destroy LEE's army, nor break the Confederate backbone; that the rebels are in SHERMAN's rear, and in the rear of SHERMAN, and on the railroad north of Atlanta, which was lately captured by Gen. SHERMAN, and that the rebels under HOOD were in SHERMAN's rear. They enlarge upon these statements, and repeat them again and again, and return to them like a dog unto his vomit. A score of hungry Shenandoah guerrillas make a twopenny raid into Maryland to get something to eat, and the Copperhead papers magnify it into a formidable invasion of the North, while they say not a word about the recent rout of EARLY's army in the Shenandoah by SHERIDAN. They have no jubilations over the fall of Atlanta; but make a tremendous fuss about the crazy and desperate movement of HOOD, which we have no doubt is the prelude of his destruction. The smallest repulse to our army before Richmond they dilate upon and magnify into a fearful disaster, involving general ruin and showing the hopelessness of conquering the rebellion, while the half-dozen terrible repulses that LEE's army has had within the last few weeks, they say as little about as possible, and that as of no consequence.

They have no jubilations over the fall of Atlanta; but make a tremendous fuss about the crazy and desperate movement of HOOD, which we have no doubt is the prelude of his destruction. abstract: Late on Sunday night, as officer JOHN H. ALLCOT, of the Police, in company with Mr. JOHN M. ARTER, was passing the corner of Houston and Greene streets, he was suddenly knocked down by one of a gang of eight or ten rowdies. While lying helpless on the pavement, he was brutally kicked and beaten by several of these desperate men, robbed of his gold watch and chain, a diamond pin and other valuables, valued in all at five hundred dollars. Not content with this, one of them named WM.J. HENNESSEN, drew a revolver and fired three shots at the officer. One of the balls took effect on his nose, inflicting a flesh wound. Mr. ARTER was also robbed of a gold chain. The theives then left, taking with them both the hats of their victims. HENNESSEN, who is said to be the ringleader, and two others named EDWARD BURNS and TERRENC[???] [???], were soon after arrested at the house No. 141 Greene-street. They were yesterday committed in default of $3,000 bail each. None of the stolen property, except the hats, has been recovered.

abstract: DWELLINGS FOR THE INDUSTRIAL CLASSES. -- Attention of capitalists is being promisingly directed to the matter or improved dwellings for the industrial classes. The Citizens' Association have facts and figures to show that dwellings giving more room, free ventilation, and all necessary conveniences, may be established at a cost for rent not beyond the means of working men. Models have been obtained from England of buildings of the description which have lately been erected in London, and which are complete in their arrangements for family use. It is proposed to have these plans laid before the public, and it is believed that capitalists in this city will see that they can with perfect safety invest money in such erections, and at the same time accomplish a most benevolent and praiseworthy work. One of the kings of France made his name glorious by wishing that every peasant in the kingdom might have a chicken in his Sunday dinner-pot. A nobler wish it would be, that every honest, industrious citizen in New-York may have a decent, clean and orderly home for his wife and little ones.
lead_paragraph: DWELLINGS FOR THE INDUSTRIAL CLASSES. -- Attention of capitalists is being promisingly directed to the matter or improved dwellings for the industrial classes.
