abstract: All the loyal men of the country owe a dept of gratitude to Gov. MORTON for the magnificent victory in Indiana, which he has been so largely instrumental in giving them. His oratorical labors have been grandly faithful and effective. The splendid canvass he has made is a fitting climax to an administration distinguished above that of all other Governors for its success as well as for its arduousness.
lead_paragraph: All the loyal men of the country owe a dept of gratitude to Gov. MORTON for the magnificent victory in Indiana, which he has been so largely instrumental in giving them. His oratorical labors have been grandly faithful and effective. The splendid canvass he has made is a fitting climax to an administration distinguished above that of all other Governors for its success as well as for its arduousness. With a Legislature against him of the most factious and disloyal character, which did its utmost to bind his hands, with a most formidable organization of traitors in his midst, all the while plotting insurrection, with a party opposition of unequaled virulence, he has yet kept Indiana the very foremost of all the Western States -- we may in truth say of all the States -- in filling its quotas and meeting every call of the Government. His peculiar success has been owing to great executive abilities, combined with a public devotion, which not only nerved him to tireless endeavor, but which elevated him above all personal jealousies and challenged universal respect. An absolute singleness of loyal purpose has characterized him from the beginning. The people of Indiana have marked it well. It not only gives weight to every act in his executive chamber, but to every word on the stump. And the result has been an election triumph so signal as quite to take the country by surprise. All honor, we say, to Gov. MORTON, the completest contrast to Gov. SEYMOUR in the times that tried men's souls.

abstract: --All the Copperhead journals of the city applaud this production, and hail it as it peaceful gleam. They find no fault with his construction of the Chicago platform -- that the "ultimate convention" is intended to be a convention in which the States are to meet in their "ultimate absolute sovereignty," without reference to any constitutional obligations under the old Union. Their acquiescence in this construction is, as the Journal of Commerce says of the letter itself, "guarded, but full of meaning." The distance between the cessationists and the Secessionists is every day growing less, They will, in due time, meet on common disunion ground, and make a combined movement for a convention that shall treat the old Union as dead, and create a new Confederacy on the ruins of the Montgomery Constitution. Thank Heaven there is a Union party which will surely shiver all such atrocious schemes.

lead_paragraph: The rebels under HOOD, who had occupied Dalton, hastily left the place on the 15th, and moved off with his whole army in the direction of Bridgeport. Gen. SHERMAN was only nine miles from Dalton on Saturday at noon, and had commenced moving in the same direction of HOOD, and was closely pressing the latter's rear. No apprehensions are now felt for Atlanta, Chattanooga or Knoxville. Gen. SHERMAN has over one hundred days rations at Atlanta. Knoxville has an abundance of provisions to stand a six months' siege. At Chattanooga the Government store-houses are full of provisions, and large supplies besides are on the ground, covered with tarpaulins. Communication with Gen. SHERMAN is again open.

abstract: British Appeal for Peace sent to; Appeal for Peace Sent to Gov Seymour
snippet: British Appeal for Peace sent to; Appeal for Peace Sent to Gov Seymour
lead_paragraph: Governor SEYMOUR is made the recipient of a memorial, published in part by us yesterday, from some three hundred Englishmen and Irishmen, pronouncing our war against the Southern States a wrong, a failure, and a ruin to our republican institutions, and asking its immediate discontinuance. This memorial is headed, and was circulated by HENRY DE HOUGHTON BARONET. That is appropriate enough, for it speaks for British class interests. It is committed to HORATIO SEYMOUR. That too, is appropriate enough, for it speaks to American faction and sedition. But though the authorship and the trusteeship are apt, the memorial itself is not so. It is a piece of superlative impertinence.

abstract: Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday sold at auction, at the City Hall, the use of five different piers on the North River, each for a period of ten years from the 1st of November ensuing. Four of the piers were rented out on leases, extending to next May, but the lessees relinquished their claims, to have an opportunity of bidding anew for the leases at the long term of years. The result will be highly favorable to the city, as the new prices are largely in excess of the old rates, and, instead of the city guaranteeing repairs, as heretofore, the lessees are to attend to them at their own expense, and also the dredging. This arrangement is an entirely new feature in such leases.

abstract: An official explanation of the case of the Roya1 Sovereign has been offered, from which it appears that the Admiralty consider this cupola ship to be fit only for harbor defence. She is not a sea-going ship at all, and the officials say they have tried her as much as they need to do; although naval men condemn the withdrawal of the ship from public service as an unwarrantable proceeding.

abstract: -- On Sunday, in the chapel of the convent of the Sacred Heart, in Seventeenth-street, two ladies, relatives of Ex-Judge WHITE, made their final vows, which renders them members of this order for life. Archbishop MCCLOBKEY performed the solemn and interesting ceremony, which was witnessed by a large assemblage of ladies and gentlemen. Present were Gen. Banks, Gov. Morgan, Gen. Doubleday, Judges Robertson, Barbour, Moncrief and Monell, Chas. O'Conor, David Dudley Field, Jas. E. Nicholson, R.D. Hatch, Jno. E. White, Esq., and others. Upon the vows being taken, the Archbishop made a touching and appropriate address, and bestowed upon them the cross and ring, only given after a member has been in Union with the society for eight or ten years. After the Mass the congregation repaired to the refectory, where they found spread for their approval a most bountiful breakfast.

abstract: The news from Gen. SHARMAN'S Department continues encouraging. HOOD'S raid on our communications, so far as any military results are concerned, has proved a gigantic failure, and the miserable rebel has dragged his army into a mesh out of which he will probably only get by the loss of half of his force.
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. SHARMAN's Department continues encouraging. HOOD's raid on our communications, so far as any military results are concerned, has proved a gigantic failure, and the miserable rebel has dragged his army into a mesh out of which he will probably only get by the loss of half of his force. On Monday morning at daylight, HOOD's force left Lafayette, Ga., in great haste, moving south toward the Coosa River, with SHERMAN on his flank, holding the gaps in Taylor's Ridge. This country is very bad for an inferior army hotly pursued, being full of ridges, hills and small valleys. If HOOD gets away, it will be by the vigorous use of his legs. He has declined battle whenever offered, and will not fight unless forced to do so. Gen. SLOCUM occupies Atlanta, with plenty of forage and provisions. HOOD demanded, over his own signature, the surrender of Resaca and Dalton, and said that if surrendered, the white officers would be paroled in a few days, but that if the post was carried by assault, "no prisoners would be taken." Dalton was surrendered, but Resaca was not. Rome is all right.

abstract: Prof D H Appeal to Men Inclined to be Neutral
snippet: Prof D H Appeal to Men Inclined to be Neutral
lead_paragraph: Hon. HENRY J. RAYMOND -- Dear Sir: In riding down in a Broadway omnibus, yesterday, I found myself vis-a-vis to one of your most wealthy citizens, well known for the elegance of his tastes, his courteous bearing, sumptuous style of living, and his intelligence in public matters, both at home and abroad. In the course of a short and often interrupted conversation, he said to me that Mr. LINCOLN and Gen. MCCLELLAN being equally indifferent to him, from an equal want of confidence, on his part, in their fitness for the Presidency, he should abstain from voting; and that he knew many persons of his way of thinking, who would do the same.

abstract: The performance of VERDI's "Ballo in Maschera," last night, fulfilled all the pleasant expectations that were excited by the first, and somewhat hasty, though agreeable, representation. Signor MASSIMILIANI was in capital voice. Signor ZUCCHI never sang better. Signora BRAMBILLA was a dainty page -- as neat and tempting as an Aldine edition. Signor BELLINI was admirable. Indeed, we have nothing but praise to bestow. The performance was in every way creditable to Mr. MARETZEK and his company, and will, we trust, be repeated.

abstract: Disunion Speech at Democratic Union Association; Speech at Manhattan Club, New-York; the Union Resolutions of
snippet: Disunion Speech at Democratic Union Association; Speech at Manhattan Club, New-York; the Union Resolutions of
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan Union Club, advocating the election of LINCOLN and JOHNSON, held their second regular meeting last evening in Clinton Hall. The attendance was large, and the proceedings throughout were of the most enthusastic character. The meeting was called to order by the President, Mr. GEORGE W. VAN SICLEN, who, in a few remarks, pledged the club to the cause of the whole Union. After some excellent music by the Glee Club, Mr. A.J. DITTENHOEFER was introduced as the first speaker.

abstract: The Freeman's Journal gives the following account of the measures adopted by the Irish authorities to prevent the threatened combat between MACE and COBURN: "Notwithstanding the result of the meeting for the appointment of the referee, the general belief on Tuesday was that the fight would take place. Mr. E. JAMES and others interested in the pugilistic encounter took their places in the mail train on Monday evening, the 3d, and a large number of detectives were hovering about the platform and book-office. The lovers of 'the manly sport of self-defence' took tickets for various stations beyond Goold's Cross, at which they were to stop, for the purpose of baffling the constabulary, who were to be seen in all kinds of strange costumes, and keeping a sharp look-out. Every male passenger was closely scrutinised for the object of coming at either of the champions, and questions were asked in the most insinuating manner with a view of finding out the place where COBURN had taken up his headquarters. As the train stopped at the several stations bodies of constabulary were to be seen drawn up on every platform, and crowds of country people all most eager to get a view of the pugilists whom they believed were in the train. Those who knew the real state of affairs were perfectly aware that the contest, of which so much had been written and spoken, would not come off, and that Mr. JAMES was only going down for the purpose of keeping an appointment with COBURN, who had pitched his ground in a farmhouse not many hundred yards from Goold's Cross Station, to tell him of the result of the meeting to appoint a referee, and to make arrangements for his appearing on the battle-ground between 12 and 2 o'clock, on the following day, in accordance with the stipulations contained in the articles. At Sallins, Newbridge, Kildare, and all the stations down to the Limerick Junction, the constabulary showed in great force, and, nothwithstanding the fact that the night was bitterly cold, with a sharp, freezing breeze from the eastward, crowds were congregated at all the places where the train stopped. It was clear from the concentration of a large force of constabulary at Goold's Cross Station, that the people in authority were well aware that that was the place selected by COBURN's friends for those concerned in the fight, to take their departure for "the trysting place." The ground selected was within a short distance of the "Rock of Cashel," a secluded place. On the arrival of the train at Goold's Cross Station there was no one to be found who could give any information about COBURN, and the absence of any of the reporters from the London sporting journals clearly proved that there was not the slightest chance of the fight taking place. One Hundred of the constabulary were drawn up under arms round the station, and after the Sergeants had taken stock of the passengers who had left the train, they retired to take shelter behind the nearest wall from the bitter wind that was blowing. Those who had come down to see the fight, and who  had not abandoned the hope that the "mill" would come off, pushed on for Cashel on outside cars in the piercing cold, and on arriving at the "City of the Kings," they found that every bed in the hotels had been engaged, principally by the friends and backers of COBURN, several of whom had come over from Liverpool. It was positively stated that COBURN was in the neighborhood, but, strange to say, his own agent did not know where to find him or CUSICK, his trainer and backer. On Tuesday morning, COBURN's friends and several members of the Dublin press, proceeded from Cashel to Goold's Cross, a distance of five miles. The constabulary were even more numerous than on the day previous, and the men looked rather exhausted after their long term of duty in weather severely cold. On the approach of every train, constables were placed behind walls, and distributed along the platform, and horse-police were in readiness to dash off at a moment's notice, to bring skirmishers in to prevent a fight that was never to take place. Military men and others who had come long distances to be present at the pugilistic encounter, were loud in their complaints at the manner in which the principals, or those acting for them, backed out of their engagements. Much amusement to the knowing ones was occasioned on the arrival of the train which left town at 7:30 o'clock, by the constabulary having arrested a man named RYAN, from Tnurles, whom they mistook for MACE. Nothing could be more comic than the bewilderment expressed on the face of Mr. RYAN, who is a jolly-looking farmer, on being taken captive. He insisted that he was himself, and not JEM MACE, but he would not be believed by the sub-inspectors and sergeants, who took him into the booking office, and interrogated him with the most laughable solemnity; and it was not until two military gentlemen had pledged themselves that Mr. RYAN was not JEM MACE that he was allowed to go at large. While this scene was being enacted, JOE COBURN, it is stated, escaped from a house in the vicinity of the station, where he had been "lying up," and which the police searched shortly after the pugilist had got away. MACE, however, did not appear during the day, nor any of the pugilistic corps, and all those who appeared to be in the "secret" returned to town by the mid-day trains. It appears that shortly before two o'clock COBURN, accompanied by his trainer, CUSICK and his second J. MACKESY, succeeded in getting to a spot about a mile behind the Goold's Cross station, named Ballack. Here in the presence of CHARLES WESTHALL, of the Sporting Life, and Mr. JAMES, of the New-York Clipper, CUSICK formed the outline of the square which is miscalled the ring by planting four upright poles in the ground. Within the ring COBURN pitched his cap, the usual gage, and then followed it himself. MACE not putting in an appearance, COBURN claimed the Â£1000 stakes, on the ground that the articles specify that the men were to be on the spot named for the contest between twelve and two o'clock, and MACE had failed to keep the engagement.
lead_paragraph: The Freeman's Journal gives the following account of the measures adopted by the Irish authorities to prevent the threatened combat between MACE and COBURN: "Notwithstanding the result of the meeting for the appointment of the referee, the general belief on Tuesday was that the fight would take place. Mr. E. JAMES and others interested in the pugilistic encounter took their places in the mail train on Monday evening, the 3d, and a large number of detectives were hovering about the platform and book-office. The lovers of 'the manly sport of self-defence' took tickets for various stations beyond Goold's Cross, at which they were to stop, for the purpose of baffling the constabulary, who were to be seen in all kinds of strange costumes, and keeping a sharp look-out. Every male passenger was closely scrutinised for the object of coming at either of the champions, and questions were asked in the most insinuating manner with a view of finding out the place where COBURN had taken up his headquarters. As the train stopped at the several stations bodies of constabulary were to be seen drawn up on every platform, and crowds of country people all most eager to get a view of the pugilists whom they believed were in the train. Those who knew the real state of affairs were perfectly aware that the contest, of which so much had been written and spoken, would not come off, and that Mr. JAMES was only going down for the purpose of keeping an appointment with COBURN, who had pitched his ground in a farmhouse not many hundred yards from Goold's Cross Station, to tell him of the result of the meeting to appoint a referee, and to make arrangements for his appearing on the battle-ground between 12 and 2 o'clock, on the following day, in accordance with the stipulations contained in the articles. At Sallins, Newbridge, Kildare, and all the stations down to the Limerick Junction, the constabulary showed in great force, and, nothwithstanding the fact that the night was bitterly cold, with a sharp, freezing breeze from the eastward, crowds were congregated at all the places where the train stopped. It was clear from the concentration of a large force of constabulary at Goold's Cross Station, that the people in authority were well aware that that was the place selected by COBURN's friends for those concerned in the fight, to take their departure for "the trysting place." The ground selected was within a short distance of the "Rock of Cashel," a secluded place. On the arrival of the train at Goold's Cross Station there was no one to be found who could give any information about COBURN, and the absence of any of the reporters from the London sporting journals clearly proved that there was not the slightest chance of the fight taking place. One Hundred of the constabulary were drawn up under arms round the station, and after the Sergeants had taken stock of the passengers who had left the train, they retired to take shelter behind the nearest wall from the bitter wind that was blowing. Those who had come down to see the fight, and who had not abandoned the hope that the "mill" would come off, pushed on for Cashel on outside cars in the piercing cold, and on arriving at the "City of the Kings," they found that every bed in the hotels had been engaged, principally by the friends and backers of COBURN, several of whom had come over from Liverpool. It was positively stated that COBURN was in the neighborhood, but, strange to say, his own agent did not know where to find him or CUSICK, his trainer and backer. On Tuesday morning, COBURN's friends and several members of the Dublin press, proceeded from Cashel to Goold's Cross, a distance of five miles. The constabulary were even more numerous than on the day previous, and the men looked rather exhausted after their long term of duty in weather severely cold. On the approach of every train, constables were placed behind walls, and distributed along the platform, and horse-police were in readiness to dash off at a moment's notice, to bring skirmishers in to prevent a fight that was never to take place. Military men and others who had come long distances to be present at the pugilistic encounter, were loud in their complaints at the manner in which the principals, or those acting for them, backed out of their engagements. Much amusement to the knowing ones was occasioned on the arrival of the train which left town at 7:30 o'clock, by the constabulary having arrested a man named RYAN, from Tnurles, whom they mistook for MACE. Nothing could be more comic than the bewilderment expressed on the face of Mr. RYAN, who is a jolly-looking farmer, on being taken captive. He insisted that he was himself, and not JEM MACE, but he would not be believed by the sub-inspectors and sergeants, who took him into the booking office, and interrogated him with the most laughable solemnity; and it was not until two military gentlemen had pledged themselves that Mr. RYAN was not JEM MACE that he was allowed to go at large. While this scene was being enacted, JOE COBURN, it is stated, escaped from a house in the vicinity of the station, where he had been "lying up," and which the police searched shortly after the pugilist had got away. MACE, however, did not appear during the day, nor any of the pugilistic corps, and all those who appeared to be in the "secret" returned to town by the mid-day trains. It appears that shortly before two o'clock COBURN, accompanied by his trainer, CUSICK and his second J. MACKESY, succeeded in getting to a spot about a mile behind the Goold's Cross station, named Ballack. Here in the presence of CHARLES WESTHALL, of the Sporting Life, and Mr. JAMES, of the New-York Clipper, CUSICK formed the outline of the square which is miscalled the ring by planting four upright poles in the ground. Within the ring COBURN pitched his cap, the usual gage, and then followed it himself. MACE not putting in an appearance, COBURN claimed the £1000 stakes, on the ground that the articles specify that the men were to be on the spot named for the contest between twelve and two o'clock, and MACE had failed to keep the engagement.

abstract: The Royal Mail steamship Scotia arrived at this port yesterday morning from Liverpool, bringing advices to the 9th inst. The continued successes of SHERIDAN in the Shenandoah Valley created great excitement in Europe. English journals admit the influence of these victories, and concede that Mr. LINCOLN's reelection is a certainty. An address to the President, bearing the signatures of one hundred and fifty members of the International Association for the Improvement of Social Science, lately in session at Amsterdam, has been presented to the United States Consul at that city, to be forwarded to Mr. LINCOLN. The great prize-fight between MACE and COBURN still excites much discussion. There is no prospect of an immediate settlement of the Danish question. The French and Italian treaty is not acceptable to the Pope, who distrusts VICTOR EMANUEL, and threatens to call for protection on some other Catholic Power, in case the French troops should be withdrawn.

abstract: -The Lincoln and Johnson Veteran Union Club hold their first mass meeting at the Cooper Institute this evening. abstract: and Stephens' Speeches on War and Peace
snippet: and Stephens' Speeches on War and Peace
lead_paragraph: -- We have been favored of late with the views of both the rebel President and the rebel Vice-President. JEFF. DAVIS gave his views of the war, and STEPHENS gave his views on peace. DAVIS' speech was filled with complaints, and STEPHENS' letter is filled with demands. DAVIS could see nothing but darkness in the military situation; STEPHENS sees a "ray of light" in the "action of the Chicago Convention." DAVIS beat about him like a madman abusing everybody; STEPHENS is smooth, sophistical, plausible and inoffensive. The difference in the character and tone of the two utterances may be easily explained by the fact, that the one was an impromptu and heartfelt declamation, addressed to and for the benefit of the rebels of Georgia, while the other was meant for effect upon the people of the North.

abstract: Germans Misled by the Name Democrat
snippet: Germans Misled by the Name Democrat
lead_paragraph: It is a matter of no surprise that the newly-arrived German immigrant is so beguiled by the word "Democrat." It is a name associated in his mind with determined struggles against arbitrary power; it is connected with long-continued contests in the history of his country against kingcraft and priestcraft; it has been baptized in heroic blood. All that there is most noble and free in the popular aspirations, is coupled with this name, so hated and despised in his Fatherland by the powerful and the rich.

abstract: Progress of the; in Georgia; Hood's Failure
snippet: Progress of the; in Georgia; Hood's Failure
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERMAN has been manoeuvering for nearly six months to get into HOOD's rear, or, in other words, to get south of him. The whole campaign which has just ended in the capture of Atlanta, consisted of a series of attempts on the part of the former to get between JOHNSTON and Atlanta, and Atlanta was not evacuated until he had actually succeeded in getting to the south of a portion of the rebel army. In short, if at any time during the first four months of the campaign the news had come that SHERMAN had fairly succeeded in putting the rebel forces between him and Chattanooga, the whole North would have been filled with rejoicing.

abstract: Letter to Union Meeting, New-York; Speech at Union Meeting, New-York
snippet: Letter to Union Meeting, New-York; Speech at Union Meeting, New-York
lead_paragraph: While the Peace Democracy have been proclaiming from Maine to California that the soldiers would vote for "Little Mac." let him stand on what platform he would, the soldiers themselves have published their declaration on the question to Ohio and Pensylvania, and last night the soldiers of New-York, the veterans of many a campaign, gave voice, and told the country who they intended to vote for. The Lincoln Veteran Club, an association composed exclusively of officers and soldiers who have served during this war, and numbering 2,000 members, held their first grand mass meeting at the Cooper Institute last evening. No such meeting has been held in that hall since the campaign of 1860. In point of numbers, respectability and enthusiasm, it excelled anything that has been seen for years. It was a war meeting. The stage was not alone decorated with the favored banner of the Republic, but the implements of warfare, the cannon, the musket, the bayonet, and many a brave man who had used those weapons in support of that flag against the enemies of his country testified that the Lincoln Veterans meant war and no "cessation of hostilities" with armed rebels. Many of the most distinguished military men now in the city, numbers of eminent private citizens, and over one hundred wounded soldiers were on the stage. The audience, which filled the hall to suffocation, was plentifully sprinkled with the blue uniforms, and sunburnt faces of the heroes of the Potomac and Georgia. In the course of the address of Col. VAN BUREN, the question as to where Gen. MCCLELLAN was at the battle of Malvern Hill was raised and referred to the veteran soldiers present. In answer they sang out in one voice, "Gunboat;" "Galena." To the credit of the Lincoln Veteran Club, it can be said that they convened last night an enthusiastic war meeting, which will thrill with joy the hearts of their comrades in the field. Their motto is,

abstract: Birney, Major-Gen. D. B.
snippet: Birney, Major-Gen. D. B.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the statement made some days since that a severe attack of fever had compelled Maj.-Gen. D.B. BIRNEY. Commander of the Tenth Army Corps, to leave his post with the Army of the Potomac, the announcement of his death in yesterday's TIMES took the country by surprise. Gen. BIRNEY, was a son of JAMES B. BIRNEE, the Alabama planter, who gave practical testimony of his hatred for slavery by freeing all his negroes, and who was some years afterward nominated by the Abolitionists as their candidate for the Presidency. When the war broke out, Mr. BIRNEY was engaged in business in Philadelphia as Mercantile Collection Agent. He had been a member of the Republican party from the date of its organization. All the military knowledge that he possessed he had gained while connected in the State militia, but promptly upon the inauguration of hostilities by the South, he set about raising the Twenty-third Regiment Pennsylvania Volunteers, of which organization he was named Lieutenant-Colonel. At the expiration of his term of service he determined to organize another regiment, and within a few weeks again left Philadelphia at the head of Birney's Zouaves, one of the largest regiments which have gone from Pennsylvania. The organization was ordered to the Army of the Potomac, and Col. BIRNEY was soon after appointed Brigadier-General. The gallantry and bravery which he displayed during the Peninsular campaign, and the promptness and skill with which he handled his troops, secured his promotion to the command of the Third Division of the Second Corps in May last. His division performed its full share of service in the actions which forced LEE to retreat through the Wilderness, and which subsequently compelled him to fall back from the Rapidan to Petersburgh. In the march from Todd's Tavern to Spottsylvania Court-house, it occupied the right of the Army of the Potomac, and at the latter place, some days before the movement toward the North Ana, it distinguished itself and its determined Commander by carrying the whole line of rifle-pits in front of the rebel position -- an exploit which doubtless hastened LEE's retreat. Then, again, under Gen. BIRNEY's leadership, the same division did its duty brilliantly and well in the crossing of the North Ana and the Pamunkey, and at Hanover Court-house and Bethesda Church. At Cold Harbor, May 31, BIRNEY's division, which was on the north bank of the Totopatamoy, forded the creek, scaled the steep bank on the opposite side and carried the works held by BRECKINRIDGE, almost without firing a gun. Gen. BIRNEY has borne a prominent part in all the operations before Petersburgh and Richmond, and on July 23d Gen. GRANT promoted him to the command of the Tenth Corps in the Army of the James. A few days since he was taken sick with the premonitory symptoms of malarious fever, and there is every reason to believe that his vigorous constitution would have enabled him to resist the disease, had it not been for the exertions which he made upon the occasion of the rebel attack upon KAUTZ's cavalry corps. Immediately upon receiving information of the disaster which had befallen this detachment, Gen. BIRNEY, as will be remembered, left his bed, and at the head of his division recovered and held all the ground that had been lost. The excitement aggravated his complaint, and a day or two afterward he was found to be so much worse that his removal to his home in Philadelphia became a matter of necessity, and there, as has already been announced, he died on Tuesday night. In him the army loses one of its best and bravest leaders, and our cause one of its most consistent and earnest defenders.

abstract: Great Speech at Covington, Ky.
snippet: Great Speech at Covington, Ky.
lead_paragraph: KENTUCKIANS -- LADIES AND GENTLEMEN: Four years ago I stood where I now stand, and spoke to an audience in this hall upon the issues which were then before the country. Then, as now, I advocated the election of ABRAHAM LINCOLN to the Presidency of the United States, and I endeavored to show to my fellow citizens that the Republican plan -- what we now know as the Union plan -- for the settlement of the great controversy before the country, was the true plan. Four parties then claimed the suffrage of American citizens. One supported Mr. BRECKINRIDGE and asserted as their fundamental principle that slavery should be extended throughout the Union; not only that it should be secure in the States where it existed under local constitutions and laws, but that it should be carried beyond those limits, into all the territories of the Union; not only so, but that under claims of transit and reclamation it should be established practically in all the States. I endeavored to show you at that time that upon this platform there could be no peace. Another party supported Mr. DOUGLAS, and their theory was, that subject to the construction of the Constitution by the Supreme Court, and to the action of the Federal Administration, slavery should be disposed of in the Territories of the Union, according to the will of the inhabitants of these Territories. The objection to this theory, which I deemed to be insuperable, and which I then stated to you was, that under the practical operations of the Government, and under judicial constructions of the Constitution by the Supreme Court, no practical liberty of choice was left to the people of the Territories. Another party, of which Mr. BELL and Mr. EVERETT were the representatives, took for their, platform the simple motto, the Union, the Constitution, and the enforcement of the laws. That this was a good platform, I fully conceded; but maintained that, as as all parties claimed alike to stand upon it, it could not form any substantial issue before the American people. That no issue was, in fact, made by it, is plain enough, from the disposition which the rebellion has made of its candidates. Mr. BELL as you all know, is now among the rebels, and openly arrayed against the Constitution and Union, and the enforcement of the laws, while Mr. EVERETT in his vigorous age, (long may he live, the pride and ornament of his country,) upholds with all his energies the Constitution and the Union, and insists that throughout every foot of American soil, every constitutional law must be enforced by the whole power of the Government. [Applause.] Having considered these plans of settlement and shown them to be impracticable and defective, I invoked your attention to that proposed by Mr. LINCOLN and his friends. Its substance was simply this: That we should let slavery alone, in all the States which it existed, subject only and absolutely to the disposal of the people of those States; but that beyond State limits, where the Government of the United States and the people who make the Government, are directly responsible for the existence of slavery, there ought to be, and could be, no allowance of the institution. I endeavored to show you that acquiescence in that simple proposition would give peace to the country. Slavery, except by the free action of the citizens of the State, would be disturbed in no State where it existed; it would simply be excluded from the territories and portions of the country under the exclusive jurisdiction of the Congress of the United States. In the States it would remain absolutely undisturbed. No guarantee of the rights of any State would be invaded or jostled. With this principle established, no just cause of complaint could remain. This I endeavored to show you on that occasion.

abstract: A party of twenty-five armed men rode into St. Albans this afternoon, and robbed the three banks there of $150,000. It is supposed they were southern- ers from the border of Canada. Five citizens were shot, one it is thought fatally. Having accomplished their object the band left immediately for Canada.

abstract: Our correspondent at Quebec sends a special telegram, announcing the agreement of the Federal Convention assembled there, on the essential points of an inter-colonial Union. The great question of a representation basis, it appears to us is "settled" in a way which will prove neither permanent nor satisfactory.
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent at Quebec sends a special telegram, announcing the agreement of the Federal Convention assembled there, on the essential points of an inter-colonial Union. The great question of a representation basis, it appears to us is "settled" in a way which will prove neither permanent nor satisfactory. They are to have a Lower House of Parliament, constituted on the principle of representation according to population. They are to have an Upper House, constituted by nomination of the Crown, with conditions attached to it which must make it, ultimately, a more dangerous instrument in the hands of an Executive than it was twenty-seven years ago. This proposed House of Lords was universally condemned in Lower Canada before the radical French Canadians rebelled in 1837. And the Liberals of both nationalities agitated until they secured an amendment of their Constitution, which gave them two elective Chambers, instead of one. They are now going back to the old system, under a provision which must ultimately make it more dangerous to popular liberty than ever. They propose to have seventy-six nominated legislators in their Upper House, distributed among the different Provinces, on a rule-of-thumb scale -- the Canadas having twenty-four each, for the twenty-eight assigned to the maritime Colonies. This distribution of Senatorial power will have to be kept up according to the new Constitution. There will be no means of increasing the number, as in the case of the House of Lords, in the event of a dead-lock taking place between the Lower and Upper Legislative Chambers. The British Reform Bill of 1832 could not have been law to-day, if the power of increasing the number of "Lords" had not vested in the King and his advisers.

abstract: The President made a most excellent speech, last night, from an "upper window" of the White House, to a body of Marylanders, congratulating them on the redemption of their State from negro slavery, by the vote of last week.
lead_paragraph: The President made a most excellent speech, last night, from an "upper window" of the White House, to a body of Marylanders, congratulating them on the redemption of their State from negro slavery, by the vote of last week. After this he gave a few remarks upon national topics, and made a most important announcement, which will furnish great relief to all Copperheads, and ought to call out proclamations from Mayor GUNTHER and Mr. BELMONT for the illumination of the city. President LINCOLN explicitly and loudly announced that if he were not elected in November, he would not usurp the reins of power for another term. Will not the Copperheads breathe freer, sleep sounder, and look less haggard and wretched after this? It is this that they have been in mortal fear of for the last six months. They have talked about it all day and every day; dreamed about it every night and all night, and pondered over it on Sundays. It has interfered with their digestion; has made them bilious and atrabilious, and has brought some of them to the verge of suicide. All this misery has been for nothing. Like so many of the worst miseries of life, it has had a purely fictitious cause. President LINCOLN does not mean to usurp power, does not intend a coup d'etat, if not elected. He kindly says that he hopes the good people will permit themselves to suffer no uneasiness. And moreover, he further declares that instead of attempting to ruin the Government, if not elected, he will struggle, from the moment of his defeat at the polls until the moment he leaves the Executive chair, to sustain the Government, so that, "whosoever shall hold the helm for the next four years, shall start with the best possible chances to save the ship."

abstract: Speech at Union Meeting, New-York; Speech at Union Meeting, New-York; Speech at Union Meeting, N Y
snippet: Speech at Union Meeting, New-York; Speech at Union Meeting, New-York; Speech at Union Meeting, N Y
lead_paragraph: The greatest gathering this town ever witnessed took place on last Tuesday night, on the occasion of the dedication of the Union Wigwam. The principal meeting inside the Wigwam was presided over by Judge J.E. CARY, of Plainfield, who, in a brief address, defined his position. For forty odd years he had been in political life, and this campaign was the first in which he had not supported the Democratic party. He could not stand on the Chicago platform, founded as it was in hypocrisy and fraud. He denied the right of those calling themselves Democrats to use the name in support of their treason. After a few eloquent remarks from the Judge, he introduced the speakers, Ex-Gov. PIERRPONT, of Virginia, and Col. R.B. CARPENTER, of Kentucky, who delighted the audience with their able and masterly expositions of the issues of the day.

abstract: Canada their Base
snippet: Canada their Base
lead_paragraph: The rebels are making Canada their base of operations for both land and naval raids. It is only a few weeks since a body of Confederates, from the British side, made their rush upon our vessels in Lake Erie, and captured a couple of small steamboats, which they burned; and this morning we are startled with a telegraphic account of an invasion and raid upon St. Albans, Vermont, yesterday, by a band of a score or more of armed rebel desperadoes from Canada. These Confederated ruffians shot several citizens of the town, wounding two seriously, and it is feared fatally -- assailed three banks, and plundered them of a very large sum of money -- supplied themselves with horses, and threatened to burn the town, -- after which they left in the direction of Canada. A body of citizens quickly started in pursuit; but as St. Albans is only about ten miles from the Canada line, there is little doubt that the rebel ruffians escaped.

abstract: As a general rule, what a man does or does not do in his own house, is not and ought not to be a matter of concern to anybody else who is not injured by it. But there are exceptions to this as to every other rule, and we cannot help saying that when a public man calls on his neighbors and followers...
lead_paragraph: As a general rule, what a man does or does not do in his own house, is not and ought not to be a matter of concern to anybody else who is not injured by it. But there are exceptions to this as to every other rule, and we cannot help saying that when a public man calls on his neighbors and followers to illuminate their houses in honor of what he alleges to be a political victory, he is bound to set the example himself, and prove his faith in his own words, by at least a display of light in his windows. This the public have a right to expect of him; for if those who call for illuminations, fail to illuminate themselves, if those who propose three cheers, refuse to lead the cheering themselves, it not unnaturally shakes the faith of the masses in human nature. If the practice became general, enthusiasm, which is perhaps the noblest of human emotions, would rapidly die out, and the very greatest occasions would soon cease to be marked by the smallest popular excitement.

abstract: The managers of the above-named institution have opened a fair at Irving Hall, under the auspices of Churches, Public Schools and the Fire Department of New-York and Brooklyn, for the purpose of securing funds sufficient to build a home for the orphan children of our volunteers. This institution was chartered by an act of the Legislature, April 24, 1862 and has been in active operation over two years, during which time it has supported and instructed over one thousand children, and has now its rooms crowded with those little objects of interest, who still look to public generosity for their support. The institution is under the immediate supervision of a number of our most wealthy and respected citizens, which, in a great measure, accounts for its success up to the present time. It, however, needs constant effort to sustain such an undertaking, and this fair should receive the liberal support of the entire public. Independent of this, the fair is of itself sufficiently an object of interest to invite public attention, it really being only second in importance to the great Sanitary Fair of this city.
lead_paragraph: The managers of the above-named institution have opened a fair at Irving Hall, under the auspices of Churches, Public Schools and the Fire Department of New-York and Brooklyn, for the purpose of securing funds sufficient to build a home for the orphan children of our volunteers. This institution was chartered by an act of the Legislature, April 24, 1862 and has been in active operation over two years, during which time it has supported and instructed over one thousand children, and has now its rooms crowded with those little objects of interest, who still look to public generosity for their support. The institution is under the immediate supervision of a number of our most wealthy and respected citizens, which, in a great measure, accounts for its success up to the present time. It, however, needs constant effort to sustain such an undertaking, and this fair should receive the liberal support of the entire public. Independent of this, the fair is of itself sufficiently an object of interest to invite public attention, it really being only second in importance to the great Sanitary Fair of this city.

abstract: Vermont, Lord Monck's Action on
snippet: Vermont, Lord Monck's Action on
lead_paragraph: -- We are glad to see that the hope we expressed yesterday, as to the action of the Governor-General and other British authorities in Canada, in reference to the pirates who entered Vermont on Wednesday, is already realized. The leader and others of the banditti have been caught, and a good portion of their plunder recovered, through the exertions of the aroused citizens of Vermont, who seem to have pursued them across the lines, and who received the most active co-operation of all the British authorities. Half a dozen of the raiders have been lodged in a Canadian jail to await a requisition from the American authorities -- the Governor-General promptly telegraphing that he will respond to a requisition for their surrender. Lord MONCK, we are told, in all his communications upon the subject, exhibits an interest equal to that of the people of Vermont to have the murderers brought to speedy retribution.

abstract: Speech on Maryland Election
snippet: Speech on Maryland Election
lead_paragraph: It was well enough, perhaps, for Mr. LINCOLN, in the freedom of a serenade speech, to put his foot, as he did, on the imputation of the Copperheads that he intended, if defeated, to do what he could to ruin the Government before transferring it to his successor. Yet it is humiliating that the party hostility to him is so reckless as to prompt the President of the United States to deny publicly that he intends to be a perjurer and a traitor. The perversion of Mr. SEWARD's language, on which the charge was based, was outrageous. It had not the faintest shadow of excuse. It could only spring from a thoroughly vitiated and utterly reprobate party spirit. Mr. SEWARD's loyal meaning was patent; and, more than that, his argument was solemn truth, which every patriot should well ponder.
headline: {'main': "President Lincoln's Speech.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "President Lincoln's Speech.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Going to Fix His Claws
snippet: Going to Fix His Claws
lead_paragraph: -- After JEFF. DAVIS had delivered his speech at Augusta, Gen. HARDEE made a few remarks, in the course of which he said that HOOD had told him that "on Tuesday, (4th,) he hoped to lay his claws upon the State road, and having once fixed them there, it was not his intention to let them lose their hold." What a pity it is that Gen. SHERMAN has so little reverence for rebel claws and rebel intentions.

abstract: Fifth Ward War Eagles Attacked by Rowdies
snippet: Fifth Ward War Eagles Attacked by Rowdies
lead_paragraph: Wednesday evening the 5th Ward War Eagles, 100 strong, under their Marshal, CHAS. H. PATRICK, with banners, torches and uniforms, paraded their Ward, and made an imposing appearance. The line of march was crowded with citizens who cheered and waved their bats in approval of the demonstration. Several members of the Club were hit from showers of brickbats and other missiles, which were nurled at the procession by gangs of Copperheads, some of whom cheered for JEFF. DAVIS. Some person in the crowd upon the sidewalk fired a pistol at the procession, and the ball struck Mr. E.C. TOWNSEND, who does business at No. 726 Broadway, in the back of the head, inflicting a painful, but not dangerous, wound. He was cared at the City Hospital. These cowardly attacks should be stopped by the Police. Please take notice, Mr. KENNEDY.

abstract: Gen. SHERIDAN, the gallant hero of the Shenandoah Valley, gives to the country, by virtue of his own brilliant genius, and the indomitable valor of his army, another substantial victory, more important, so far as the trophies of battle are concerned, than any he has yet won. On Wednesday morning at daylight, the rebels, under ...
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERIDAN, the gallant hero of the Shenandoah Valley, gives to the country, by virtue of his own brilliant genius, and the indomitable valor of his army, another substantial victory, more important, so far as the trophies of battle are concerned, than any he has yet won. On Wednesday morning at daylight, the rebels, under command of LONGSTREET, and strongly reinforced, made a surprise attack upon the left of the Eighth Corps, and succeeded in throwing it into confusion, forcing it back some distance, throwing the whole line into more or less disorder, and finally causing it to fallback four miles with the loss of twenty pieces of artillery. Gen. SHERIDAN, who was at Winchester, on his return from Washington, hastened to the battle-field, twelve miles distant, "took the affair in hand," as he tersely says, and by 1 o'clock had reformed his lines compactly, just in time to repulse, in good style, a second attack of the enemy. At 3 o'clock Gen. SHERIDAN took the offensive himself, made an impetuous assault upon the rebel lines, which soon gave way in complete rout, leaving many prisoners, forty-three pieces of artillery and one hundred wagons and ambulances in our hands. The enemy were pursued beyond Strasburgh, which town SHERIDAN occupied at night. The losses on either side are not yet reported. Gen. BIDWELL commanding a brigade in the Sixth Corps, was killed, and Gens. WRIGHT, RICKETTS and GROVER were wounded, the first-named but slightly. The rebel Gen. RAMSEUR fell into our hands mortally wounded.

abstract: Moore vs J G Bennett, (New-York Herald;) Libel; Taney, Chief-Justice, United States Circuit Court on
snippet: Moore vs J G Bennett, (New-York Herald;) Libel; Taney, Chief-Justice, United States Circuit Court on
lead_paragraph: John. W. Moore vs. James Gordon Bennett. -- This was an action for libel against the New-York Herald, plaintiff laying his damages at $10,000. Plaintiff, who is the general agent of the Central Railroad Company in this city, alleges that defendant published against him a malicious libel in a letter from Mrs. Helen M. Kimball, widow of Col. Kimball, of the Ninth New-York Volunteers, which appealed in the Herald of the 17th of June, 1863. In this letter Mrs. Kimball said, among other things, that even the letters of her deceased husband were returned to her after his death "through the hands of a prostitute called Mary Ann Smith, who was living under the protection of J.W. Moore, agent of the Central Railroad Company." This was the libelous matter complained of by plaintiff. Before the case was opened, David Dudley Field, counsel for Mr. Bennett, stated that the defendant desired to amend his answer. In the original answer the defense set up was a justification of the publication by alleging the truth of the matter called libelous. Since that answer was served the defendant had ascertained from Mrs. Kimball and others, that the charge contained in the published letter was unfounded in fact, as far as Moore was concerned. Defendant had then offered Mr. Moore all the reparation in his power, and had published a retraction of the libel. Plaintiff not being satisfied with this retraction, defendant offered to publish a retraction written by plaintiff himself, and such an article was prepared by plaintiff's attorney and published in the Herald, but plaintiff was still dissatisfied. Counsel now moved to strike out all that portion of the original answer which set up that the libelous matter was true. Plaintiff's counsel objected to this, but the objection was overruled and the motion granted.

abstract: Desperate Hopes and False Statements
snippet: Desperate Hopes and False Statements
lead_paragraph: Nothing proves more clearly that the fortunes of the rebels are more desperate now than ever before, than the false hopes and false statements which have been entertained and uttered in regard to HOOD's last movement. The condition of rebel public sentiment is now so gloomy, that their papers are resorting, with renewed vigor, to the old dodge of gross exaggeration and downright lying. They feel so greatly the necessity of throwing some gleam of light upon their failing fortunes, that the merest rumors -- even their hopes -- are printed as facts and sent forth, to cheer the despondent hearts of their people. All manner of concealment in regard to their reverses is now more uniformly resorted to than ever before, and you might as well expect the truth from the father of liars as from a rebel newspaper in these days. Witness their reports about HOOD's attack on Allatoona. The bare, actual facts of their attack and repulse are first given, just as they reached us. But that would not do. The desperate rebels follow it up by a statement that after the attack by one division failed, a whole corps was brought up, the town carried by assault, and four thousand prisoners, with immense munitions of war captured. Our readers will remember the bloody repulse of the rebels by five regiments of infantry and one battery of artillery, and their inglorious retreat afterward. So in regard to the capture of Rome. The rebels first reported that the city had been taken, and three thousand negro soldiers captured with it. What is the truth? Why, from their own sources we learn that Rome was empty when the rebels marched into it, our troops having been sent to the relief of Allatoona. Rome was not on our line of communication, and, therefore, it was not necessary to hold it. Again, with regard to affairs in the Valley. The rebel papers stoutly denied that they lost more than a dozen pieces of artillery in that whole campaign. SHERIDAN can show 35 in his actual possession -- not to speak of the 43 he took on Wednesday last. But the truth, after a while, sometimes gets out through rebel sources. A "well-informed officer of EARLY's army," as the Richmond Enquirer calls him, in a letter deploring the utter uselessness of their cavalry, admits that SHERIDAN has taken thirty-one guns from them. This desperate shift of the rebel papers to sustain their rapidly sinking cause, will possibly help to sustain the hearts of their people a short time longer. But how will the miserable dupes feel when they discover that they have been made the victims of such an outrageous system of falsehood? Will they have halters long enough and strong enough to hang the villains who daily and hourly deceive them?
headline: {'main': 'THE DESPERATION OF REBEL FORTUNES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE DESPERATION OF REBEL FORTUNES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Carpenter's Emancipation Proclamation; Cabinet-Making
snippet: Carpenter's Emancipation Proclamation; Cabinet-Making
lead_paragraph: Mr. F.B. CARPENTER's picture, representing the Cabinet-meeting at which President LINCOLN promulgated for the first time his Emancipation Proclamation, is now on exhibition in this city. It will repay an examination. The subject possesses great interest, and will improve with the growing civilization of the age. Public virtue must always be satisfied with an act that contemplates the happiness of a down-trodden race, and no more fitting subject for the brush of an artist can be found than the illustration of those great principles of human freedom which, in this moment of intense conviction, have happily actuated the minds of some of our best and most prominent statesmen. The subject chosen by Mr. CARPENTER does not lend itself to any other treatment than that which he has bestowed upon it. The picture will be viewed with satisfaction by succeeding generations for its special merits of portraiture. When slavery has become a surprise and a horror to everyone in the land; when the Proclamation of President LINCOLN has passed into history as a splendid trophy of a sanguinary war; when the gratitude of a people that no longer knows a bondsman reverts to the heroes that made them glorious, then will such a canvas be gazed upon with respectful admiration, and the features that are familiar to us to-day be regarded as typical of a stronger race of men than the world can always claim for its leaders.

abstract: -- The annual Convention of the Sabbath School teachers of Essex County, N.J., was held at bloomfield on Wednesday last. The Sabbath Schools of the township, nine in number, embraced the opportunity to show their strength, and early in the afternoon assembled in the public square to the number of nearly one thousand. After marching in procession around the square, they repaired to the Presbyterian church, which they filled to overflowing, hardly any room being left for outsiders. Spirited addresses were made by Rev. Dr. PORTER, of Williamsburgh, Rev. Mr. PARDEE, of this city, Mr. MOORE, of Jersey City, and Mr. SWENZEL, of Newark. The singing was under the charge of Prof. W.B. BRADBURY, of this city, and was such as he alone is capable of eliciting from juvenile throats. In the evening the Sabbath school teachers elected the officers of their organization for another year, and listened to an eloquent address from Dr. PORTER upon the importance of their work and its rewards, while Mr. PARDEE gave both superintendents and teachers some practical suggestions regarding the manner in which they might render their labors most effective.

abstract: -- A Union meeting is to be held this evening at the Bleecker Building, in the Ninth Ward, partly to ratify the nomination of HENRY J. RAYMOND for Congress. The speakers who will be present are Hon. C.A. PHELPS, Speaker of the Massachusetts House of Representatives, Judge W.R. BEEBE and Mr. RAYMOND. It will be remembered that Col. HAWKINS is also a Union candidate in this District; but we are assured that, so far as Mr. RAYMOND is concerned, there will be no difficulty in making such arrangements as will lead to the concentration of the vote of the District upon a single candidate.

abstract: Arming Slaves; Richmond Enquirer on; Richmond Enquirer on
snippet: Arming Slaves; Richmond Enquirer on; Richmond Enquirer on
lead_paragraph: We publish an extraordinary article from the Richmond Enquirer of Tuesday, of this week, on the subject of arming the negro slaves of the Confederacy to do battle for its existence. This is the second discussion of the subject by the Enquirer, and it tells us that since it first formally and favorably advanced the idea of creating a negro army for the South, it "has received many assurances of its popular favor, and none whatever of opposition to it." It adds that the "planters in the extreme Southern States favor the proposition, and some have signified their readiness to free five, ten, or fifteen of their slaves if they will enter the army." It says there is in the South a "half million of fighting material which is property; shall we use that property for the common cause?" It argues that the "conscription of negroes should be accompanied with freedom, and the privilege of remaining in the States," and that "justice and sound policy demand that we make free men of those who fight for freedom." The whole subject is discussed at once with an earnestness, and absence of bombast, that shows it was intended to have a practical effect, and the closing words are these: "If there are any reasons against extending the conscription to slaves, we should like to have them stated, but we are decidedly of the opinion that the whole country will agree to the proposition, and that at an early day the next Congress will be called upon to provide for it by law."
headline: {'main': 'A New and Starting Development The "Richmond Enquirer" on Arming Negro Slaves.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A New and Starting Development The "Richmond Enquirer" on Arming Negro Slaves.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Political Failure
snippet: Political Failure
lead_paragraph: -- It seems that the present, or rather the late offensive campaign of HOOD was actually undertaken as a means of affording aid and comfort to the peace party of the North. JEFF. DAVIS, himself, confessed so in his speech delivered at Augusta on the 3d inst., just prior to HOOD's advance. He said: "Wc must beat SHERMAN; we must march into Tennessee; there we will draw from 20,000 to 30,000 to our standard, and so strengthened, we must push the enemy back to the Ohio, and thus give the peace party of the North an accretion no puny editorial can give." The peace party must greatly grieve over the ill fortune which has be fallen the army of HOOD in its desperate effort to aid them. Their newspapers and speakers give abundant evidence of their disappointment.

abstract: Call for Convention of those Opposed to Chicago Platform
snippet: Call for Convention of those Opposed to Chicago Platform
lead_paragraph: All of Democratic faith, who retain then respect for the manhood and patriotism which animated the Democratic Party in the days of JACKSON; who will not consent that the cherished [???]ame and principles of that party be disgraced; who cannot endure the shame of seeing their country's flag lowered to a loitering foe, ever ready to trample it in the dust; who deny that the American Democracy was fairly represented at Chicago by the few, who, by threats of Northwestern revolt, forced upon the Convention the degrading concession, that "the war," so nobly fought by our brave army and navy, "was a failure and that justice, humanity, liberty and the public welfare demand that immediate efforts be made for a cessation of hostilities:" who believed that "the immediate cessation of hostilities" should begin with Southern traitors and not with Northern patriots; who believe that we should first exhaust the rebel armies, before we attempt "to exhaust all the resources of statesmanship;" who insist "that the Union must be preserved at all hazards," and are determined to preserve it whole and entire at any sacrifice, and against all attacks from whatever quarter; such are requested to meet at the Cooper Institute, in the city of New-York, on Tuesday, the 1st day of November, 1864, to consider the proper course to be pursued in the present exigencies of public affairs, and of preserving the honor and integrity of our country.

abstract: The managers of the Union Home and School for Soldiers' Children, are now holding a fair at Irving Hall to raise funds for this truly charitable and patriotic institution. It would be a reproach to the patriotism and benevolence of New-York if this truly worthy enterprise should fail for want of the cooperation of her liberal citizens, The rooms were visited last evening by Maj.-Gen. BANKS and lady, and Brig.-Gen. COCHRANE who were received and entertained in a handsome manner by Mr. HUNTINGTON, LEE and the committee. Gen. COCHRANE made a few remarks in his usual happy vein, and expressed his fervent wishes for the success of the fair. To those who desire to pass a pleasant evening in delightful company, to enjoy excellent music and to invest their spare cash in useful articles, at reasonable prices, the fair for the soldiers' children is cordially recommended. The decorations of the hall are elegant, and the stalls well supplied with merchandise. The refreshment saloon is unusually well provided and attended. The Floral Temple, presided over by Mrs. DEVOE, is one of the chief features of the room, and the stall filled by Thirteenth Ward Primary School No. 4, is especially to be commended for the good taste displayed and the patriotism of its fair attendants. Miss KATE GAYNOR, Miss MARY RIGGS and Miss SWARTZ.

abstract: Letter on Peace; Peace Principle, the; H V Johnson's and Boyce's Letters; Letter on Peace; Union Convention; The Call for
snippet: Letter on Peace; Peace Principle, the; H V Johnson's and Boyce's Letters; Letter on Peace; Union Convention; The Call for
lead_paragraph: None of the Northera "peace men," so called, can desire peace more strongly than we do, provided it does not endanger the nation. The man who wants this bloodshed continuedlone day beyond an actual national necessity, is a criminal before high Heaven. It is the solemn duty of every Northern man to understand precisely what this necessity is, and where it stops. To understand this, it must be known what the Southern peace principle is. Is it one that can safely be accepted?

abstract: The Eighty-fourth Regiment, N.G.S.N.Y., Col. CONKLING, now at Martinsburgh, Va., will leave for home on Friday morning, reaching this city on Saturday, the 22d inst. This regiment has spent its hundred days' enlistment in active service. During the past ten days it has, in conjunction with the Thirteenth and Fifteenth Maine Regiments, the Eighteenth Connecticut, and Second East Shore Maryland, been guarding the communications of Gen. SHERIDAN, as also the city of Martinsburgh, the great depot of the supplies for his army. Col. RUST, of the Thirteenth Maine, commands the brigade. Col. CONKLING will bring home 600 men.

abstract: Nabuc, Monitor, Launch of
snippet: Nabuc, Monitor, Launch of
lead_paragraph: LAUNCH OF THE NABUC. -- The light-draught monitor Nabuc was launched yesterday about noon from the yard of W. PERINE, Esq., at Williamsburgh. Quite a number of distinguished persons were present, among them Admiral: F.H. GREGORY, Capt. BOGGS and Chief-Engineer HALL. The launch passed off nicely, and the vessel entered the water amid enthusiastic cheering. The Nabuc was designed, with nineteen others, by Chief-Engineer ALBAN C. STIMERS, United States Navy. Thus far they have been failures. In the case of the Nabuc, she promises better success. Over one hundred and sixty tons of dead weight have been set aside, including the turret and its appurtenances. Much extraneous matter has been taken out of the vessel, the surface condenser has been removed and a jet concenser fills its place. The diameter of the screws have been increased, and the propeller well cut out" so that she will not drag so much water in her wake. A pilot house will take the place of the turret, and one 11-inch gun will be placed in pivot on the forward deck. The gun's crew will be protected by portable wrought iron shields. The Nabuc is of the following dimensions: Length, 225 feet; beam, 45 feet 3 inches; depth, 8 feet 11 inches; tons. 614. She has two engines, built by DORLAN & FARRON, Williamsburgh, with 30-inch cylinders, and 32-inch stroke of piston. She has two four-blocked screws, 9 feet in diameter, with 9 feet pitch. After launching, her average draught of water was ascertained to be 5 feet 7 inches. She was 3 feet out of water forward, two feet three inches aft, and two feet five inches amidships. This is better than any of them have done yet. In addition to the eleven-inch gun, the vessel will be filled with WOOD's torpedo machine. When complete for service, this vessel, as well as those which are being subjected to the same alterations, will be of some service, but nothing to comparison to their cost. It is expected to have her ready for sea by the first day of November, when she will be sent out to do duty. The Cohoes, bul[???]ding at the Continental Iron Works, and Modoc, building by J.S. UNDERHLL, will soon be ready to launch, which will complete all of the monitor iron-clads building in this immediate vicinity.

abstract: It has pleased Almighty God to prolong our national life another year, defending us, with His guardian care, against unfriendly designs from abroad, and vouchsafed to us, in His mercy, many and signal victories over the enemy, who is of our own household. It has also pleased our Heavenly Father to favor as well our citizens in their homes as our soldiers in their camps and our sailors on the rivers and seas, with unusual health. He has largely augmented our free population by emancipation and by immigration, while He has opened to us new sources of wealth, and has crowned the labor of our working men in every department of industry with abundant reward. Moreover, he has been pleased to animate and inspire our minds and hearts with fortitude, courage and resolution sufficient for the great trial of civil war into which we have been brought by our adherence, as a nation, to the cause of freedom and humanity, and to afford to us reasonable hopes of an ultimate and happy deliverance from all our dangers and afflictions.

abstract: In our columns this morning will be found an important political document, in the shape of a call for a convention and mass meeting of "all of Democratic faith, who retain their respect for the manhood and patriotism which animated the Democratic party in the days ...
lead_paragraph: In our columns this morning will be found an important political document, in the shape of a call for a convention and mass meeting of "all of Democratic faith, who retain their respect for the manhood and patriotism which animated the Democratic party in the days of JACKSON; who will not consent that the cherished name and principles of that party be disgraced; who cannot endure the shame of seeing their country's flag lowered to a tottering foe, ever ready to trample it in the dust; who deny that the American Democracy was fairly represented at Chicago by the few, who, by threats of Northwestern revolt, forced upon the convention the degrading concession that 'the war,' so nobly fought by our brave army and navy, 'was a failure, and that justice, humanity, liberty and the public welfare demand that immediate efforts be made for a cessation of hostilities;' who believe that 'the immediate cessation of hostilities' should begin with Southern traitors and not with Northern patriots; who believe that we should first exhaust the rebel armies before we attempt 'to exhaust all the resources of statesmanship;' who insist 'that the Union must be preserved at all hazards,' and are determined to preserve it whole and entire at any sacrifice and against all attacks from whatever quarter." The call is signed by a large number of the most respected and most prominent Democrats of this city, such as F.B. CUTTING, MOSES TAYLOR, JOHN A. DIX, A.T. STEWART, JAMES R. WHITING, WM. H. WEBB, D.S. CODDINGTON, THEODORE ROOSEVELT, and others; and also by prominent Democrats of all the Eastern, Western, Central and Southwestern States, who "unite in the call in behalf of their respective States and organizations."

abstract: A large Union meeting was held by the Young Men's Central Committee on Thursday night, corner of Twenty-third-street and Broadway. H.C. PARK presided, and introduced WILLIAM WALTER PHELPS, Esq., who delivered an address. Mr. PHELPS reviewed the rise and progress of the rebellion, and the course of the Government in quelling it. He denounced the Democracy as the peace party, and showed the audience that there could be no peace with the South except in the successful prosecution of the war. If it should he attempted to make peace by negotiation the South would demand of us that we should give up Maryland, Kentucky, Missouri, Delaware and Tennessee. More than all that, they would demand the rendition of 300,000 colored men now bearing arms in behalf of freedom and the Union.

abstract: Later intelligence from Gen. SHERIDAN has been received by the War Department at Washington, which shows the recent victory in the Shenandoah Valley to have been most complete in its results. By the most admirable strategy, ...
lead_paragraph: Later intelligence from Gen. SHERIDAN has been received by the War Department at Washington, which shows the recent victory in the Shenandoah Valley to have been most complete in its results. By the most admirable strategy, Gen. SHERIDAN turned what bade fair to be an overwhelming disaster into a glorious victory. The attack on the enemy was made about 3 in the afternoon, by a left half wheel of the whole line, with a division of cavalry turning each flank of the enemy. The enemy made a brave and stubborn defence; but such was the impetuosity of the attack that they could not long withstand it, and they finally broke and fled, leaving, it is estimated, over fifty pieces of artillery in on hands. At least sixteen hundred prisoners were captured, and large numbers of wagons and ambulances. On Thursday morning, our cavalry made a dash at Fisher's Hill, which the rebels had been fortifying, and captured it. It was feebly defended by a small rear guard.

lead_paragraph: Another mass meeting of the Union party, in which the returned veterans took a prominent part, was held last evening at the Cooper Institute, under the auspices of the Central Union Lincoln and Johnson Club. The number and frequency at these gatherings in no sense weakens the enthusiasm felt by the people; but, on the contrary, the interest, as demonstrated by crowded audiences and unflagging attention, increases with each occasion -- heightened in no small degree by the victories which give a text to every argument in favor of an uncompromising prosecution of the war.

abstract: Hanley, Miss E, by Poison; Skelton, Druggist, Censured
snippet: Hanley, Miss E, by Poison; Skelton, Druggist, Censured
lead_paragraph: -- Miss ELLEN HANLEY, aged eighteen years, residing with her parents at No. 535 Second-avenue, died on Friday from the effects of a dose of arsenic administered by herself for the purpose of terminating her life. Coroner RANNEY held an inquest on the body. The testimony taken failed to elicit the cause that induced the young woman to commit the fatal deed. She had been in a depressed state of mind for two or three days. Deceased sent a small girl, named HENRIETTA SHERWOOD. residing in the same house, to the drug store of Dr. CHRISTOPHER P. SKELTON, NO. 573 Second-avenue, to purchase six cents worth of arsenic, for the avowed purpose of killing rats. Neither the name or residence of the girl was taken by the druggist, as is required by law. When Dr. SKELTON delivered the poison to the messenger, he told her to be sure and give it to the person who sent her for it. When Miss HANLEY received it from the girl, she earnestly requested her to tell no one that she had procured the drug for her. She then swallowed the poison and died soon after. The jury in their verdict say "deceased came to her death by suicide by taking arsenic, and we further censure Dr. CHRISTOPHER P. SKELTON, of No. 573 Second-avenue, for selling poison to a child contrary to law." The Doctor was required by the Coroner to find bail in the sum of $1,000 to answer any indictment that the Grand Jury may find against him.

abstract: -- The city rang yesterday with the praises of SHERIDAN. They were recited in prose and chanted in verse. SHERIDAN's doings, SHERIDAN's sayings, SHERIDAN's "style," were all the rage. He is deserving of all the praise that is given him. The way in which he "wrested victory from the jaws of defeat;" the way in which he repulsed assault; the way in which he assaulted; the style of victory he won; the number of famous victories he has achieved in one short month -- all mark him as worthy of the remarkable eulogium of the Lieutenant-General, in styling him "one of the ablest of Generals." NAPOLEON used to do such things as SHERIDAN has been doing during the past four weeks.

abstract: At the regular meeting of the Polytechnic Club, at the Cooper Institute, last Thursday evening -- an association of scientific and literary gentlemen -- among other subjects, involving the progress in art, science and commerce, that of the Hermetical Barrel of Mr. ROBBINS was brought up for discussion. While its great advantages as a commercial package generally were clearly demonstrated, its superiority to all other packages for the transmission of the great staple of the day, petroleum, was fully conceded. The deductions drawn by the inventor from the chemical laws of vegetation, and applied to his ingenious invention, as well as other analogies in nature, were most entertaining and instructive. The laws of chemical affinity and antagonism are so practically appropriated and applied in the preparation of the wood of the Hermetieal Barrel, that it was clearly apparent to the minds of all present, that it was simply impossible for a fluid, even so subtle and permeating as petroleum, to penetrate through them.

abstract: On Friday afternoon the Chamber of Commerce held a special meeting with reference to the death of JOSHUA BATES, the American member of the firm of BARING & BROTHERS, London. The call for the meeting was read when A.A. LOW, Esq., presiding, addressed the Chamber, making reference to the high character the firm of BARING & BROTHERS bore at home and abroad, and to the long, honorable, and useful connection of Mr. BATES with it. He made handsome reference to the loyalty and patriotism of deceased during the present struggle, and deemed it eminently proper that some action should be taken on his death.
