abstract: Brittan's Man and his Relations; Fern, Fanny; New Story Book for Children; Browning's Dramatis Personae; Trial, The; More Links of the Daisy Chain
snippet: Brittan's Man and his Relations; Fern, Fanny; New Story Book for Children; Browning's Dramatis Personae; Trial, The; More Links of the Daisy Chain
lead_paragraph: The warmth or devotion manifested by a sect, either in literature or religion, is generally in an inverse ratio to its size, and there exist, undoubtedly, the Intelligent few to whom a new volume of ROBERT BROWNING will prove a dearer possession -- a choicer treasure than even the similar present recently offered us by TENNY- SON. The two poets are contemporaries, and started on the race for fame at a nearly corresponding period of their youth. BROWNING's first poem, Paracelsus was given to the world in 1835, when he was in his twenty-third year, and so natural to him is the mode of expression adopted in his poetry, that succeeding years have done little to deepen the characteristics, or bring into more prominent relief the idiosyncrasies exhibited in his first work. In one respect the fortunes of the poets have been different, while half the writing world (especially the more juvenile portion of it) are weighing their syllables and measuring their versification, in the vain hope of reproducing the magic flow of TENNYSON's heroic metre, or the wild and airy charm of his lyrics -- BROWNING can scarcely be said to have found a single imitator. Though the style of no other writer presents so many obvious peculiarities, they are not for every one's use. His involved and cumbrous sentences are double-shotted with knowledge, reflection and poetical insight. Wanting these, the imitation would be mere blank cartridge, scarcely a passable echo of the original. BROWNING's range has been a wider one than that of TENNYSON. Narrative poems, dramas, (three of which have met with favor on the stage,) lyrics, and pieces that come within no recognized arrangement, have all flowed freely from his pen, and attest a breadth, and variety of power that has left undying traces in the minds of his readers, and has affected, in a manner we are yet too near to estimate, the national poetical literature of the age. It is a shallow aspiration that would desire to see the excellencies of BROWNING, cleared of his eccentricities and open to the current comprehension of all. The poet is homogeneous, and his radiancies and obscurities are all cognate in their origin. In much of his writings, ROBERT BROWNING is less a poet than a "subtle souled psychologist," flinging himself with all the resources of vast learning and creative art into attempts to reconstruct the mental processes of personages the most remote from ordinary comprehension or sympathy. Such are in the present volume --"Caliban upon Setebos, or Natural Theology in the Island," "A Death in the Desert," "Mr. Sludge, the Medium," and the greater part of his previous collection, Men and Women. Success in this field is not for the plaudits of ordinary readers; for them each poem wants a commentary, and is scarcely intelligible without. We do not believe that there are twenty people in New-York -- and are not sure that there is one -- who could at the first reading understand the drift of the author in the poem, "A Death in the Desert," or make out the machinery by which it is introduced, and apportion to each of the characters his share of the narration. Though nothing can be finer than the conception, or more vividly touched in single lines and epithets than the situation. Its subject is the aged apostle St. John dying in the desert, tended lovingly by disciples in the cool of a cave, and uttering a protest against the heresies of the time, while a wild Bactrian convert keeps watch, where "outside was all noon, and the burning blue." An author who designedly adopts this abstruse form for the communication of his ideas must necessarily be ready to relinquish the suffrages of the many; but there are indications in "Dramatis Personae" of a capacity for clearer things, where the poet permits himself expression in his own person, instead of vivifying with strange speech the dusky spectres of past ages and remote countries. Some of the shorter poems are admirable is conciseness and strength, and are written in such excellent English as must disgust the painful students of the original Browningese dialect; and make them fear that their oracle is gradually coming down to the vernacular. That a really great poet may in time work himself clear of many willful obscurities, and so become more appreciated by the mass of readers is sincerely to be hoped. We give a short poem, severe in its simplicity, that all will appreciate, and which derives additional interest when the writer's relation to the highest woman's intellect of the century -- his lately lost wife -- is considered, alluded to at the end --

abstract: Mr. BENJAMIN FITCH, whose generosity in behalf of the soldiers seems to be inexhaustible, has lately started on a voyage to Europe for the benefit of his health. Before leaving, he presented to the "Home" founded by him at Darien, Conn., a further sum of $5,000 for the establishment of a school for destitute children of soldiers.

abstract: Capt. MILLS, of the Second Police Precinct, has been transferred to the Eighth Precinct, and Capt. DE CAMP, of the Eighth, to the Second. Capt. MILLS' command in the Second has been characterized by the utmost energy and fidelity; he has worked many valuable reforms, and leaves the precinct in a most orderly, safe and creditable condition. He leaves the Second with the good wishes of those resident and those doing business in it. Capt. DE CAMP has had in the English one of the worst, if not the worst, precincts in the city, the resort, in portions of it, of outlaws, thieves and vagabonds of high and low degree. He has had much to contend with and hard duty to perform, but has succeeded in bringing about a very different state of affairs than such as existed when he took command. He will transfer his ability and faithfulness to the Second, where both will soon be as gratifyingly recognized as they were in the Eighth.

abstract: Union and Abol. Slavery; a Subordinate Question to Union
snippet: Union and Abol. Slavery; a Subordinate Question to Union
lead_paragraph: A cotemporary intimates that the subject of slavery is entirely indifferent to the Union party, because not much is said of it in this canvass. There could not be a greater mistake. The course of the Union party from its origin as the Republican party in 1856, when it declared "Polygamy and Slavery the twin sisters of Barbarism;" during the canvass of 1860, when it established its protest against the extension of Slavery; through the immortal legislation of the years 1860-1864, whereby slavery was practically stricken down forever as a political power, and culminating in the Platform of 1864, which will be a Bill of Rights for humanity during many centuries to come, has been most honorable, and will win the everlasting gratitude of posterity. The Union party needs no explanation or defence in its most clear position on the subject of this great national evil.

abstract: I closed my letter to the TIMES last evening while the excitement here in regard to the rebel raid into Northern Vermont was but little past its highest point. A company composed of the citizens of Montpelier, and members of the Legislature, had marched to the railroad depot, and were about to take the cars, but the order for their departure had been countermanded on the reception of additional intelligence.

abstract: McClellan; Electioneering for
snippet: McClellan; Electioneering for
lead_paragraph: -- A while ago the rebels sent JUBAL EARLY, as they proclaimed, to "stump Pennsylvania against LINCOLN." EARLY failed to come up to time. He unfortunately had a sudden attack of the draptomania, a disease which impels men to run away, and which the learned Dr. CARTWRIGHT, of New-Orleans, in his famous treatise, laid down as contagious, yet confined to the black race. In this last particular the Doctor was mistaken. It has lately struck the white race of the South, and has become prevalent. JUBAL was taken one fine morning, and so did not stump it. The generals, not being able to canvass for MCCLELLAN on our ground, the shift now is to make the jailers do it on Southern ground. Sick Pennsylvania soldiers, lately returned from Dixie, testify that offers of permission to return North have been made to sick soldiers on condition that they would vote for MCCLELLAN. A soldier in Montgomery County, who was taken prisoner last March, deposes on oath, that being sick in the General Hospital No. 21, in Richmond, he was waited upon by the director of the hospital, and was told that he would be allowed to return home "if he would promise to vote for GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN at the approaching election," and that "all the prisoners of said hospital who promptly and positively said that they would vote for ABRAHAM LINCOLN, were not paroled, but remained in said hospital."

abstract: Taeping Rebellion; The End of
snippet: Taeping Rebellion; The End of
lead_paragraph: The Taeping rebellion in China is virtually at an end. Nankin, its capital, and the ancient capital of China, has been taken by the Imperialists, the rebel King has committed suicide, the bravest of the rebel chiefs have been slain or made prisoners, the remains of the rebel forces are no longer an army, but a fugitive, panic-stricken mob, without leaders capable of reorganizing them, and without spirit to renew the conflict.

abstract: Captures of Artillery and Arms
snippet: Captures of Artillery and Arms
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERIDAN telegraphs that he pursued the flying rebels nearly to Mt. Jackson, and that the evidences of an entire rout were complete on every hand. The rebels took twenty-four pieces of artillery from us early in the morning, but SHERIDAN not only retook them, but added twenty-four more to them, and they are now at his headquarters. The Valley is strewn with arms and equipments thrown away by the enemy, and not less than three hundred wagons have been captured or destroyed.

lead_paragraph: This brave officer, who fell in the battle of Cedar Creek, commanded, by virtue of his rank, a whole division in the Kanawha Army Corps, under the impetuous CROOK. He entered the service as Colonel of the Third Western Virginia Infantry, and through nearly all the arduous campaigns of that department he has held a brigade, and many a time, by his valor in battle, has won the star which has never yet glistened upon his shoulders. Hisreward now is a laurel wreath on his victorious brows. His memory will be enshrined in the hearts of a grateful people.

abstract: -The Monongahela Republican contains the following: "Parties engaged in exhuming the bodies of the MERCER family for removal from the old graveyard to Monongahela City Cemetery on Friday last, found the body of Mr. J.B. MERCER in a singular state of petrifaction. The graves of Mrs. MERCER and the two children on each side were about sixteen inches lower than that of their father, yet while their bodies had returned to dust and were perfectly dry, his grave was filled with water, and his body turned to stone. Mr. MERCER was drowned in May, 1843, at what is called the old wharf, and his body, remaining in the river for eighteen days, was found on the 'riffle' near Parkinson's; he was forty-five years of age, and was buried on the hill in the above described grave. Through the kindness of Mr. FILSON we were permitted to examine the body closely. It was solid and firm, turned to stone, from the ankle joints to the neck; the feet had fallen off and were mouldered to dust, but the head, which had also fallen off, was petrified, and the hair well preserved. The body was solid, and upon being struck, gave out a dead heavy sound; the petrification was so perfect that the pores of the skin were distinct, and the proportions of the form well preserved. This has been attributed by many to the length of time the body remained in the water before interment. As petrification is never caused by internal action, but is always the result of external deposites and surroundings, this theory cannot explain the circumstances fully. The bodies of the family were reinterred in the Monongahela Cemetery by the M.E. Church of this city, and a handsome marble shaft placed above their graves by that congregation, to which, it will be remembered, Mrs. AGATHA MERCER bequeathed some $1,000 at her decease."

abstract: Italian Convention and Negotiations
snippet: Italian Convention and Negotiations
lead_paragraph: The European journals have arrived at the most opposite conclusions touching the objects and probable effects of this new and remarkable treaty, and yet its terms do not afford much scope for doubt. The FrancoItalian convention, the text of which has recently appeared in the Moniteur and in our own columns, is evidently a compromise. The French Emperor, on certain conditions, agrees to withdraw his garrison from Rome within a fixed period, and the Italian King, in order to rid Italy of these foreign troops, assents to the conditions specified. He promises to remove his Court and Government to Florence in six months from the date of the convention; he undertakes the liquidation of that portion of the Papal debt which belongs to those States of the Church lately annexed to his Kingdom; and he binds himself to protect the "Patrimony of St. Peter" from all external aggression.

abstract: Since the attack upon our rear while falling back from Harrisonsburgh to Strasburgh, there has been no regular fighting. abstract: Applauding Rebel Invasion of North
snippet: Applauding Rebel Invasion of North
lead_paragraph: -In every possible way, and on every possible occasion, the Copperhead faction are exhibiting their total and shameless want of anything like patriotism. Thus the Express, of this city, opens an article upon the murderous raid of rebels into Vermont from Canada, in this delightful style: "That New-England should thus be made to feel a slight touch of the horrors of war, and to have commended to her own lips the poisoned chalice, of which Pennsylvania and other portions of the North, territorially contiguous to the rebellion, have been obliged occasionally to quaff, naturally enough excites the most intense disgust, on the part of the New-England edited (Administration) presses of this city." Only the other day, the News expressed its satisfaction with the proposed policy of the rebels of arming their black slaves for the invasion of the North, and now we have the above in reference to the rebel raiders. These Copperheads would undoubtedly welcome foreign intervention in our affairs, and would cheer a foreign army if it landed on our soil. They ought to be ashamed of themselves.

abstract: Abduction Case of Seagrist, a Gymnast
snippet: Abduction Case of Seagrist, a Gymnast
lead_paragraph: The hearing in the case of Senorita ECKHARD, arrested in Washington, and brought hither, on a charge of abducting GEORGE W. SEAGRIST, a boy gympast, came up, yesterday, before Justice DOWLING. The evidence showed that some four years ago Senorita ECKHARD took the boy from the Almshouse at Soffulk County, Mass. After keeping him a while the married, whereupon she returned the boy to his old quarters. Subsequently the Senorita informed NICHOLAS SEAGRIST, of the SEAGRIST BROTHERS, gymnasts, of the boy, represented him as smart and active, us likely to make, when instructed, a valuable addition to the troupe. SEAGRIST took him, securing indenture papers, some two years ago. The child was abducted Oct. 6. The Senorita gave as her reason that the child had been abused. Justice DOWLING remanded the Senorita and the lad to the City Prison until Monday, when a further examination will be had and a decision given. The lad appears much attached to the Senorita, and looks forward with manifest dread to a separation from her.

abstract: Whig Advises Burning Cities; Burning Cities Suggested by Richmond Whig
snippet: Whig Advises Burning Cities; Burning Cities Suggested by Richmond Whig
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Whig proposes that the rebel Government shall employ secret emissaries to set fire to the principal cities of the North. Bands of their ruffians seem to be already engaged on the Canadian frontier in robbery and murder. There are one or two other little expedients for bringing the North to terms which the Whig seems to have overlooked, but which we do not object to mentioning. One is, the poisoning of reservoirs and wells. There are plenty of cutthroats who can be hired to do jobs of this kind all over the North, and the matter ought to be brought under the notice of the rebel Senate at that secret session which the Whig recommends for the consideration of the town-burning project. The subject is one well fitted for the deliberations of such an august body. The poisoning scheme has many advantages over the other. Hecatombs of "Yankees" might be killed in this way at a very small expense to the Confederacy. We think an appropriation of $10,000 in Confederate paper would probably cover the whole cost.

abstract: The classes of the Cooper Union for 1864-5 were recently opened to the public; and it is a gratifying evidence of the increasing desire for education among working people that the number of applications for admission was largely in excess of previous years. Last Year 1,281 pupils were admitted ...
lead_paragraph: The classes of the Cooper Union for 1864-5 were recently opened to the public; and it is a gratifying evidence of the increasing desire for education among working people that the number of applications for admission was largely in excess of previous years. Last Year 1,281 pupils were admitted to the free night classes; this year the number is 1,557. In addition to these, there were 159 applications for admission to the free school of art for females, and 105 to the free chorister class -- making the total number of applications to all the classes of the Union, 1,821.

abstract: -The Southern Confederacy will soon be short of hardware if SHERIDAN remains in active business. His dispatch, published yesterday, says that fifty pieces of artillery were captured on Wednesday; but as this includes twenty of our own guns, which had fallen into the hands of the enemy in the early part of the day, it makes our actual gain thirty. Add to these the other thirty-five pieces he had captured from EARLY in the three preceding battles of the campaign, and it reduces the rebel artillery by sixty-five guns. Beside this hardware proper, he has taken between twenty and thirty caissons, and, it is estimated, over 12,000 small arms, in his month's campaign. Of articles seized by SHERIDAN that perhaps cannot be strictly classified as hardware, (to wit, rebel soldiers,) we shall soon know from SHERIDAN himself how near they are to ten thousand in number.

lead_paragraph: The loyal citizens of the town of West Farms, attempted to hold an outdoor meeting in the village of Fordham, on Monday evening, of this week. Able speakers and a fine glee club were in attendance. The presiding officer called the meeting to order within sight of the residence of Hon. JOHN B. HASKINS, whose influence as a retired national lawmaker, might be supposed to be wholesome among his neighbors; within sight also of the Catholic Theological Seminary, generally supposed to inculcate obedience to authority, if not to law.

abstract: -- It is to be hoped that the matter of properly warming and ventilating our public schools will receive attention from the proper authorities before the cold weather sets in. The deficiencies as to both have been a cause of serious complaint. The School Committee of the Citizens' Association call attention to the matter and say, in regard to the warming, that in many schools the so-called warming apparatus is a disgrace to civilization and humanity. Take the school No. 99 Greenwich-street, where the thermometer could not be made to show a temperature above forty degrees till 1 or 2 o'clock P.M. all last Winter, and where the teachers and scholars were constantly shivering, taking cold, and laving the foundation of fatal disease. In another school built in Forty-second-street, the teachers and scholars were compelled to keep on shawls, and cloaks through school hours, to preserve themselves from freezing. So of several other schools. And in numerous cases no provision is made to enable the attendants to dry and warm their feet on coming in from wet and snowy pavements. Such schools are mere death-traps to the attendants.

abstract: Churches Outspoken for and for War; Religious Element of Country Strongest for War
snippet: Churches Outspoken for and for War; Religious Element of Country Strongest for War
lead_paragraph: It is a most significant thing that the religious and moral element of the nation is precisely the element which is strongest for war. The fact is indisputable. It is not only manifest to every man within his own sphere of observation, but it has its official proof in the emphatic resolutions, approving the war, which have been adopted by nearly every great ecclesiastical organization, with entire, or almost entire, unanimity. It found an irrepressible utterance in the annual meeting of the American Board of Foreign Missions, the other day, in Worcester, the largest religious association in America, when this fact being announced that out of more than one thousand missionaries abroad there was not one who was not sustaining the cause of national unity and human freedom, with sympathy and prayer, the great gathering of four thousand clergymen and laymen from all parts of the North, united to a man in a regular vote that the Government must be sustained and the rebellion crushed. There are about one hundred and fifty religious newspapers in the loyal States. Nine out of ten of them are outspoken for LINCOLN. There are about twenty-five thousand clergymen in the loyal States; of this number there are probably not five hundred who are not for the reelection of our President. Of course, an absolute unanimity, with human nature as it is, must be impossible. There are some minds so curiously made up that even the grace of God cannot prevent their sticking, limpet-like, to the past. There were Tory clergymen in the revolution -- and godly men too. There were bishops in England who clung to the slave-trade to the last, and who, on the episcopal bench in Parliament, voted against WILBERFORCE's resolution, that the slave trade was "inconsistent with justice, humanity and sound policy." There are ministers of the gospel, and even doctors of divinity, here in the North, who worship slavery even after it is dead, as the priests of of Isis did their sacred crocodile. Such exceptions are always sure to exist, but the anomaly is rather mental than moral. It has little moral consequence. The fact still stands, that the whole force of the religious and moral sentiment of the country is on the side of the Baltimore platform, and against that of Chicago.

abstract: -- The Richmond Sentinel expresses the utmost satisfaction that the "home vote" in Pennsylvania has "gone for the Democrats by some thousands." It likewise rejoices that this political victory cannot be reversed by the soldiers' vote, since the election commissioners found it impossible to communicate with more than a section of the army. This Richmond rebel has penetration enough to see that an anti-administration vote in the loyal States has within it the essential elements of a Confederate victory. He has sense enough to see, also, that the Union soldiers, where they have the opportunity of voting, will not give their support to a party which declares the war a failure. It is of the greatest consequence, indeed, to JEFF. DAVIS and his cause, that no army vote whatever shall be taken. And hence the importance which the rebel organ attaches to the assumed fact that MOSBY's guerrillas prevented the vote of SHERIDAN's force from being recorded, thereby -- as it fancies -- preserving Pennsylvania to the rebel allies.

abstract: and the Recent Victory
snippet: and the Recent Victory
lead_paragraph: The very suggestive letter we quoted on Friday from the Richmond Examiner of the 17th, fully justifies all we have said of the respective merits of the rebel cavalry and our own. The truth evidently is that the rebel horsemen have become a band of roving thieves and guerrillas, have lost discipline and organization, and are no sort of match for the splendid body of hardy, disciplined and well-armed cavalry which TORBERT and CUSTAR command. In the battle of Wednesday last they did not even bring any cavalry into action, though they might have proved of very great service to them. They were, doubtless, so used up by the drubbing administered to them a fortnight before, as to be incapable of making an appearance. On the other hand, the triumph of our arms, which was really achieved by one man's genius and resolution, was greatly aided by decisive charges in flank by the splendid cavalry which SHERIDAN commands; and after the decision of the battle our horse pursued the enemy with great energy. The rebels have nothing, as the Examiner admits, which can now stand against them.
headline: {'main': 'The Cavalry and Our Recent Victory.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Cavalry and Our Recent Victory.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: MILITARY FUNERALS. The remains of Capt. JOHN W. SWIFT, late of the One Hundred and Thirtyninth Regiment New-York Volunteers, were yesterconsigned to their last resting place in Greenwood cemetery. The religious ceremonies were held in the Fleet-street Methodist Church, which was filled with relatives and sympathizing friends, together with members of the Forty-seventh Regiment N. Y. V., and John D. Willard Lodge F.  A.M., to which deceased had formerly been attached.
lead_paragraph: MILITARY FUNERALS. -- The remains of Capt. JOHN W. SWIFT, late of the One Hundred and Thirtyninth Regiment New-York Volunteers, were yesterconsigned to their last resting place in Greenwood cemetery. The religious ceremonies were held in the Fleet-street Methodist Church, which was filled with relatives and sympathizing friends, together with members of the Forty-seventh Regiment N. Y. V., and John D. Willard Lodge F. A.M., to which deceased had formerly been attached. A company of the Fifty-second Regiment National Guard escorted the remains to the grave. Capt. SWIFT died in hospital at Bermuda, Va., on the 1st inst., from wounds received in the assault upon the enemy's works at Chapin's Farm, Sept. 29. The body of private SAMUEL J. LUSK, of Company D, Fourteenth Regiment N.Y.S.M., was also conveyed to Greenwood Cemetery, and consigned to its last resting-place. The funeral ceremonies were held at the house of his mother, No. 377 Carlton-avenue. A large number of persons were present, including Franklin Engine Company No. 3, of which deceased had formerly been a member. The remains were escorted to the cemetery by a company of the Fourteenth Regiment. The deceased was killed in front of Petersburgh, on the 28th of June last.

abstract: German Emigration to America
snippet: German Emigration to America
lead_paragraph: For many years the Governments of the German States have looked with apprehension on the steadily increasing exodus of their laboring classes to America. They have long foreseen that a movement which, at first was felt as a relief to an over-populated country, would eventually become an exhausting drain upon their military resources. Yet they were powerless to check the movement. Summary laws against emigration would have provoked revolution at once; and in spite of numberless restrictions and vexatious regulations, designed to throw obstructions in the way of the emigrant, and to make leaving the country as difficult as possible, the stream of emigration grew in volume from year to year. In vain the Government employed newspapers and book-makers to depict the horrors of American society, and the dreadful fate that awaited the too-confiding wanderer who trusted his life among the wilds, the beasts and savages of the Western world. Some of these attempts were exquisitely ludicrous; and had they been credited, no German who valued his life a penny would ever have ventured to set foot in such a land of horrors as America was represented to be.
headline: {'main': 'German Emigration to America.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'German Emigration to America.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner WILDEY on the body of JOHN H. MASS, a boy aged 13 years, residing at No. 29 West Tenth-street, who was run over and almost instantly killed by car No. 121 of the Seventh-avenue line, on Saturday evening. The deceased was riding on the front platform, and when in Thompson-street, near Amity, he either fell or jumped off, and a wheel passed over his breast. The jury rendered a verdict of accidental death.

abstract: No official intelligence from the field has been received since the dispatch from Secretary STANTON, dated Saturday, the 22d. Gen. SHERIDAN announces that he pursued the dying rebels nearly to Mt. Jackson, and that the evidences of an entire rout were complete on every hand. The rebels took twenty-four pieces of artillery from us early in the morning, but SHERIDAN not only retook them, but added twenty-four more to them, and they are now at his  headquarters. The Valley is strewn with arms and equipments thrown away by the enemy, and not less than three hundred wagons have been captured or destroyed.
lead_paragraph: No official intelligence from the field has been received since the dispatch from Secretary STANTON, dated Saturday, the 22d. Gen. The Valley is strewn with arms and equipments thrown away by the enemy, and not less than three hundred wagons have been captured or destroyed.

abstract: A singularly effective performance of DONIZETTI's opera of "Il Poliuto" was given at the Academy of Music on Friday evening. The work has always been a favorite with our public, and at one time (when Mmme. CORTESI was here,) excited a genuine furore. It deserves the same fate now, for the singers are as good as they ever were, and so far as the prima donna is concerned, Signora ZUCCHI will certainly compare favorably with any of her predecessors. The earnestness and intelligent freedom of her rendering of the difficult role of Pauline are in fact perfect. The enthusiasm of the audience was absolute, and manifested itself in tumu[???]tuous and almost frenzied outbursts of applause. The extraordinary vigor of the representation has become a matter of town talk, and had it taken place in any European opera house, there cannot be a doubt that "Il Poliuto" would again renew its early triumphs. There are few works in the repertoire whose saliencies in the way of melody are more grateful. The plot, too, is simple and affecting, lending itself readily to situations of great emotional interest, and to s[???]enes where a brilliant display of numbers and costumes is not superfluous. Long before the opera found its way to our stage, the choruses were known to our musical societies, and thoroughly appreciated. They are extremely interesting, and are superbly interpreted by Mr. MARETZEK's forces. The entire performance, indeed, was all that could be desired. Signor MASSIMILIANI has never been heard to such decided advantage as in the role of Poliutus, and Signor BELLINI, although a little hoarse at the beginning of the evening, rapidly recovered himself and sang with his customary excellence. We look forward with much pleasure to the repetition of this opera to-morrow night.

abstract: Food Question in; Richmond Sentinel Gratified by
snippet: Food Question in; Richmond Sentinel Gratified by
lead_paragraph: It is important that we should analyze with great care the evidence of Southern journals touching the question of supplies. They have frequently good reason for seeking to deceive the outside world on this point, beyond all others. In a singular article, however, which we reproduce to-day from the Richmond Sentinel, we find a series of admissions which go far to prove that there is, at this moment, something approaching to actual famine in both Richmond and Petersburgh. The journalist endeavors to condemn, with as much earnestness as he can command, the absolute military law which requires that the provision markets shall be under military control; that the army must be fed first, and the people second. He puts the point with logical impressiveness, as well as with pathetic earnestness, when he says: "It is contended that the army must be first fed; but yet it is evident that all must be fed." Nothing, surely, can be clearer than this -- if there is to be any but a military population left in Richmond and Petersburgh, "all must be fed." It seems, however, by the rebel reasoning, that the effect of giving the military this right of preemption over the populace is, that only the rich portion of the latter get anything like a regular supply. And this they get solely by setting the military law at defiance. "Men must eat," observes this practical philosopher. Hence, if private consumers cannot get a wagon for transportation purposes, they will find a mule-cart. If they are forbidden the railroads, "the wits of the ingenious are thereby but quickened for evading the prohibition, and it is evaded." Moreover, he takes heart of grace, to tell the Military authorities that, after all they have done to cheat the common people of their grub, and "after all they can do, the agents of the Government cannot avoid dividing the food of the country with the non-producers."

abstract: Progress of
snippet: Progress of
lead_paragraph: our own correspondent, respecting the progress of the Federation scheme. It seems to us that the whole project, if it can be got into a workable shape, will be of an exceedingly Conservative, if not Tory, character. A Governor-General or Viceroy, nominated by the Crown; four Lieutenant-Governors for the two Canadas, Acadia and Newfoundland, nominated by the Viceroy; a general Parliament, with 200 elected members in the lower branch, sitting five years, and 76 nominated or Crown members in the Upper House, retaining their seats for life, a system of ministerial responsibility similar to that of the mother country. Such are the leading features of the proposed Colonial Union. We have before pointed out in these columns that a fixed number of "Lords" in the second branch of the Legislature cannot possibly work without bringing the two Houses sooner or later, into collision. The rate at which changes could be introduced in such a House, as it is proposed to make this legislative council, would probably not exceed two members a year. Vacancies by death, on the average, would probably be represented by this number. And that would be all the safety-valve the Constitution would furnish. Upper Canada, we see, is to be well represented in the Lower House of the Federal Legislature, so that she will have no longer reason to complain that one-third of the people have practically had no representation in the Provincial Parliament.

abstract: -- In order to insure to New-York soldiers the right of voting by proxy at the coming election, the Postmaster-General has issued an order directing the Postmasters generally throughout the State to see that the envelopes containing the ballots are delivered with the utmost dispatch. If these are not taken out of the office on the day of receipt, the Postmaster is ordered to find out the person to whom they are addressed, so that he may call for them without delay.

abstract: Prisoners Under Fire at Dutch Gap
snippet: Prisoners Under Fire at Dutch Gap
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. BUTLER's latest application of the law of retaliation has been followed by practical and satisfactory results. Gen. LEE had a number of negro troops, that had fallen into his hands as prisoners of war, put to work in the trenches near Fort Gilmer. Gen. BUTLER made his Provost-Marshal take evidence as to the facts, and on finding them proven, he at once ordered a number of rebel soldiers to be put to work on the Dutch Gap Canal, within range of the rebel fire. The expedient worked like a charm. LEE has released the negroes from the trenches at Fort Gilmer, BUTLER has released the rebels at Dutch Gap. We presume the dignity of the Confederacy is sustained.

abstract: -- There is a fine dash of variety to-day again in the news we get from Mexico. Sometimes, no doubt, there is a slight sacrifice of what may be called strict accuracy to picturesqueness of effect. But the variety is there. A few weeks ago Gen. CORTINAS, commanding the Republican forces on the Rio GRANDE, was in Texas, had captured Brownsville, raised the American flag on the ramparts, and promised well to lend a stout hand to us in closing up the rebellion in this country. He didn't do any of these things, as it afterward turned out, although he may have intended to do them all. Now, to-day comes a report of CORTINAS, which may be equally one of anticipation. We are told by way of New-Orleans that CORTINAS has surrendered to the French, and become a Brigadier-General in MAXIMILIAN's army. We should have expected that a Major-General-ship would have rewarded such service.

abstract: treal Witness, an able and intelligent friend of free government on both sides of the line, in speaking of the rebel raid into Vermont, remarks that it is the aim of the rebels operating in Canada, to involve Canada, and through her Great Britain, in a war on behalf of their Southern friends. We have no doubt that this statement is made with a knowl- ...
lead_paragraph: -- The Montreal Witness, an able and intelligent friend of free government on both sides of the line, in speaking of the rebel raid into Vermont, remarks that it is the aim of the rebels operating in Canada, to involve Canada, and through her Great Britain, in a war on behalf of their Southern friends. We have no doubt that this statement is made with a knowledge of the facts, and we have no doubt of its truth. JEFF. DAVIS said in one of his late Georgia speeches that there was now no prospect of foreign intervention in behalf of the South; and as things have lately stood, that is perfectly correct. Nevertheless, if he could succeed in producing such embroilments as that of last week along our Northern border, there is no telling what would speedily be the result.

abstract: Reception in New-York
snippet: Reception in New-York
lead_paragraph: Gov. MORTON had a splendid reception from as many of the Union citizens of New-York as could get into Cooper Institute on Saturday evening last. The hall was crowded to its utmost capacity, and the Governor was received with the utmost enthusiasm. His speech, which was stenogrphicaly reported in our issue of yesterday morning, was worthy of his reputation -- clear, strong, and argumentative. It was an admirable presentation of the whole subject at issue in the Presidential canvass. Its exposition of the Chicago platform, and its exposition of the essential treason which lurks under the proposition for a cessation of hostilities, were especially cogent and convincing.

abstract: Or War; The Controlling Issue
snippet: Or War; The Controlling Issue
lead_paragraph: The Copperhead managers have labored more or less from the beginning to keep the real issue of peace or war with the rebels in the background, and to engross the public mind with bugbears of their own creation, or with personal defamation of President LINCOLN, or with questions of no vital account one way or the other. It is curious to observe how difficult they find the work. If they start a bugbear like that of "miscegenation," for instance, it subjects them to such derision that they are quickly glad enough to get clear of it. If they concoct a calumny against Mr. LINCOLN, like that of his demanding his salary in gold, it is exposed, and they only get contempt for it. If they try to take issue on any of the incidentals of the war, as, for instance, bad management in the field, or the enlisting of colored soldiers, or the system of conscription, or the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus, or the making of paper money legal tender, they get no substantial benefit from any of them. They soon tire of each as bootless, and then desperately fill its place with a new one.

abstract: Gen. BLUNT has been stubbornly resisting the advance of Gen. PRICE all day. BLUNT is falling back slowly, contesting every rod of ground as he retires. The force at PRICE is estimated at 28,000 men. Gen. CURTIS is concentrating his forces on the Little Blue River. Gov. CARNEY has telegraphed that the danger is very great, and to send every available man to the front. Troops are going forward rapidly.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad. I made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader: and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. FLOTOW'S opera of "Martha," in whatever language it may be presented, returns always pleasurably to its permanent place in the public affections. It holds its own with a rare tenacity. The story, perhaps, has much to do with this. It is lively, somewhat piquant, and illustrated by a quartette of nicely-balanced characters...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- FLOTOW's opera of "Martha," in whatever language it may be presented, returns always pleasurably to its permanent place in the public affections. It holds its own with a rare tenacity. The story, perhaps, has much to do with this. It is lively, somewhat piquant, and illustrated by a quartette of nicely-balanced characters who reflect many moods of musical sensibility, and give Herr VON FLOTOW a corresponding number of opportunities for displaying the felicity of his invention, The latter is never overtasked, and hence "Martha," with many peculiar merits in the way of instrumentation, is never overstrained in the matter of melody. Beginning with the airiest of court-embroidered coquetry, there is in the later parts a good, stout, honest texture of domestic earnestness, and the two, deftly interwoven, form an article that is at once elegant and comfortable. As Le Follet might say: "The opera is a specimen of fine needlework and good taste."

abstract: -- If we interpret aright the item of news received from Bermuda by way of Halifax, it would seem reasonable to expect that the British authorities may in time become tired of their Confederate friends. The pirate BRAINE and his companions, who repeated the tragedy of the Chesapeake in a milder form on board the Havana steamer Roanoke, have been put on trial, and the Bermuda court has refused to bail them. Fourteen of the bank robbers who profess to hold commissions from Richmond to invade Vermont by way of Canada, are also in jail at St. John's, in Lower Canada, with some prospect of their being brought to trial, not as Confederate soldiers, but as common thieves and murderers. These are signs of improvement in British Colonial life.
lead_paragraph: -- If we interpret aright the item of news received from Bermuda by way of Halifax, it would seem reasonable to expect that the British authorities may in time become tired of their Confederate friends. abstract: and Mayor Gunther; and City Inspector Boole
snippet: and Mayor Gunther; and City Inspector Boole
lead_paragraph: The Mayor has suspended Mr. Inspector BOOLE from office. That is, he has suspended him as far as the City Charter and various amendments thereto will permit. The Mayor contends that the Charter of 1857 gives him the amplest power of suspension. Mr. BOOLE and his friends contend otherwise. They say that the amendment act of 1863 provides that Heads of certain Departments -- among which the City Inspector's Department -- shall only be subject to removal under conditions which are not embraced in the Mayor's lists of causes. Between these interpreters of the Charter and its amendments, Mr. Solicitor WHITING appears and says that the Mayor has the power of suspending Heads of Departments, but not of removing them. If Mr. WHITING is right in this interpretation of the law, the Mayor's power of suspension is sustained.

There were a goodly number present, including a number of Democrats who did not like the Chicago platform, but had not yet made up their minds to vote for LINCOLN and...
lead_paragraph: The War Democracy of the east side of the town met at Botanic Hall, No. 68 East Broadway, Saturday evening, H. C. PAGE, Esq., Chairman of the General Committee, presiding. There were a goodly number present, including a number of Democrats who did not like the Chicago platform, but had not yet made up their minds to vote for LINCOLN and JOHNSON, because they had belonged to their party so long. Before they left, however, very many of them, from the rays of Union light afforded them by the speakers, were ready to shout for the Union nominees.

abstract: The steamship New-York, from Southampton Oct. 12, arrived at this port yesterday. The Belgian, from Liverpool on the 13th, via Queenstown Oct. 14, arrived off Father Point yesterday. The news by these arrivals is five days later. The most portant item is the reported departure of Capt. SEMMES, the notorious pirate, from Liverpool, with eight officers and one hundred men, for Madeira, there to man the steamer Ranger, which has been lying there some time. The United States steam frigate Niagara had arrived off Shereham with a Spanish steamer, seized under suspicion of being a blockade-runner. The ship Southern Rights, of Richmond, Me., was captured Aug. 22, by the pirate Florida, and released under bonds. The commercial depression in England still continued, and more failures were reported. Uneasiness was also felt in French commercial circles. The Confederate loan was quoted at 55.

abstract: Transcendant Issue, the
snippet: Transcendant Issue, the
lead_paragraph: The great decision is to be made two weeks from to-day. The fate of the American Union will then be settled. It is almost impossible to realize that an issue of such tremendous moment is so close upon us, and dependent upon the little act of dropping one bit of paper into the ballot-box rather than another. We naturally associate the settlement of the destiny of a great nation with mighty convulsions, or with the long operation of some silent influence. It is something new that it should turn on so simple and brief an act as casting votes, between the rising and the setting of the sun.
headline: {'main': 'The Transcendent Issue.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Transcendent Issue.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Labeulaye, M., on the American Crisis
snippet: Labeulaye, M., on the American Crisis
lead_paragraph: The distinguished French professor and political philosopher, M. EDOUARD LABOULAYE, who, by his lectures in Paris on our Constitution and form of Government, has shown his thorough knowledge of the American system, and who, moreover, during this whole struggle, has exhibited the warmest interest in our success, has written a letter containing his views at length on the bearings of the forthcoming Presidential election. He opens by remarking that "there are critical moments in the life of nations, when the course that is taken decides their future; the greatness and liberty of the nation are at stake; an instant of weakness and all is lost; an instant of energy, a last effort, and all is saved. It is in one of these crises that the United States is involved. The Presidential election may insure the triumph or ruin of the North. According to the name that shall be drawn from the popular urn, America may regain peace and become the model of free countries, or she may fall into that incurable anarchy which has made the Spanish Republics the prey of wretched despots, the laughing-stock and plaything of Europe."
headline: {'main': 'OUR ELECTION ABROAD.; Mr. Laboulaye on the American Crisis.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OUR ELECTION ABROAD.; Mr. Laboulaye on the American Crisis.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Rebel Gen; Operations in Missouri
snippet: Rebel Gen; Operations in Missouri
lead_paragraph: The embroilment in southern Missouri is evidently about to be brought to a headway. PRICE and his powerful force of 15,000 mounted Western men have had pretty much their own way for two months. There has been no successful resistance made to his march from the Southern line of the State to the Missouri River, and thence westward to the Kansas border. At Pilot Knob he was stoutly held at bay for a time by Gen. EWING; at Jefferson City, the capital, he found the fortifications so strong that he thought it indiscreet to make an assault; and at Lexington Gen. BLUNT fought him with vigor on Wednesday last. But with these and lesser exceptions, he has, in more than one sense, carried everything easily before him. He has ravaged and plundered everywhere, and the Union people have suffered untold horrors. Thousands of them have been rendered homeless by his cruelty; thousands upon thousands of them have fled before his advance, and hundreds of them have been killed in cold blood. The most undesirable region in the whole land to live in, during the last two months, has been the southern half of the State of Missouri.

abstract: to Vote; the Act on; Soldiers' Naturalization Act
snippet: to Vote; the Act on; Soldiers' Naturalization Act
lead_paragraph: The rush for maturalization papers this season is unusually large, even fer a Presidential campaign. The Judges of the Superior Court and Court of Common Pleas have their hands full with the work of transforming aliens into full-grown citizens, at the rate of nearly five hundred per day. This unprecedented rush is partially owing to the fact that large numbers of foreigners, who have refrained from taking out their papers from a dread of making themselves liable to a draft, have come to the conclusion that the conscription will never be enforced in New-York, and that they may as well have their share of the fun of electing a President.

abstract: New-York Serenade; Speech at New-York and Error in Pamphlet
snippet: New-York Serenade; Speech at New-York and Error in Pamphlet
lead_paragraph: The October elections have awakened the Chicago candidate for the Vice-Presidency to the necessity of making some sign again. When put on the peace platform, he was all cock-a-hoop for peace. Atlanta fell, and for six weeks he didn't peep. Not even a wink could be got from him, indicating whether he would stand, and how. But the October elections have come like three buckets of water upon him. He fluttered -- after a little, pecked at HASKIN, then pecked at WARD, then turned tail for New-York, and here we have him.

abstract: Roanoke Pirates and Border Thieves; Game of
snippet: Roanoke Pirates and Border Thieves; Game of
lead_paragraph: It is well that the public should be amply apprised of every scheme set on foot to bring the United States into collision with foreign Powers, at the present crisis. Certainly, the British neutrality practiced at Bermuda and the Bahamas is not much to brag of. But we are disposed to throw whatever discredit we can upon the telegram relating to the capture of the Roanoke, which we publish this morning as the latest received from Bermuda, by way of Halifax.

abstract: EXAMINATION IN THE SHOOTING CASE AT THE FIFTH-AVENUE HOTEL. -- The parties to the Fifth-avenue Hotel shooting affair, which has been previously reported, were before Justice LEDWITH yesterday at Jefferson Market Court. Both parties complained against each other, and charged each other with an assault with intent to take life. Mr. JAS. S. PHELPS, of the Fifth-avenue Hotel, charged that he was assaulted and beaten by WM.A. GLASS, of No. 251 Fifth-avenue, and shot at by him with a pistol. Mr. GLASS made a similar complaint against Mr. PHELPS. Nothing appeared in evidence showing the cause of the disturbance. The parties are brothers-in-law, and there was a feud of longstanding existing between them. They both stated themselves to be natives of Kentucky, and commission merchants. Mr. GLASS is 36 years of age, and resides at No. 251 Fifth-avenue. Mr. PHELPS is 38 years of age. He is temporarily stopping at the Fifth-avenue Hotel. Both pleaded not guilty, but were ordered to find bail in the sum of $1,000 each. WM. BARBOUR, of No. 11 West Thirty-second-street became security for Mr. GLASS, and Mr. SIMEON LELAND, of the Metropolitan Hotel, became surety for Mr. PHELPS.

abstract: The assets of this company are nearly two millions of dollars. Organized in 1850, with a capital of a hundred thousand, it has steadily progressed to its present monetary importance; and its new building on Broadway, between Liberty-street and Maiden-lane, now being completed, is one of the handsomest in the city. In receipts last year were more than $750,000. The policies of the company are incontestible after five years for any errors, omissions or misstatements or in the application, except as to age, and the directors have a personal pecuniary interest in the judicious management of its affairs, -- Commercial A[???].

ZUCCHI's superb style is heard to the best advantage in the role of Pauline, ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- The repetition of "Il Poliuto" last night fulfilled alt the expectations that had been formed of its excellence by the previous performance. The work was received with positive enthusiasm, due not merely to the popular merits of the music, but to the singular vigor with which it was interpreted. Mile. ZUCCHI's superb style is heard to the best advantage in the role of Pauline, and her voice has never revealed itself in such abundance and beauty. The success is due largely to this lady, although in the finale to the second act Signor MASSIMILIANI fairly divides the honors with her. Signor BELLINI, too, contributes in no small degree to the effectiveness of the cast, which is in all respects equal to anything we have ever had here.

abstract: -- The Copperheads who have been arguing that it is the great desire of the rebel leaders to secure the reelection of President LINCOLN, will please to read the speech of the chief rebel, JEFF. DAVIS, which they will find in the TIMES of to-day. DAVIS urges his subjects to renewed efforts to plant the rebel banners on the banks of the Ohio, and adds: "Let fresh victories crown our (rebel) arms, and the Peace party, if there be one at the North, can elect its candidate." Thus among those who advocate, by words and by arms, the election of MCCLELLAN, is the chief conspirator of the great rebellion, JEFF. DAVIS.

abstract: Offering to Bet on McClellan

abstract: Desperate Speech at Columbia
snippet: Desperate Speech at Columbia
lead_paragraph: Successive files of papers from different parts of the South bring us more and more of the remarkable speeches which the President of the Southern Confederacy delivered during his late tour into Georgia, and which have been first given to the country in the columns of the Times. Thus, on the 7th current, we were the first to give JEFF. DAVIS' astounding and desperate speech at Macon; which we procured by telegraph from Washington at some expense; but which our cotemporaries copied next day without credit. On Saturday last, we published DAVIS' more moderate but not less interesting speech at Augusta, which our cotemporaries published the following Monday; and to-day we give the highly important speech which DAVIS delivered at Columbia, the capital of South Carolina.

abstract: Tallahassee the, Again
snippet: Tallahassee the, Again
lead_paragraph: It has been represented of late that the port of Wilmington was now so effectively blockaded, that the entrance or exit of Confederate cruisers or blockade-runners was impossible. We have news, however, this morning from Halifax that the pirate Tallahassee, which has been lying in the harbor of Wilmington since she entered it on the 25th of August last, at the close of her month's disastrous depredations upon our commerce, has again succeeded in eluding our blockaders and making her escape to sea. Her purpose, we are told, is to make a raid. The Tallahassee, it seems, was accompanied, and is to be aided, by the Edith.

abstract: In the matter of the application of Francis Seagrist for the custody of George Winfield, alias Seagrist. -- Justice CARDOZA yesterday morning released the Senorita Eckhardt and the boy claimed by her as her child. Immediately afterward, Senorita Eckhardt was served with a writ of habeas corpus, requiring her to produce the boy before Judge LEONARD, at the Supreme Court, Chambers. The return of the Senorita to this writ set forth that the boy, George Winfield, was her own child, but that she had been compelled, through inability to support him, to leave him in the Boston Poorhouse. In the traverse, Mr. Seagrist claimed that he had taken the boy from the poorhouse, and had him regularly apprenticed by the Probate of Boston. His Honor adjourned the case until to-morrow morning, and in the meantime directed that the boy should remain in custody of Mrs. Sutton, the wife of the Warden of the City Prison.

abstract: Redfield, Col James
snippet: Redfield, Col James
lead_paragraph: It will be learned with regret by the many friends of this gallant officer in this State that he fell, while fighting at the head of his regiment, in the last battle at Allatoona Pass, Oct. 5, 1864. At the outbreak of the rebellion he was in the State Senate of Iowa, to which office he had been elected by an overwhelming majority; but impelled by his patriotic and chivalrous spirit, he threw all his energies into the contest. He was largely instrumental in raising the Thirty-ninth Iowa Regiment, which he has led through, nearly all the hard campaigns of the Western army. He was severely wounded at the battle of Parker's Cross-roads, where his conduct won him the highest admiration of his fellow officers. His last fight was at Allatoona Pass, Georgia, where, under the brave Gen. CORSE, FRENCH's division of HOOD's army was repulsed with great slaughter.

abstract: Rebel Agents; The, in England
snippet: Rebel Agents; The, in England
lead_paragraph: -- The Charleston Courier has a correspondent in London who appears to devote himself much to taking a view of things in a personal aspect. We gather from his last letter, among other points, that Mr. MASON's table in Upper Seymour-street, London, is loaded with invitations to dinner from Bishops and leading statesmen. Prof. MAURY represents the Confederate Navy, but as he has no navy immediately at his command, and as Capt. BULLOCK and Commodore BARRON are on hand for practical duties. "Mr. MAURY's influence is more beneficially exerted among the scientific men of England." His health is bad, "but he is so much of a savan" that he will be scientific. Mr. HENRY HOETZE is editor of the Index, chosen thereto because he is a Swiss by birth, and takes naturally to the advocacy of the peculiar institutions of the South. Mrs. GREENHOW (that was) has been almost of use enough to the Confederacy in London to entitle her to be classed as "an official." Prof. BLEDSOE, of the Virginia University, is also in London, and "much is hoped from the influence of his master mind." Messrs. FRAZER, TRENHOLM & Co., Liverpool merchants, "are characterized by patriotism," Messrs. CRENSHAW & Co., of the same place, "are among the most liberal and patriotic in the land," and the name of Mr. W.S. LINDSAY all Confederate children "should be taught to love."

abstract: and St. Albans Raiders
snippet: and St. Albans Raiders
lead_paragraph: -- It appears that the horde of ruffians now at St. John, are under the special patronage of GEORGE N. SANDERS. The text of the report is noteworthy. He is "managing their cause." No one should be in haste to disturb this arrangement. It simplifies the case exceedingly, to have SANDERS vouch, as it seems he is prepared to do, for the good standing of these miscreants as commissioned soldiers of DAVIS' Confederacy. And if he can persuade the Canadian authorities that organized gangs of burglars may appear in this way at any point on the frontier with duly attested proof of their "belligerent" character, he will probably help to bring to a solution at once the simple question whether the Province can afford to become their base of offensive operations. Much more satisfactory than a surrender of these ruffians under an extradition claim would be to find the Canadians manly and honest enough to assert the authority of their own municipal law. With Mr. SANDERS as a witness, they may do this, in preference to giving up the so-called refugees as murderers and burglars. But in any case, the Provincial authorities should not forget what is due to themselves. They have an opportunity of showing that they desire to live on terms of friendship with this country. If they are wise they will show it.

abstract: The Candidate of the Rebellion
snippet: The Candidate of the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: "Let fresh victories crown our arms, and the Peace party, if there be such at the North, can elect its candidate." Such are the words of JEFF. DAVIS to the rebels in his last speech. "Hurrah for MCCLELLAN!" Such was the cry from HOOD's soldiers in the late attack upon Resaca. So the arch-rebel invokes fiercer fight to help the Chicago nominee, and so the rebel rank and file shout his name as their battle cry.

abstract: State Rights; and State Rights
snippet: State Rights; and State Rights
lead_paragraph: Those who defend secession as but the assertion of one of the undoubted rights of the States, also oppose the war as destructive of these rights. Their theory seems to be, that there can be no security for local independence, no safety for the small States against the violence or intrigues of the large ones, unless the right of withdrawing from the confederation at pleasure is conceded by the central government. The truth is, however, that there are no more formidable enemies of States' rights than these same Secessionists; no doctrines from which the weak States have so much to fear, as from them.

abstract: Saturday Review Essays; American Journal Science and Art; Richter, Life of; by Mrs E B Lee
snippet: Saturday Review Essays; American Journal Science and Art; Richter, Life of; by Mrs E B Lee
lead_paragraph: It is a little remarkable that the present hard-headed and matter-of-fact age, should have witnessed the resurrection of that older type of desultory literature, the Essay, in which, with an easy familiarity reminding one of the Spectator and Tattler days -- the author discusses some topic generally of manners, minor morals, or any subject of temporary conventional interest. The writers of the Saturday Review were among the most potent agents of this revival, and the volume before us contains some of its best specimens.

abstract: Ripe Old Age of
snippet: Ripe Old Age of
lead_paragraph: D.D., of Rochester, reached the advanced age of 80 years on Tuesday last. Prof. DEWEY graduated at Williams College in 1806, and was tutor and professor in that institution from 1808 to 1827. In the latter year he took charge of the Berkshire Gymnasium in Pittsfield, Mass., which was for many years a celebrated and successful school for boys. In 1836 he removed to Rochester, and was principal of the Collegiate Institute there until 1850, since which time he has filled the chair of chemistry and the natural sciences in the University of Rochester. During most of the period from his graduation until 1850 he was professor and lecturer on chemistry and botany in the Medical College at Pittsfield, and for a part of the time in the medical school of Woodstock, Vt. Prof. DEWEY retains his faculties of mind and body in a remarkable degree, and is in better health now than for some time past. His eightieth birthday was made the occasion of a family gathering and the offering of the congratulations of many of his fellow-citizens. Thousands of Prof. DEWEY's pupils, scattered over the whole Union, will hear with pleasure of the vigor and health which attends his advanced age. During the past year some of Prof. DEWEY's college pupils have presented to the Alumni Hall of Williams College a fine portrait of their former instructor. The donors of this portrait were Hon. E.C. Benedict and Hon. D.D. Field, of New-York; Hon. Emory Washburn, Hon. Homer Bartlett, Judge Charles A. Dewey and Rev. Dr. Orville Dewey, of Massachusetts; Hon. A.C. Paige, of Schenectady; and Rev. Dr. E.P. Swift, of Pennsylvania.

abstract: Debt; Richmond Enquirer's Way to Pay
snippet: Debt; Richmond Enquirer's Way to Pay
lead_paragraph: There is something both touching and instructive in the rapid progress which the rebels are making in knowledge of finance. The state of mind in which the war found them with regard to the art of raising revenue was primitive in the extreme. Most of their newspapers seem to have been possessed with the notion that human nature was to be changed for the special benefit of the Southern Confederacy, and that men would lay aside some of the most prominent characteristics of human nature in order to help the rebellion along.

abstract: Speech at Columbia and Rebel Programme
snippet: Speech at Columbia and Rebel Programme
lead_paragraph: -- The remarkable speech of JEFF. DAVIS, at Columbia, which was published in the TIMES of yesterday, deserves more careful study by those who would comprehend the real feelings and purposes of the rebel leaders at this crisis, than anything heretofore uttered by any other man. Unlike his speech at Macon, it was evidently carefully prepared, and was characterized by a cool desperation the very opposite of the hot and furious passion of his first Georgia speech. The military programme which he announced is the necessary programme of the rebels in the Southwest under their present circumstances. They were to make an incursion northward and assume the offensive, because they must do so. We possess the great strongholds and control the great water-lines of the Southwest, and as it is impossible to drive us from these by direct assault, the only alternative is to try and force their evacuation, by making desperate efforts to strike northward with an army. Hence after asserting that his western army has increased in strength since the fall of Atlanta, that it has risen in tone, that its march is onward and its face to the front, he says that HOOD's eye is now fixed upon a point far beyond that where he was assailed by the enemy; and further on adds, "I believe it is in the power of the men of the Confederacy to plant our banners on the banks of the Ohio, where we may say to the Yankee, 'be quiet, or we shall teach you another lesson.' Within the next thirty days, much is to be done, for upon our success much depends." HOOD and BEAUREGARD are now struggling to carry out this programme, but their success thus far certainly does not hold out much prospect of ultimate success.

abstract: New-York; Feely, of Pittsburgh, Penn. of $4,500
snippet: New-York; Feely, of Pittsburgh, Penn. of $4,500
lead_paragraph: TWO MEN ARRESTED CHARGED WITH THE THEFT. -- PATRICK COLEMAN and PATRICK CONLON, of this city, were arrested yesterday by Capt. JOURDAN and Officer GOLDEN, of the Sixth Precinct, on the charge of having robbed MARTIN FEELY, a Councilman of the city of Pittsburgh, Pa. It seems that Mr. FEELY was in this city for the purpose of purchasing goods. On Monday night last he took a stroll around town, with $4,500 in bills, on various banks of the city of Pittsburgh, in his pockets. CONLON, who is an acquaintance of Mr. FEELY, took him to his residence, where he staid during the night. COLEMAN accompanied them, and the three slept in one bed, -- Councilman FEELY, as the testimony shows, was placed in the middle, in the morning the latter was awakened by some one tumbling over his clothes, when he discovered COLEMAN's hand in his pocket. An examination of the pockets showed that the sum of $4,500 was gone. Both CONLIN and COLEMAN ran away as soon as FEELY discovered them in the act of stealing. When the prisoners were brought before Justice DOWLING they were committed to the Tombs in default of $5,000 bail each, for trial. None of the money was recovered.

abstract: THE $50,000 ROBBERY IN BOSTON -- FURTHER EXAMINATION IN THE CASE OF MANNING, THE WALL STREET BROKER. -- Yesterday the examination in the case of JOHN B. MANNING, the Wall-street broker, who is charged with passing some of the $100 bills stolen from Messrs. BREWSTER, SWEET & CO., of Boston, in August last, was continued before Justice DOWLING at the Tombs Police Court. Mr. THOMAS R. MCNELL, keeping a restaurant at No. 203 Washington-street, was examined. He testified that Mr. MANNING, or a man in his company, called at his place on the evening of the 8th inst., and presented a $100 Treasury-note, and asked witness to give him small bills for it. Witness said he would do so if the bill was all right, and afterward he changed the note. ANDREW F. HEISER, bartender in the saloon of ALEXANDER MATTHEWS, No. 222 Greenwich-street was examined and testified that on the evening of the 8th inst., a man whom he identified as Mr. MANNING, came into the bar-room, and asked him to change a $100 Treasury note. Not having the money witness referred him to THOMAS H. CORWIN, also employed on the premises. CORWIN soon after gave MANNING the change for the $100 note. It was subsequently discovered that the names on this note had been erased. The investigation will be continued to-day.

We have no great movement to record; but there are signs that active operations will soon be resumed at different points. abstract: Lichtenstein on Illustration; a Specimen of State Sovereignty
snippet: Lichtenstein on Illustration; a Specimen of State Sovereignty
lead_paragraph: -- The last mail from Europe brought us a somewhat pointed and painful illustration of the theory of State Sovereignty, in the case of a commonwealth, venerable by age and illustrious by the antiquity of its dynastic inheritors. The sovereign principality of Lichtenstein, one of the "Powers" of Europe, has ceased to exist in a state of independence. It had a territory of sixty-four square miles. It had a high-spirited population of over seven thousand souls. It had a representative voice in the Federal Diet. It had a guaranteed existence from the Congress of Vienna in 1815. It had the privilege of contributing to the German army a force of ninety full privates and one drummer. But failing in the exercise of this latter privilege, on the technical point of whether the people or the Sovereign should provide for the military items in the budget, a secession feeling arose, and incontinently, the sovereign State of Lichtenstein merged its sovereign existence in that of the Empire of Austria.

abstract: and Chicago Platform
snippet: and Chicago Platform
lead_paragraph: -- The Copperheaded idea that the soldiers of the Republic will vote for the Chicago platform is a very odd one. That all the degenerate elements of society in civil life should vote for it -- that all deserters, skedaddlers, bounty-jumpers, sneaks and malcontents should vote for it -- is according to the eternal fitness of things. But that the brave men confronting the enemy should sustain the coward's platform -- that the victorious regiments who have borne cur flag over half the Southern Confederacy, conquering and to conquer, should vote themselves and their deeds a "failure" -- that the army which has the rebellion by the throat should ask JEFF. DAVIS for an armistice -- that the host holding high and ultimate convention in the heart of Georgia and in the heart of Virginia should adjourn to jangle about another ultimate convention -- were rather anomalous.

abstract: Trial of; Boole, Inspector; Reply to Mayor on Suspension from Office
snippet: Trial of; Boole, Inspector; Reply to Mayor on Suspension from Office
lead_paragraph: The grand test of the twenty-inch Rodman gun at Fort Hamilton yesterday proved to be an entire success. At the hour announced, 12 o'clock, for the first loading of the heaviest piece of ordnance in the world, the parapets of the Fort were thronged with distinguished officers and ladies and gentlemen all anxious to witness the trial of the great gun. Considerable delay was experienced in the proper adjustment of the piece, as it was not until half past two o'clock the first discharge, a blank cartridge, of one hundred pounds of powder was fired. The concussion following the discharge was slight, and the recoil of the gun much less than was anticipated. The piece was next loaded with a charge of fifty pounds of powder and a thousand pound shell. The time taken in loading was about half an hour. The second trial was as successful as the first, the bail, in consequence of considerable depression of the gun, striking the water at a quarter of a mile distance recocheting several times. The gun, on examination, being found to have received no strain, preparations were made for the final test. At 5 o'clock the piece was again loaded with a charge of one hundred pounds of powder and a ball weighing one thousand and eighty pounds -- one of the largest ordnance projectiles ever cast. Owing to the rather impromptu arrangements for raising the ball, it was found to be anything but an easy task to adjust it. However, at the hour mentioned, the piece was loaded, and everybody stood clear for the last grand trial. The gun was raised to an elevation of twenty-five degrees, and the discharge was deafening. The ball was twenty-four seconds in the air, and tell at the distance of about three miles and a half. Considerable applause followed the final shot, and all concerned in the management of the piece were warmly congratulated. The following are the dimensions of this last great achievement of Capt. RODMAN: Weight of gun, 110,497 pounds; length, 21 feet; bore, 20 inches; usual charge of powder, 100 pounds; average weight of ball, 1,000 pounds. Previous to the trial of the gun, the revenue cutter Bronx. Capt. MARCEL, arrived at the Government dock, having on board a large number of ladies and gentlemen. Prominent among the latter were Gen. DIX, Gen. HAYS, Gen. DYER, Gen. SMITH, Commodore PAULDING, Commodore WISE, Commodore RODGERS, Maj. VAN FLEET, Capt. RODMAN and PETER COOPER. During the afternoon an elegant collation was served on board the cutter, and to the music of the Fort Hamilton Band the guests joined in a dance on the deck.

abstract: Will Neither Write Acceptance Nor Withdraw
snippet: Will Neither Write Acceptance Nor Withdraw
lead_paragraph: We have heard, on very good authority, that a select meeting of Democratic politicians was held, a few evenings ago, in this city, at the house of a prominent Copperhead, to consider the propriety of requiring Mr. PENDLETON either to write a good rampant war letter, expressing his "views," or to withdraw from the canvass. Since this gentleman's selection for the Vice-Presidency, he has proved nearly as great a nuisance to the Democratic party as the bull in the china shop to the proprietor of that establishment. They have so far failed in getting him to write a letter with any meaning to it, or which gives the public any clearer idea of his opinions about the war, than it had already. The recent epistle, in which he avowed his attachment to the Constitution, throws about as much light on his political position, as an expression of admiration for the planet Mars. A man may adore the Union, as everybody knows, and yet refuse to fire a shot or spend a cent to save it. It is now generally admitted that his speech the other night, at the New-York Hotel, was not a success. His sole reply to the charges made against him of hostility to the war, hostility to the army, and sympathy with the rebellion is, that the printer made the mistake of substituting "June" for "Jan." or "January." This is fearfully "smart," but smartness is hardly the quality most needed in a Vice-President of the United States.

abstract: His Emigration Letter in England
snippet: His Emigration Letter in England
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. Mayor GUNTHER has achieved the distinction of a favorable notice from the British journals peculiarly and malignantly Anti-American in their sympathy. His letter discouraging emigration is highly spoken of in such circles as are most closely allied in interest and feeling with the rebels. In reproduing it in England, the rebel organs are careful to point out, on GUNTHER's authority, that the British workman who comes here, instead of earning five shillings for his day's labor, really earns but two shillings. It is considered highly gratifying, moreover, that the Chief Magistrate of the first city of the American Union should have vouchsafed his testimony in so open and explicit a manner. In short, GUNTHER has done what he hoped to do; he has lent a hand to the foreign foes of our country, and they acknowledge it gratefully.

abstract: -- Yesterday afternoon the Fifty-second Regiment, N.Y.S.V., distinguished for the last three years as one of the best disciplined, hard-fighting and enduring organizations in the army, arrived in this city from Washington. Although it was the general desire of the veterans to avoid a public display, still the Fifth Regiment, N.Y.N.G., were out in full force, under command of Col. BURGER, to receive them. The complete ranks of the Fifth Regiment presented a striking contrast to those of the Fifty-second, of which but thirty-five of the original thousand strong remained. Early in the afternoon these heroes of many battles were drawn up in line in front of the City Hall, and were formally received by their military escort. Judge DALEY delivered the speech of welcome. He spoke in eloquent terms of the honorable record of the regiment; the faithfulness with which they had served the republic, and tendered them the thanks of their fellow-citizens. In conclusion he presented a beautiful wreath, bearing the inscription "Welcome Home Fifty-second Regiment." The officer commanding responded, saying that his command had always endeavored to do their duty in whatever position they were placed. He referred to the battles in which the regiment had been engaged, and trusted that its record was a sufficient guarantee of its patriotism and the services it had rendered the country. At the conclusion of his remarks the volunteers gave three cheers for the city, when the ceremonies ended.
