abstract: partnership with St Albans Robbers

lead_paragraph: -- Among the reports of the St. Alban's outrage will be found an intercepted telegram directed to GEORGE N. SANDERS, in which one of the robbers practically admits that SANDERS had been forewarned of the burglaries. A sort of partnership, in fact, is set up between the thieves and the Niagara peace negotiator. This accounts for the statement made in a previous report, that SANDERS had gone to Lower Canada, and was at St. John, along with the captured gang, "managing their cause."

abstract: Vote Conspiracy; and Soldiers' Vote Conspiracy
snippet: Vote Conspiracy; and Soldiers' Vote Conspiracy
lead_paragraph: The party of the Copperheads, so far as it has been able, has precluded the soldiers who are devoting their lives to their country, from the elective franchise. In every State where it had the control of the Legislature, Indiana, Illinois, New-Jersey and Delaware, it has thwarted every attempt to secure to them the exercise of the first right of American freemen. This was sufficiently base. But intelligence from Washington concerning the conspiracy to fa[???]y the votes of the soldiers in this vote displays a depth of villainy in the Copperhead managers beyond all previous conception. We could hardly believe it if it did not come so authenticated as to exclude all doubt of the actual crime. It remains only for the particular details to be exposed by the court-martial already at work. Very full details of the facts as developed yesterday, will be found in this morning's TIMES.

abstract: The steamship Canada arrived yesterday at Halifax, bringing two days' later news from Europe. The report that Capt. SEMMES had left England in the blockade-runner Laurel, is denied by the owner of that vessel, who ridicules the idea that the little steamer Ranger, of less than one hundred tons burden, is to be converted into a privateer. A report is current that JULES GERARD, the African explorer, has been drowned.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Canada arrived yesterday at Halifax, bringing two days' later news from Europe. The report that Capt. SEMMES had left England in the blockade-runner Laurel, is denied by the owner of that vessel, who ridicules the idea that the little steamer Ranger, of less than one hundred tons burden, is to be converted into a privateer. A report is current that JULES GERARD, the African explorer, has been drowned. Financial affairs in England continue in a very unsettled state, and several additional suspensions are reported. The Confederate loan experienced a slight improvement on the receipt of the Persia's news, which was considered unfavorable to the North. The Spanish steamer captured by the Niagara had been released. There appears to be some prospect of a speedy peaceful settlement of the Danish question.

abstract: Proposed Capital of the
snippet: Proposed Capital of the
lead_paragraph: -- There is probably little ground for the report of the conference proceedings in Quebec, which announce the selection of Ottawa as the seat of Government for the new Union. Such reports are frequently inspired by interested persons. The Queen, six years ago, selected Ottawa as the capital for Canada. But it is a most unlikely place to be chosen as the capital for the whole of British America.

abstract: Agreement with Lee on Prisoners; Agreement between Grant and Lee on Supplies to
snippet: Agreement with Lee on Prisoners; Agreement between Grant and Lee on Supplies to
lead_paragraph: The country will be rejoiced to learn that an agreement has been entered into between Gens. GRANT and LEE which will greatly alleviate the sufferings of Union prisoners in the South. By the terms of this agreement, the details of which have not yet been definitely settled, we shall be permitted to send to the South clothing, blankets and supplies for our prisoners in the hands of the Confederates; they, in return, being allowed to do the same by their prisoners in our hands.

abstract: There is joyous news is our columns today news which will carry relief to tens of thousands of brave men suffering under anguisli as great as mortal can endure greater, in fact, for thousands of them have succumbed under it; news which will bring relief to hundreds of thousands of the immediate relatives and friends of the sufferers;  news which will give a sense of relief to the millions of this broad continent, who...
lead_paragraph: There is joyous news is our columns today -- news which will carry relief to tens of thousands of brave men suffering under anguisli as great as mortal can endure -- greater, in fact, for thousands of them have succumbed under it; -- news which will bring relief to hundreds of thousands of the immediate relatives and friends of the sufferers; -- news which will give a sense of relief to the millions of this broad continent, who have been horror-struck at the long continued and fearful atrocities of the rebels committed upon our prisoners of war in their hands. A plan, originally at the instance of the rebel Commissioner of Exchange, has been agreed upon between the Union and Confederate military authorities, (Gens. GRANT and LEE being the chief correspondents,) by which our Government is permitted to send necessary supplies of food, clothing and medicines to the starving, naked and sick brave men whom the fortunes of war have placed in the power of the rebels. In return for this, our Government is to permit the rebel authorities to purchase abroad such proper supplies as they may desire for the use of their soldiers who are prisoners in our hands.

abstract: -The telegraph brings news that the trial of the St. Alban's robbers has been transferred from St. John to Montreal, with the consent, as it appears, of the Hon. Mr. EDMONDS, who appeared for the United States Government. There is probably wisdom in this arrangement. St. John is an exposed country town, only a few miles from the border; and although the prisoners were well guarded by police and regular soldiers, there is better security for their safe keeping in the jail of Montreal.
lead_paragraph: -The telegraph brings news that the trial of the St. Alban's robbers has been transferred from St. John to Montreal, with the consent, as it appears, of the Hon. abstract: Chief of Police JORDON, of Jersey City, was notified yesterday afternoon that a large number of the prize-fighters who were engaged in robbing passengers on the trains on Thursday night, were on their way to New-York, and would arrive in Jersey City about 7 P.M.; also that the train had been ordered to come through without stopping at the station. The Chief, with a passe of about twenty men, proceeded to the Erie Depot and laid his plans for capturing the whole party. As the train neared the west end of the Erie tunnel, the desperadoes broke open the doors of the cars and put on the brakes, by which means the train was stopped sufficiently to allow about 150, (nearly all the party) to make their escape.
lead_paragraph: Chief of Police JORDON, of Jersey City, was notified yesterday afternoon that a large number of the prize-fighters who were engaged in robbing passengers on the trains on Thursday night, were on their way to New-York, and would arrive in Jersey City about 7 P.M.; also that the train had been ordered to come through without stopping at the station. The Chief, with a passe of about twenty men, proceeded to the Erie Depot and laid his plans for capturing the whole party. As the train neared the west end of the Erie tunnel, the desperadoes broke open the doors of the cars and put on the brakes, by which means the train was stopped sufficiently to allow about 150, (nearly all the party) to make their escape.

abstract: Movements on the Left; Movement on the Left and Strategy
snippet: Movements on the Left; Movement on the Left and Strategy
lead_paragraph: The official bulletin of this morning contains news of an important movement made toward the left, or toward the Southside Railroad, by two corps of our army, on Thursday. Gen. GRANT moved out in this direction with a view of testing the strength of the enemy's line and works in this locality, and perhaps with other views which have not yet reached their consummation. We had news two days ago that the rebels, doubtless in anticipation of this movement, had been massing their troops on our left; and Gen. GRANT says that at every point reconnoitred, the enemy was found intrenched and his works manned. In the evening, the rebels attacked HANCOCK vigorously, but the latter gained a decided success, repulsing them and holding possession of the field until midnight. It is evident, however, that it was not GRANT's design to make a general assault upon the enemy's works, for he withdrew his army from the advanced positions to which it had been pushed.

abstract: Every one rejoices at the detection of the attempted frauds in the soldiers' votes, but there also comes to every one the question whether it does not come too late; whether a dangerous number of these fraudulent ballots may not have already been sent so far on their way that they will not be stopped by the mere discovery of the fraud, and whether anything can be done here at home to keep them out of the ballot-boxes. We have been examining the law with reference to this latter point, and though it would seem to have been carelessly or carefully drawn, so as to make fraud easy and its detection difficult, yet something may perhaps be done.
lead_paragraph: Every one rejoices at the detection of the attempted frauds in the soldiers' votes, but there also comes to every one the question whether it does not come too late; whether a dangerous number of these fraudulent ballots may not have already been sent so far on their way that they will not be stopped by the mere discovery of the fraud, and whether anything can be done here at home to keep them out of the ballot-boxes. We have been examining the law with reference to this latter point, and though it would seem to have been carelessly or carefully drawn, so as to make fraud easy and its detection difficult, yet something may perhaps be done.

abstract: Did the Best he Could; Sherman's Opinion; Says President Lincoln did Best he Could
snippet: Did the Best he Could; Sherman's Opinion; Says President Lincoln did Best he Could
lead_paragraph: "I believe Mr. LINCOLN has done the best he could," says Maj.-Gen. SHERMAN, in his letter just published. Such is the conviction of an officer who, by his breadth of mind, his long residence in the South previous to the rebellion, and his military experience farther within the cordon of the rebellion than that of any other general officer, peculiarly qualify him to form a correct judgment. It derives additional force from the fact that Gen. SHERMAN has always been a staunch Democrat.
headline: {'main': 'The Best He Could.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Best He Could.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: and the Soldiers' Vote Swindle; Vote Conspiracy, the
snippet: and the Soldiers' Vote Swindle; Vote Conspiracy, the
lead_paragraph: The discovery of the conspiracy to falsify the suffrage of the soldiers puts the last brand of infamy on the brow of HORATIO SEYMOUR. His connivance with the mob that undertook to bully our Legislature from the election of a loyal United States Senator, dishonored him. He did so connive, for when the Assembly solicited him to protect it, he refused. His fomenting and countenancing the insurrection which for days went through these streets, pillaging, burning, mutilating and murdering, disgraced him. He did so foment, by his letters and speeches against the draft, and he did so countenance by his hailing the miscreants on the afternoon of the second day of their work as "friends," and by his assurance that he had sent his Adjutant-General to Washington to ask the President to stop the draft. But his plotting to reverse, by fraud, the votes of living soldiers, and to forge the votes of dead soldiers, affixes the supreme stigma. He did so plot, for the work was done by agents he commissioned.
headline: {'main': "The Soldiers' Vote Swindle.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Soldiers' Vote Swindle.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SANITARY REFORMS NEEDED. -- That a better sanitary system than we now have should exist, no one will question. For the want of a well-organized Health Department, our weekly bills of mortality show a fearful number of deaths, and medical records an unnatural and alarming amount of disease. These two practical questions must occur to every citizen: First, What is the remedy for this gigantic evil? No one can be at a loss for an answer. The remedy consists simply in this -- cleanliness -- cleanliness of streets -- cleanliness of houses -- cleanliness of the individual. The Health Officer of London thus states the result of his vast experience. "For the permanent avoidance of epidemic diseases, cleanliness is the sole safeguard." Second, How can this be accomplished? This admits of a ready answer. A Health Department, consisting of a properly organized Board of Health, and properly selected subordinate officers, has remedied these evils in London. Paris, Boston, Providence and Philadelphia. Why may it not in New-York? In these cities the Boards of Health are active bodies, having regular meetings, and maintaining a constant and intelligent vigilance over all health laws. The chief executive officer is in each instance a medical man of eminence, whose duty it is, under the direction of the Board of Health, to attend to the execution of the health laws. The local officers for sanitary inspection are also medical men, whose duty it is to search out every cause of disease, and compel its removal. Such a system has raised the standard of the health of London above even the surrounding country. There is no doubt that a Board of Health composed of five or seven of our best citizens, meeting weekly, with sufficient power to enforce all the health laws, and with practical subordinates, as above, would soon not only give us a clean city, but one rivaling any other in the great desideratum of health.

abstract: An important reconnoissance in force was made by Gen. GRANT to the extreme left of his line with the corps of Gens. HANCOCK and WARREN. No attack was made by our troops, though the rebel pickets were driven in, and their line, which now proves very strong and well-guarded, was horoughly reconnoitered. During the afternoon the rebels attacked HANCOCK with considerable vigor, but were repulsed in the most complete manner. We captured over nine hundred prisoners during the movement, together with seven trains of army supplies, which were on their way from Stony Creek, on the Weldon Railroad, to the rebel lines, via the Boydton plank-road. On Thursday night, at 12 o'clock, our forces returned to nearly their former positions, without interruption.

abstract: The inquiries of the Shareholders' Investigation Committee have already led to some astounding disclosures respecting the manner in which the business of the Leeds Banking Company, which recently failed, has been conducted. It has been discovered, for instance, that MARSDEN, the Leeds Ironfounder, who has fled to New-York, had within the last few years  passed forged bills to the amount of about  80,000 through the bank.
lead_paragraph: -- The inquiries of the Shareholders' Investigation Committee have already led to some astounding disclosures respecting the manner in which the business of the Leeds Banking Company, which recently failed, has been conducted. It has been discovered, for instance, that MARSDEN, the Leeds Ironfounder, who has fled to New-York, had within the last few years passed forged bills to the amount of about 80,000 through the bank. Many of these bills were drawn upon persons who had no business connection or even personal acquaintance with MARSDEN. In this work the fraudulent bankrupt seems to have been assisted by THOMAS SKAIFE, his manager and brother-in-law, who has been apprehended on a charge of forgery and committed for trial at the assizes. At the examination of SKAIFE, Mr. WALKER JOY, a member of the Shareholders' Committee, stated that SKAIFE had informed the Committee that Mr. GREENLAND, the manager of the bank "knew all about it."

abstract: The particulars of the movement made on Thursday by Gen GRANT, show it to have been a reconnoissance in force to develop the real rebel line on the southwest front of Petersburgh. Our forces advanced some eight or ten miles, driving the enemy's skirmishers before them, and taking up a position on the Boynton plank road, over which the rebels have wagoned their supplies from Stony Creek, on the Weldon Railroad.
lead_paragraph: The particulars of the movement made on Thursday by Gen GRANT, show it to have been a reconnoissance in force to develop the real rebel line on the southwest front of Petersburgh. Our forces advanced some eight or ten miles, driving the enemy's skirmishers before them, and taking up a position on the Boynton plank road, over which the rebels have wagoned their supplies from Stony Creek, on the Weldon Railroad. No attack was made by our forces, though the rebels tried it, by striking the right flank of the Second Corps, but they were finally repulsed with the loss of a considerable number of prisoners. At night our lines were contracted somewhat, though they are still much advanced from their former position.

abstract: London Times and New Rebel Proposal; Independence, New Scheme for
snippet: London Times and New Rebel Proposal; Independence, New Scheme for
lead_paragraph: We perceive that one of the leading newspaper agents employed by the rebel Government has had instructions to put forward, through the London Times, a scheme of settlement between the North and the South, which probably would be valuable, if it had novelty enough in it to commend it to notice. The sum of the matter is, that many of the exiles "highest in the confidence of the Confederate Government" are beginning to admit that the day may come when the South will be driven into a corner, "unable to find help abroad or reinforcements at home;" that in such an emergency, "the Southern leaders might be induced to propose terms to Mr. LINCOLN." If Mr. LINCOLN should happen not to be elected, the same authority tells us, then, the Southern leaders would propose terms to Gen. MCCLELLAN. They would, at all events, represent to the actual President that they could never honorably lay down their arms until they had secured their political independence. They would rely upon the forbearance of the North not to exterminate them, having a regard to "the opinions of the world and the doctrines of Christianity." And such being the case, the South, "upon consideration of a Federal recognition of its independence, would be prepared to enter into a treaty of free trade with the North; to place an export duty of ten cents upon cotton, for the express benefit of New-England, and to give that industrious community, and all the rest of the 'Federal States,' an advantage to that extent over Great Britain and France and every other part of the world."
headline: {'main': 'Southern Independence A New Lever Power.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Southern Independence A New Lever Power.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Planters Settling in Brazil
snippet: Planters Settling in Brazil
lead_paragraph: Among late news from Europe is the curious item that "several wealthy. Southern planters from South Carolina propose settling in Brazil." One gentleman is expected to arrive there with an odd quarter of a million in some sort of money. This cannot well be considered good news for the Richmond Government. Why should the capitalists of South Carolina desert that chivalrous commonwealth at this particular crisis? Can it be considered patriotic? Is this the assertion of absolute State Sovereignty in that ideal form which has challenged the admiration of the world? Deserting the cause when the Confederate organs of Richmond and New-York agree that it is about to achieve its crowning triumph! Fie upon the chivalry!

abstract: On Whipping Spaniels and Yankees
snippet: On Whipping Spaniels and Yankees
lead_paragraph: -- JEFF. DAVIS, speaking recently at Columbia, S.C., said to the rebels:. "Does any man imagine that we can conquer the Yankees by retreating before them, or do you not all know that the only way to make spaniels civil is to whip them? And you can whip them." JEFF's knowledge of natural history is at fault. If he was going to compare us to any breed of dog at all, accuracy would have compelled him to substitute bulldogs instead of "spaniels," as we have got him in a death-grip.

abstract: Governors, Meeting of
snippet: Governors, Meeting of
lead_paragraph: There is one quality in which the traitors are infinitely superior to their allies, the Copperheads. It is openness. While it is the very nature of the Copperhead to have a forked tongue and to creep stealthily, the traitor is straight in speech, and erect so that you see him just as he is. Essentially they differ not at all; but in manner altogether. The one is like the fiend --

abstract: on Democrats and the Old Union
snippet: on Democrats and the Old Union
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. PENDLETON, in his speech at the New-York Hotel a few evenings ago, made the statement (and he certainly is good authority) that "the Democratic party is pledged to the restoration of peace on the basis of the Federal Union of the States." We desire to know what at this time are the cardinal principles of the Democratic party, and are induced to believe that the above statement indicates one of them; but the phraseology is so ambiguous that we are uncertain as to its full meaning, therefore we take the liberty to inquire for light on the following points: 1. If by "Federal Union of the States," &c., he means a disruption of the existing Union and the formation of a Federal League or Confederate Union on some other basis? 2. Can we be assured that peace will result? 3. What kind of a peace?
headline: {'main': 'THE OLD UNION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE OLD UNION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Yesterday morning WM. COLLINS, FRANCIS N. JONES and WM. PHILLIPS were taken to Thomaston to serve three years in the Maine State Prison. Deputy WARDEN MAXEY took them from jail at Machias and brought them through this city, where they took the steamer Katahdin. These three men were arrested when the raid was made on the Calais Bank, and were the only ones secured. When they were taken from the jail at Machias a large crowd collected around the stage. The prisoners commenced hurrahing for JEFF. DAVIS, much to the satisfaction of the Copperheads, who expressed their sympathy as openly as they dared to.

abstract: -- A correspondent of the Cincinnati Commercial says it seems as if all agencies, human and natural, had combined to obliterate all traces of Fort Pillow -- the theatre of deeds so odious to God and man. By various parties it has been leveled down, until now there remains not so much as one shovelful of earth upon another, and the incessant dashing and rushing of the great river below is fast washing away even the foundation on which it stood.

abstract: Would they Return if Allowed to leave the Union; Independence Gained would Continue
snippet: Would they Return if Allowed to leave the Union; Independence Gained would Continue
lead_paragraph: There is one article of the Copperhead creed, which is hardly ever repeated in public, but which may generally be extorted from any candid member of the party, in private conversation, without the slightest difficulty, and it is this, that the immediate restoration of the Union is not only not possible, but not necessary -- that even if the South is now allowed to go, we might count either on its coming back to us, or our going over to it after a few years. Consequently, there are few Copperheads who look forward to the failure of the negotiations which they propose to open after "the immediate cessation of hostilities" with the slightest chagrin of despondency. In fact, it is very doubtful whether one in a thousand of them has in his secret soul the smallest expectation that any such negotiations would have the smallest chance of success. If you press one of them to tell you what is to be done in case the Confederacy refuses to listen to our appeals for reunion, after an armistice has been entered into, he will tell you, in ninety-nine cases out of a hundred, that we ought then to suffer it to go in peace; that the North would soon find the disadvantages of disunion so great, that it would go over, State by State, to the Confederacy; or else the South would find it so great, that it would come back again voluntarily.

abstract: Dano-German Question; The
snippet: Dano-German Question; The
lead_paragraph: The Dano-German question approaches a solution. The financial difficulty, at all events, has been set at rest, Denmark having consented to fix at the round sum of 9,000,000 rigsdalers the share which the Duchies are to have in the public property of the Kingdom. It is evident, however, that the Copenhagen Government yielded its assent to this proposition with the greatest reluctance. The amount named is more than equal to the whole annual revenue of the Danish monarchy, and msut press heavily on the resources of a State, already exhausted by war, by the loss of rich Provinces, and by the exactions of its enemies. Nothing, in fact, save hard necessity, could have wrung the concession from Denmark, and, deserted though she was, by her allies and advisers, she defended her position with obstinacy as long as it seemed tenable. At first her representative in the conference received instructions to reject the claim altogether as inequitable and unjust. Then he was authorized to propose that the question should be settled by arbitration; and not till it was found that the German Powers were inexorable, and that there remained no alternative for the Danes, but concession, or a renewal of the conflict, was their plenipotentiary permitted to succumb.
headline: {'main': 'The Dano-German Question.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Dano-German Question.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: PRICE left three hundred killed and tweve hundred wounded on the field, in the late battle. His army was composed of three divisions, of nine brigades. There were thirty-six regiments, averaging four hundred men to each, besides a large irregular force. He was in Jasper County on Friday, hard pressed by our forces. He had but two pieces of artillery, and one of them was disabled. The country is full of his stragglers.

abstract: Roanoke; Braine, Lieut.; Who is He
snippet: Roanoke; Braine, Lieut.; Who is He
lead_paragraph: This reckless young scoundrel who is said to have been the leader in the capture of the Roanoke, and previously of the Chesapeake, was just before the breaking out of the rebellion a lounger -- a Micawber who insisted upon having it that the world owed him a living. His first venture, so far as is known, was in Williamsburgh, Long Island, where he became acquainted with a young woman of poor but respectable connections, whom he eventually made his wife. After marriage, they went on what is technically called a "honeymoon" tour throughout the West, stopping at the leading hotels by the way, and stepping out to the tune of the "Free list." Arriving at an extreme point West, the "Lieut." finding that he was "played out" on that line, left his wife as security for the hotel bill. The landlord in this case declined the agreement, and the young wife returned to Williamsburgh, where she resided for a series of months in the family of a gentleman not remotely connected with one of the Brooklyn journals, where she was retained as an object of mercy. At length the "Lieutenant,' dropped her a note, and she left. This was about the time when the rebellion broke out. A few months only elapsed before Mrs. B. returned to Williamsburgh, loaded down with luxurious apparel, so much so as to astonish her old friends with the splendor of the transformation. Her purse was lined with gold, and she was unaccountably rich. Lieut. BRAINE was engaged in the secret service of the rebel Government. This was the secret of the "change" on the part of his wife. Mrs. B. departed from that region, and nothing was heard of the Braine family again till the Chesapeake affair came off, and after another interval, in the capture and burning of the Roanoke. For a young man, he is about as reckless as is necessary to make a dashing pirate. It appears that he has fallen into British hands at Bermuda, but under a very different exercise of governmental policy than that which prevailed at the time of the Chesapeake piracy.
headline: {'main': 'Who is Lieut. Braine?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Who is Lieut. Braine?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

snippet: Pretended Bankers' Meeting in Wall-street; Bankers' McClellan Meeting in N. Y.
lead_paragraph: A call was advertised, on Saturday, for a meeting of bankers, merchants, , of the City of New-York, on the corner of Broad and Wall streets, this afternoon, to support Gen. McCLELLAN, by way of remedy for "the prostrate condition of the National finances!" It bears the names of about five hundred persons, supposed to be bankers and merchants, and other widely-known business people, immediately concerned for the prostrate finances aforesaid. The gathering is to be preeminently a great "Bankers' Meeting," (see Express of Saturday night,) and to be held where bankers and merchants most do congregate, on the very rialto, as it were, of the great commercial metropolis.

abstract: The present week terminates Mr. MARETZEK'S first subscription season of eighteen nights, bringing it close up to the time of election. Fifteen performances have already been given, and consequently there will be but three representations this week instead of four. There may be a Matinee on Saturday. To-night "II Travatore" is to be repeated for the last time. On Wednesday "Don Giovanni" will be given with an unusually good cast, especially in the female department.
lead_paragraph: The present week terminates Mr. MARETZEK'S first subscription season of eighteen nights, bringing it close up to the time of election. Fifteen performances have already been given, and consequently there will be but three representations this week instead of four. There may be a Matinee on Saturday. To-night "II Travatore" is to be repeated for the last time. On Wednesday "Don Giovanni" will be given with an unusually good cast, especially in the female department. It is as follows: Donna Anna, Madame ZUCCHI, Donna Elvira, Mademoiselle MORENSI; and Zerlina, Miss KELLOGG. Signor BELLINI is the Don; Signor SUSINI the Leporello, and Signor LOTTI the Count. On Wednesday evening VERDI's fine opera of "Rigoletto" will be produced for the debut of Mademoiselle VAN ZANDT, a lady of high repute in musical circles. The programme of the week, it will be seen, is full of interest.

abstract: Sermon on Presidential Election
snippet: Sermon on Presidential Election
lead_paragraph: Plymouth Church was last evening crowded to its utmost capacity to bear the fourth sermon of Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, on the condition of the country and the coming election. The doors were opened at six o'clock, and before seven the building was completely filled. Before the services were commenced every aisle and passage-way was filled, and thousands were turned away unable to see, much less hear the speaker.

abstract: The movement made on Thursday, by Gen. GRANT, has resulted in the extension of our line has far as Thatcher's Run, on the Duncan road, an advance of about three miles beyond our former position on the left, and in the discovery of the exact position of the enemy's lines, and the works erected for their defence, as well as a more complete knowledge of the country between us and the Southside Railroad.
lead_paragraph: The movement made on Thursday, by Gen. GRANT, has resulted in the extension of our line has far as Thatcher's Run, on the Duncan road, an advance of about three miles beyond our former position on the left, and in the discovery of the exact position of the enemy's lines, and the works erected for their defence, as well as a more complete knowledge of the country between us and the Southside Railroad. The letters from our special correspondents, which we give this morning, afford a clear idea of the character and results of the late movement.

abstract: We have to-day further details of the news by the City of Manchester, via Cape Race, with [???] to the 14th inst. The mails of the Canada, with dates to the 16th, were also received yesterday. The United States frigate Niagara passed Deal on the 20th, bound westward. The steamship Ontario, which went ashore near Yarmouth, it is said will prove a total wreck. Commercial failures increase at a fearful rate; no fewer than twenty, of firms engaged in the American trade, are reported from Liverpool alone. The Duke of Newcastle, well known as one of the able school of statesmen, which included such names as CANNING, DALHOUSIE, HERBERT, GLADSTONE, and CARDWELL, and also known to very many American citizens as the chief counselor of the Prince of Wales during his tour in this country, died at his seat of Clumber Park, near Nottingham, on the 18th inst. A grand bazaar had been opened at Liverpool for the relief of rebel prisoners. Political feeling is disclaimed in the matter; but doubtless it has much to do with it. Another suicide in connection with the commercial failures has taken place in London. The Manager of the Manchester Exchange Bank in London, killed himself while laboring under excitement in regard to the affairs of the bank. Large bank failures are reported from Rio de Janeiro. The liabilities of the four suspended banks, it is said, will reach Â£1,100,000 sterling.

abstract: Preparing to squat on Pacific Coast; French Designs on Sonora, >amp;c.
snippet: Preparing to squat on Pacific Coast; French Designs on Sonora, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Among the curious items of news contained in the Paris letter which we publish this morning, is that relating to a project of colonization which the Emperor's Government have in view on the Pacific coast and of which we have heard something before. Preparatory to the introduction of the military or the political part of the enterprise, two eminent civil engineers have been employed to make an elaborate inquiry into the mineral and agricultural resources of Lower California, Sonora, and the chain of the Madre Mountains. That this survey is preliminary to another for "squatting" on the Pacific coast, is made tolerably clear, we think, from the admissions made by the Emperor's spokesman in the Corps Legislatif many months ago.

abstract: About seven o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the Greenwich-street Flouring Mill, a five story building, No. 54 Greenwich-street, and extending through the block to No. 55 Washington-street. The fire originated on the third floor of the Washington-street building, and in about two hours both buildings were consumed. The loss on stock of grain and flour is thought to be about $25,000; on engine and machinery, $15,000 and on building about $50,000. The machinery and stock are insured. HUMPHREY & CO.'s bonded warehouse, Nos. 56 and 58 Greenwich-street, and the storage warehouse of HORTON & CO., No. 53 Washington-street, were slightly damaged by water. A man whose name was not ascertained, was injured by the falling of an iron safe from building No. 54 Greenwich-street, and was taken to the City Hospital. The origin of the fire is not known. Fire-Marshal BAKER has the matter under investigation. Capt. HELME and a platoon of men from the Twenty-seventh Precinct were on hand, and rendered efficient service in protecting the property.

abstract: -Mr. JAMES R. WATERSTON, one of our distinguished artists, has in his studio at No. 235 Thompson-street, a beautiful water color of "Roslyn Castle," near Edinburgh, Scotland. abstract: The Memphis Bulletin, of the 27th says it is reported that the rebel leaders of West Tennessee are exceedingly active. They have established railroad and telegraph communication between Corinth and Jackson, and are conscripting every person able to bear arms, including old men and sending agents to every part of West Tennessee, outside our lines, for sheep, stock of all kinds, goods, money and everything that can be of service to them.

abstract: AN EXPEDITION DOWN THE RIVER.  The United States steamer Don, flagship of the Potomac Flotilla, has just returned from an expedition down the river. A short time since, at a point on the eastern shore of the Chesapeake Bay, a short distance below the mouth of the Potomac, near Wycomoco Inlet, a guerrilla parts fired into Government transports, capturing and burning one of them.

abstract: -- From an exchanged prisoner, recently arrived from Columbia, S.C., to which place the prisoners of war placed under fire in Charleston, several months ago, were recently removed, we learn that they are in a piece of woods, and at the time our informant left, most of them were without shelter of any kind. From long confinement many of them were without the necessary clothing to protect them from the weather, and the rations furnished were made up of the coarsest food, and was insufficient in quantity. No meat whatever was furnished them, though such of them as had means could purchase it. Not a few of these prisoners, all commissioned officers, have been in the hands of the rebels since the battle of Gettysburgh, nearly sixteen months, so long that they thought their Government had forgotten them. They had first been confined for several months in Libby prison, Richmond, and from there had been remoted to Macon, Ga., then to Charleston, where they had been placed under fire, and lastly to Columbia. During their stay at Charleston only one of them was wounded. A shell from one of Gen. FOSTER's batteries fell into the Marine Hospital, and exploded, wounding one of the prisoners in the leg. A few of the prisoners, unfit to be removed from Charleston, were left in the infirmary there. Our informant states that boxes containing clothing and provisions have been received lately by a few of the prisoners, and he is of the opinion that they are still passed through the lines to them if sent by the way of Hilton Head, to which place Government transports are constantly sailing. He recommends that boxes be strongly made, and bound round by iron hoops. If they are not they are liable to be opened by the rebel guard, and much of their contents abstracted. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Oct. 27.

Not a few of these prisoners, all commissioned officers, have been in the hands of the rebels since the battle of Gettysburgh, nearly sixteen months, so long that they thought their Government had forgotten them. They had first been confined for several months in Libby prison, Richmond, and from there had been remoted to Macon, Ga., then to Charleston, where they had been placed under fire, and lastly to Columbia. During their stay at Charleston only one of them was wounded. A shell from one of Gen. FOSTER's batteries fell into the Marine Hospital, and exploded, wounding one of the prisoners in the leg. A few of the prisoners, unfit to be removed from Charleston, were left in the infirmary there. Our informant states that boxes containing clothing and provisions have been received lately by a few of the prisoners, and he is of the opinion that they are still passed through the lines to them if sent by the way of Hilton Head, to which place Government transports are constantly sailing. He recommends that boxes be strongly made, and bound round by iron hoops. If they are not they are liable to be opened by the rebel guard, and much of their contents abstracted. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Oct. 27.

abstract: A very large and enthusiastic meeting was held in the Sixteenth Ward on Friday evening, to ratify the nomination of HENRY J. RAYMOND for Congress. A speech was made by F.S. LAMBERT, ESQ., and he was followed by Mr. RAYMOND, who addressed the meeting in an extended and animated review of the questions at issue.
lead_paragraph: A very large and enthusiastic meeting was held in the Sixteenth Ward on Friday evening, to ratify the nomination of HENRY J. RAYMOND for Congress. A speech was made by F.S. LAMBERT, ESQ., and he was followed by Mr. RAYMOND, who addressed the meeting in an extended and animated review of the questions at issue. In regard to the Congressional canvass, he said that he had no other motive for being a candidate except a desire to be of service to the country and the Union cause, and that as the Union men of the District, with a very considreable degree of unanimity, had thought he could do so best by going to Congress, he had accepted the nomination. He had done so, however, with the distinct statement that he reserved the right to withdraw whenever he should be satisfied that any other Union candidate could stand a better chance of carrying the district. He had made repeated personal attempts to secure an adjustment of the differences which seemed to stand in the way of harmony, but had entirely failed. He saw no way, therefore, of evading the labors and chances of the canvass, but felt bound to submit the whole matter to the action of the voters of the district. He then spoke of the importance of securing for the Union cause two-thirds of the next Congress in order to submit to the people the question of amending the Constitution so as to provide for the abolition of slavery, and said that a gain of four more members would give us the requisite number. The remainder of his speech was devoted to a discussion of the general subject. After Mr. RAYMOND closed, some eloquent remarks were made in support of his nomination by C.S. SPENCER, Esq., and a resolution was unanimously and enthusiastically passed, declaring that it was for the interest of the city and of the whole country, as well as of the sixth District, that Mr. RAYMOND should be elected.

abstract: FRIENDS: The white refugees from the South have accumulated in our vicinity to such an extent that our local charity is no longer adequate to their relief. They are still arriving in constantly increasing numbers, mostly women and children, and all of them equally destitute, homeless, and almost hopeless.

abstract: a State of the Union
snippet: a State of the Union
lead_paragraph: The President has issued a proclamation, agreeably to an act passed in the last session of Congress, declaring the admission of Nevada into the Union as a State. By the last census Nevada had a population of only about twenty-six thousand, two-thirds of whom were Indians; but the great increase of the population of the territory, and its great growth in wealth, has taken place within the last six, indeed within the last four years. Silver was discovered there in great abundance and purity, and the mining of it at once became the great interest and industry of the region. As California lay directly west of Nevada, Utah north of it, and Colorado to its eastward, it at once secured from these regions, and particularly from California, vast numbers of emigrants acquainted with mining. Our readers must remember the intense excitement which prevailed on the Pacific coast four years ago about the "Washoe" silver region, which was the first profitable mining done in what now constitutes the State of Nevada. Various fortunes waited on the territory and on its mining prospects; but it has grown with unprecedented rapidity -- distancing completely all the contiguous territories.
headline: {'main': 'NEVADA A STATE OF THE UNION', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'NEVADA A STATE OF THE UNION', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
